When Counter-Strike: Condition Zero was first announced three years ago, it seemed like a decent enough idea. The definitive first-person shooter mod was at the height of its popularity, so having a single-player game based on the winning formula sounded like a good way to win a new following and perhaps entice even more people to venture online. However, those who have been reading up on the game over the years know that development has been a bumpy ride. The duty of making Condition Zero has practically been passed around more than the collection basket at Easter Mass. What started internally at Valve Software quickly moved to Gearbox, then to Ritual Entertainment, and finally over to Turtle Rock Studios. Given such an unusual development path, Condition Zero is surprisingly enjoyable, thanks mostly to some remarkable artificial intelligence. Unfortunately, the game will be remembered as a victim of its own delays.

By now, most FPS fans at least know what Counter-Strike is and have likely played it or have seen it. For those of you who have recently been paroled from a lengthy incarceration or have awakened from a coma, Counter-Strike is a team-based tactical shooter that pits terrorists versus counterterrorists in round-based match play. In the game's current incarnation, there are two game types--bombing and hostage rescue. Bombing maps require the terrorist team to plant and detonate a time bomb in one of two bombing areas while the counterterrorists guard these sites. Hostage rescue involves having the terrorists guard computer-controlled civilians while the counterterrorists try to rescue them. In practice, both game types often result in one team or the other being eliminated in bloody, fast shoot-outs.

Players earn money based on their performances in the previous rounds, and with this money, they can buy weapons at the beginning of each subsequent round (and those who survive the last round keep their guns). The game's arsenal is based on real-life weapons, including Desert Eagle pistols, pump-action shotguns, AK-47 assault rifles, and even some exotic equipment, like tactical shields that deflect bullets.

Single-player Condition Zero is just like the multiplayer version of Counter-Strike that's been played for years, only your teammates and the enemies are replaced by computer-controlled bots. You assume the role of the commander of a counterterrorist force, and you choose your teammates from a menu of named bots. The bots vary in skill, aggressiveness, choice of weapon, and tendency to cooperate with the rest of the team. Those with greater skill and more-powerful weapons cost more points to hire, but you'll earn points steadily as you make your way through the game's campaign.

The campaign is divided into six "tours of duty," each of which consists of three maps, thus offering you a total of 18 maps for gameplay. Most of the maps are drawn from Counter-Strike's classic collection, so veterans will be familiar with classics such as Dust, Aztec, and Italy. Some of the maps have been tweaked greatly, however. For example, Militia is now vastly different from the map longtime CS players are familiar with. The above-land approach from the counterterrorist spawn area to the house has been shortened and adorned with additional rocks to hide behind, thus making life more difficult for terrorist snipers. A handful of new maps have also been included, like Stadium, a multilevel demolitions map that features a lot of narrow hallways and stairwells. Fastline should also be new to PC players, since it was borrowed from the Xbox version of Counter-Strike. It's a very small bombing map, set in a Tokyo subway, that encourages quick rounds and a frenetic pace.

Beating each map requires you to win at least three rounds against the terrorists, and you must be ahead of the terrorists by at least two successive wins while also completing a number of special challenges. These challenges usually involve getting a certain total number of kills, getting kills with a specific weapon, rescuing hostages, and/or winning a round under a certain amount of time. You don't have to complete all these challenges within the three rounds, so if you're beating the terrorists 3-1 and still have a challenge left unfulfilled, the match will continue until you've satisfied all the requirements.

The challenges vary with the difficulty level, as does the rate at which the terrorist team ramps up in skill and number. At the easiest difficulty level, you'll have few prerequisites, and the ones that are there are simple to accomplish. At the expert difficulty level, however, you'll be asked to perform some particularly tough feats, such as getting a knife kill and surviving the same round. For veterans of CS, the normal difficulty level won't be much of a challenge, but the two higher difficulty levels offer some pretty decent challenges, thanks to the surprisingly good bot AI.

The bot AI in most first-person shooters is laughably bad. Counter-Strike provides even more challenges for programmers who are attempting to design capable bots because of the relatively complex tasks these bots must perform. At any rate, we were pleasantly surprised by how clever the bots on both sides were in Condition Zero. Teammates communicate with you constantly by voice by telling you where they are, what they're doing, and if they've spotted an enemy. If the bomb carrier falls, bot CTs know to camp the dropped bomb, and the remaining terrorists are aware that they need to pick up the bomb to complete the mission. Terrorists on hostage rescue maps know that once a certain amount of time has elapsed, patrolling or camping hostage rescue points is an important strategy. They'll also plant bombs behind boxes and other defensible positions. All the bots seem to be programmed to know each map intimately and will crouch on top of good spots or will lie in wait behind strategic corners, just like an experienced human player would. Even more remarkable is that you'll see bots breaking windows and jumping down from high ledges to purposely reach other areas more quickly--even at the expense of incurring a bit of falling damage.

The bots aren't infallible, though. Occasionally you'll spot one getting hung up temporarily on some geometry. We've also seen the terrorist bots abandon planted bombs, thus allowing CTs to sneak in and defuse them without a fight. To be fair, we've also seen many human players make the same boneheaded mistakes over the years. Overall, the bots are remarkably human--and varied--in their behaviors. Some teammates will respond to your commands, while others insist on forging their own paths, which isn't terribly different from human teammates either. It's too bad there's no way to play as the terrorist side on these maps, but assuming you're willing to retry the game on higher difficulty settings after beating it on normal, there's decent value here.

Adding to the game's aesthetic significance is the fact that a special "deleted scenes" mode has been included. These deleted scenes actually comprised the single-player campaign that Ritual was working on before game development was handed off to Turtle Rock. While the 12 missions here are pretty fleshed-out--with scripted sequences and dense amounts of action--the deleted scenes, as a whole, feel like clich√©s. To anyone who's played shooters for years, the deleted scenes seem like flashbacks to the shooters of 1999 and 2000, so you'll immediately know why Ritual's project was canceled. While it's nice to have this extra content, your decision on whether to buy Condition Zero shouldn't hinge on it.

*** THIS REVIEW IS FOR COUNTER-STRIKE CONDITION ZERO DELETED SCENES ***

The only single player campaign in Counter-Strike history. It's a shame, really! It's pretty good, and I'm sure Valve could've turned Counter-Strike into their own version of CoD/Battlefield with awesome multiplayer but even equally good campaigns (the only thing I play when it comes to games like this). 

It's not a story campaign persay, it's an anthology of fully voiced missions where you play as different counter-terrorist from around the world. It's kind of like a rail-shooter mixed with Half-Life puzzle elements. It starts as a mindless shooter but then you need to start walking around in vents and parkouring up gates to get to the next place you need to get. BASICALLY, It's Half-Life, but the aliens are replaced with terrorists. 

It's good. It's okay. It's fun. BUT it can be buggy and a little glitchy. You can get stuck. But remember that Valve cut out these missions and never bothered updating them. There IS 6 bonus missions you can play once you finish the "main" campaign missions. Make sure not to miss out on those. You can tell Ritual had a lot of fun making it. Plenty of nice developer easter eggs scattered through-out. 

Highly recommend if anyone wants a Half-Life era CoD-like game, this is for you.

Counterstrike Condition Zero is the perfect CS game. Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a follow up to the original Counter-Strike game. This game was released in 2004, so almost eleven years ago. Condition Zero uses the Half-Life engine.

What we have here is a CS game which includes a single player mission pack. When it comes to playing Counter-Strike, I am more or less a newb at it. This game gave me the perfect opportunity to learn the guns, maps and mission types without the pressure of feeling like you are letting your team down by sucking. The campaign took me about four hours to complete, but this was only on Normal mode, you can go back and replay the missions on a higher difficulty to eventually work your way up to playing online.

I also found the squad management system to be a nice little feature which isn't seen in other CS games, at the start of each mission, you can choose which squad members to take with you on the mission, each of the team members have their positive and negative stats so you can really get stuck in with min-maxing them. You start out with three members and you work you way up to having a full blown squad of about eight men.

On each of the missions you also have to complete specific challenges, these can be goals set around killing a certain amount of people, winning the match in less than ninety seconds, rescuing a specific amount of hostages etc etc. This added a little variety of play, especially the challenges where you have to use a certain weapon in order to complete them. This allowed you to learn how to use other guns effectively rather than sticking with your tried and tested Rifle and Deagle.

While the graphics do not come close to looking like games we have in the current day, the game still does look nice. I wasn't put off by the dated graphics one bit; I guess that just shows how good the Half Life engine actually is!

The difficulty levels completely rely on how hard you want to make it. I started out on Normal mode just to get to grips with the game as I am newb like that; but you can work all the way up to playing as if you are in a match online and have the brutally hard experience if you want to. Easy mode is complete walk in the park though, enemies can be standing in front of you for about three seconds before they realize they should shoot you, and even then they spray bullets randomly all around you without actually hitting, so I wouldn't recommend you start out on Easy mode.

Like I said, the campaign took me about four hours to complete, but there are two or three more difficulty levels to try out, and I can see this adding a lot of variety into the game play, so I can easily see the single player alone taking about twelve hours to complete it fully on all difficulties.

I found no technical issues what so ever while playing, I would assume all the bugs and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• would of been ironed out years ago..

In conclusion I can easily recommend Counter-Strike: Condition Zero for anyone looking to get into the FPS or CS scene, it will easily give you a worthwhile experience, giving you the opportunity to learn all of the CS maps, guns and game modes in a pressure free environment.

It is the same game as Counter-Strike 1.6, but it is a lot more stable, in addition to having the same arcade mode known as "multiplayer on lan" it has a very fun campaign mode. In Windows 10, Counter-Strike 1.6 (Steam, original) constantly crashed and I had to use old executables from third-party developers to install the bots, in Counter-Strike Condition Zero everything is ready, you can choose between the map in Condition Zero version and 1.6 original. I like playing for Proton through Manjaro Linux because the API fixes anti-aliasing, texture filtering and implemeting an new modern font.

Hostages are much more alive and smart, they take command from afar, show submission to terrorists, panic in moments of combat and express relief after rescue, they crouch and go through pipes following the rescuer, they make the game more alive.

The game is very worthwhile, if you just want to have fun with the bots through the classic maps without stressing about fixing the bugs of Counter-Strike 1.6, consider buying this game.

"Would I recommend counterstrike?"  Hell #$@*(#ng yes.

This game, despite its age, was made with the perfect graphics to show just enough without bogging down simpler computers and crashing every two minutes.

This was a classic staple in high school days when a bunch of us would pitch in for LAN parties.  You know, back in dial-up days.

Half-life was a great game, story, voices, and design.  Counterstrike in my opinion is the game that accurately determines some of a gamer's true abilities.  As does Diablo 2, Contra, Mario Bro's 3, Smash Bros, Castlevania SotN, FF7 and Chrono Trigger.  Game testers would know all of these games by heart, as do many of us.  I'm no fan of CoD or Halo, but this game gives as fair chance in all perspectives.

Tour of Duty pt.1 - Breakdown
This is Counter-Strike's version of a single player campaign not named Deleted Scenes, that focuses on the core aspects of the series at large, the only difference here between this mode and a traditional online game is that you'll play against bots while trying to complete each of a map's objectives; with a few friendly handpicked bots set to back you up. While this might sound good on paper, execution wise, it leaves a lot to be desired.

Tour of Duty pt.2 - Difficulty
There are four difficulty tiers with Tour of Duty, each one ramping up the challenge as you go along. The first two tiers, if you're a CS veteran, you'll probably breeze right through them no problem, but the third tier is when this mode becomes pure agony. This is due to the fact that you're facing tougher bots that can kill you instantly if you even have your body slightly poking out from around a corner, and they can get a headshot on you within mere nanoseconds at just about any distance because, well, they're bots. That's what they're programmed to do. Another thing that adds to the difficulty is that in the final two tiers, you're going to be outnumbered by two or three bots. If you're not skilled enough to dump at least four enemies before you die, well, I got some bad news for you...

Tour of Duty pt. 3 - Ally Bots
As you progress in a tier, you'll have more points to disperse when it comes to "hiring points." This just basically means that you can always hire one bot with better AI after every map you clear, but... You probably shouldn't rely on them too much because of how wildly inconsistent they are; They're either so pensive and unsure of themselves that they find a corner to plop down at and stare off into a wall as they get shot in the back of the head or they'll be like the T-1000, just laying waste to the enemy team without so much as flinching. The enemy bots on the other hand are almost guaranteed to be hardened killers, patrolling up and down hallways and capping anybody that they run across. They're ruthless.

Tour of Duty pt.4 - Objectives
The first two tiers have simple enough objectives: Kill 5 enemies, get two kills with the MP5, etc., etc,. These are fun enough to do without really breaking up the game as a whole, but just like everything else, the game gets unbearable in the last two tiers when they start adding stuff like "get a kill with the knife" or "kill a flashbanged enemy and survive the round." I'll happily admit that I'm no CS god, so things like that are incredibly difficult for me to pull off, especially against the overcharged enemies that you face off against in those rounds. I'll also happily admit that I never got to the last and final tier, so God only knows what they expect you to do in those rounds. Kill two enemies with a frag grenade at once? Kill three people with the knife and survive the round? Sky's the limit I guess.

Combat
I'm going to be plain here: I hate the combat of 1.6, but this is mainly because I spent so many years playing Global Offensive. Going back to this washed up mess of a game is total whiplash and I just don't care for it at all. I just can't seem to tell where my bullets are going to go, and I attribute that to the game's extremely poor crosshair system. Every weapon is so highly inaccurate that my bullets just seem to dance in a perfect circle around my target's head, but, like I stated earlier, your enemies have no trouble shooting you dead the second you pop around a corner. I'll admit it: This game has made me rage more than a couple of times, and I'm not someone who gets rattled very easily.

Map Design
You of course have some CS heavy hitters like Dust, Dust II, and Office in their infancy here, but there's also a number of maps that have gone missing in modern CS, and, again, I'll be plain here: It's because most of the maps featured in this game suck. Fastline is kind of interesting, but it's way too open. Downed is too big and too open. Chateau... While I used to really like this map in my days spent with Source, Tour of Duty mode in this game has absolutely made me hate it to the point where if it was added back to Global Offensive, I'd avoid it like the black plague. Maps like the aforementioned Dust and Office have stuck around through the years because they're just objectively good maps, and they've stood the test of time. Maps like Stadium, Piranisi... They'll remain in the past for a reason.

Graphics
You can't fault this game too much for the primitive graphics, I mean, it is the Goldsrc engine after all which is, at the time of me writing up this review, over two decades old... But... This does mean that the game can't ever be "prettied up." Even if you download a bunch of mods, they won't have any fancy shader effects on them, no reflections, etc. Graphics doesn't mean much, but when the gameplay is so terrible as it is in 1.6, some fancier graphics would actually make a difference for me.

Sound
Counter-Strike was never known for having a stellar soundtrack or anything, so I don't have much to say about the generic music featured here, but I can say that, without a doubt, the bot chatter pack in this game is absolutely atrocious. Your buddies sound like stone cold nerds, and, I know nerds are the clientele for Counter-Strike and I'm one of them, I don't like hearing these guys sound as square as they do. It's just a choice of preference, but still.

Conclusion
I can't recommend this game because it's just not fun. Not 100% fun anyway. I'd rank it as being 30% fun and 70% hair-pulling frustration. I loved the first two difficulty tiers because they offered a fair challenge, but the third tier wasted so much of my life that I just had no more energy to push on, which brings me to another point: With this game being as difficult as it is, why in the world aren't there any achievements?! I understand that this is an old game but, come on... Even I would have stuck around past my frustrations to get some hard earned achievements, but with no incentive to keep going? No dice. I uninstalled this game and don't have any intentions on playing it again.

I bought this game originally at Best Buy in 2005 and didn't load it onto Steam with the product key until college. Needless to say that my "52 hours on record" is completely false. That number is closer to 5000 hours on record. I must have played this almost every day after school with friends from 7th grade all the way through my senior year of high school. 

The core gameplay, even to this day, is incredibly enjoyable. It's why today, 18 years after release, people are still actively on here playing. The map mods that people created on this game are second to none. I remember when I first discovered the "surf" mechanic, and that there will around 30 maps created to fit this concept. The map mods were insane. Springfield from the Simpsons, Tattooine from Star Wars, someone even created a map that perfectly details your nearest Wal-Mart! The creativity astounded me and I loved every second of it. Unfortunately most of these are dead and buried, as the player base (while still going) is nowhere where it used to be.

Some of my fondest gaming memories are from this game, and booting it up today gives me such nostalgia. While I had been an avid fan of gaming already, this cemented my interest in being a "gamer".
If you've played this game in your childhood, regardless of your current age, this game will bring you the nostalgia of your childhood period.

1. Bots are insane. Compared to modern CS this bots can easily destroy you on hard or higher difficulties. 
2. Tons of maps, skins, customized campaigns or whatever you want to add to it. 
3. Unbalanced weapons. There are just a few weapons that can be useful in this game. 
4. Amazing sound design.
5. You can't marry Maverick, but you can hear him say NO to every order you give him every day if you want. 

I'd recommend this game to any son/father that wants to have some fun in a game with no PC requirements. 10/10 you will enjoy it.

[h1]Counter-Strike: Condition Zero - Review[/h1]

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a game, that does not really have any new features, except for bots. Other than that, it's almost the same game as the classic Counter-Strike. In terms of the "campaign", it's poor - boring and unnecessarily hard. Your bots get blocked on ladders. Enemy bots have an aim assist, so I found the game quite annoying on higher difficulties. I played all the difficulties, and yeah, Expert was a pain in the ass.
I can't say anything about multiplayer - didn't play it too much.

Anyway, the game is definitely not revolutionary. If someone enjoys playing vs annoying bots, or maybe got nostalgic an wants to play their childhood game - go ahead. Otherwise, I do not recommend.

The Tour of Duty 'campaign' is ok, it's fun to play an old CS game with bots which wasn't possible without mods before this game.

The Deleted Scenes campaign however is brilliant, a true Counter-Strike single player campaign. Ritual Entertainment's work here is much better than the bot matches labelled as a 'campaign' in the main game. This should have been in the main game and not hidden away. At least we can be glad it was even released at all and not just joined the pile of unreleased Valve projects. It also received an additional six missions in later updates that are playable from the World Map. If you're a Counter-Strike fan, give both a go but if you only have the time to try one, choose Deleted Scenes.

Classic CS with bots. Runs on a potato and still more fun than most newer games.

In regards to the Deleted Scenes content:

Being released only months prior before source back in 2004, I felt like this game was swept under the rug. This game is a half-life inspired campaign that puts you in a number of counter-terrorist scenarios. From recovering nuclear stolen warheads, to hostage rescue mission within secret cartel bases hidden in the jungle ---- This game offers an array of thrilling and exciting missions that offer a decent challenge.

Condition Zero Experienced a lot of setbacks during its development, yet the intricate design of the game, from level pathways, Easter eggs, to the overall setting of each level certainly highlights the developers' passion in producing this game. It's a shame this game has drifted into obscurity, for it is a must play for any lover of the FPS genre.

Counter Strike, the world's most popular first-person shooter game. Arguably over 2 million people are playing this game at this very moment as you are reading this post. The game was developed from the old game known as Quack, which had poor graphics but was one of the most addictive games of its time. The game has had many improvements since then, at first counter strike was not known to many and it wasn't until counter strike 1.5 that people really got into this game. The next version which was condition zero was even a better version of the previous 1.5, but then 1.6 really changed things and set the standards for playing counter strike in the big leagues. The next version which was counter strike source had a completely new engine and many liked it but most did not, it is really more about what a player prefers I can play counter strike 1.6 but if someone asks me to play source I would keep playing because they are equally fun to play but again it is based on preference. The next revolution in Counter Strike is Counter Strike Global Offensive which has a touch of 1.6 and Source. So Counter Strike Global Offensive is the new thing in the world of Counter Strike and is said to be the standard game used worldwide for the big leagues like WCG.

A game to put Half-Life 1 [and Valve] to shame.
This hidden gem runs on the GoldSrc engine, but really showcases what the engine has to offer.
Each mission has it's own background story. Throughout the game you will come across Corny dialogue makes for a good laugh.
The level design is convincing and realistic, with custom models for each level.
Small scripted events with custom animation make this game immersive.
Once you play this game you will realise Half-Life didn't live up to it's full potential for what the GoldSrc engine had to offer.
I will replay again, again and again.

Are you lonely on a weekend and have no plans? Do you wish Counter-Strike had a single player campaign? Well fret not! Counter-Strike: Condition Zero surely does hit the mark of single player content in a Counter-Strike game, but that's about it. The single player content is kind of like Mission Mode in Mario Kart DS or Spec Ops in the Call of Duty: Modern Warfare series. This games name also match the amount of active players, 0. There is literally no reason to get this game nowadays when CS:GO has more to offer and CS:Source is just better. But, if you're an avid Counter-Strike fan and want to collect all the games, I'd say wait for it to go on sale. Damn near every Summer and Winter you can pick up this game for a dollar. Not to mention the development process behind this and CS:CZ Deleted scenes makes this an interesting piece of Valve history.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a first-person shooter game published by VAlve.  It is an improved version of the original Counter-Strike, which was a mod for the game Half-Life.  Initially focused on the single-player "story" mode, however, it was cut from the main version of the game and was later released under the name "Deleted Scenes"

People complain about CS S being the worst in the series, cause they don't want to admit Condition Zero is truly the black sheep of Counter Strike.

First of all, there are no differences between 1.6 and CZ (if there is any). Graphically is the same. Same weapons. Same HUD but with different color. The only good improvement I noticed was adding the Spetsnaz and Midwest Militia. 

But the worst thing is that still uses GoldSrc... in 2004... That same year Half Life 2 and CS S arrived with the new Source engine, which is fresh even 20 years later with ragdoll mechanics, better graphics, etc. I understand Valve and TurtleRock Studios had issues doing the game, but looks like a joke that in the same year we got a game made with the Half Life engine and its sucesor.

I said there were barely some changes, right? Well, we've got some kind of "operations", which are basically levels trying to stop terrorists with bots. So almost nothing that makes this game superior than 1.6, Source or Global Offensive. 

And for last, game includes Deleted Scenes, which is the only thing worth playing from this. Originally this game was suposed to include campaign, and I must admit Valve and TurtleRock made their best with that. Might not be the glory, but it's was more amusing than base game.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

How are those checklist format reviews helpful at all? I keep seeing more and more of them pop up and they keep getting to the top of store pages as "most helpful" when they really don't say anything. Here is an example:

---{ ? / 10 }---

‚òê 2
‚òê 3
‚òê 4
‚òê 5
‚òê 6
‚òê 7
‚òê 8
‚òê 9
‚òë 10

Based on the information provided, can you guess what game this review is for? What's it about? What kind of game is it?

Point is, these reviews are completely interchangeable. I bet if you took this exact review, and copy and pasted it to every game in your library, you'd get the top review for half of the games you put it on, even if you didn't change the check marks to fit each individual game.

In my opinion, the Steam community should stop encouraging this format and instead downvote them all into oblivion. Maybe it's just me, and I guess it's not THAT big a deal, but for someone that puts at least some effort into the reviews they write, it is a little disheartening that the steam community prefers lazy checklists that ultimately don't say anything specific about the games in question. Plus I don't see how they could ever actually influence someone's decision to purchase a game or not when so little information is given.

Anyone agree or am I the only one that wants to read legitimately helpful reviews for games I might be interested in?

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is an expansion pack and, in a sense, a visual upgrade for Counter-Strike 1.6, with more HD looking models and new detail textures, which were created for the game's exclusive maps for a better graphical experience, but there's more than meets the eye.

CS:CZ introduced a campaign mode, called the Tour of Duty, which is treated as a single-player experience, consisting of tasks that the player must complete if they want to advance to the next mission. The Tour of Duty campaign consists of 6 chapters, called "tours", with each tour containing 3 maps (missions) in it. In order to efficiently play against the enemy team and be able to have a chance on winning them, it is strongly recommended/most definitely essential that one recruits members for their team, though that comes with a cost. The amount/skill-strength of soldiers that the player is able to recruit is determined by Reputation Points, which are gained by completing missions (though some are also granted to the player at the beginning of the tour, and the amount depends on the difficulty chosen). In general the campaign is pretty easy to learn and while it can sometimes be frustrating due to either some ridiculous tasks (especially in harder difficulties) or just the difficulty of the game itself, it's still a fun and addictive experience.

Since CS:CZ is the first game that introduced built-in bots, the game also technically introduced an offline (multiplayer) mode, which gives the player the ability to either target practice or just kill some time, but everything else is identical to CS 1.6.

CS:CZ had received quite the undeserving flak because it was released in the same year as the Source engine, which was Valve's breakthrough product, and since with it also came Counter-Strike: Source, it's only natural that it would unfortunately outshine this game in every aspect and place it as an "obsolete on arrival" product. Also the fact that the development state of this game had been bad in every aspect, having changed development teams twice over the course of 4 years, which obviously brought over significant delay, very sadly helped in making Condition Zero lose most of its relevance by the time that it hit the shelves.

With everything being said above, CZ's infamous reputation among the Counter-Strike franchise is attributed not as much to it being "lackluster" as it is to it being unlucky due to all the delays, overhauls as well as the horrendously bad timing of its release with the Source engine. Otherwise, this game has much to offer and its status as an underrated cult-classic is here to stay.

[i]*Since this is a remaster to Counter-Strike and I feel like some of what I have said on the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/ciocolici/recommended/10?snr=1_5_9__402]review for that game[/url] applies here as well, I am going to quote that stuff here. Afterwards I am going to write how I feel about what the remaster brings new, and of course also about Deleted Scenes.[/i]

[quote]Counter-Strike used to be my curse and my primary hobby. I have thousands upon thousands of hours spent in this game. So many nights... I had a dozen of Steam accounts created only to play CS on a (now dead) platform called PlayZeek, which was kind of what FaceIT is for CS:GO. This game represents my childhood and when I say CS all I think about is nostalgia.

CS's middlename is ESports, and it would not be an understatement if we would say that ESports wouldn't be today what it is, without this game. This game's ESports has died, obviously, but the game's community did not. Which is mindblowing. You don't have an issue finding a server with players at any given time, night or day. For a game so old it's wow. So if you're nostalgic and want to get back into this game, you won't have one problem, even after all this time. 

But for someone that has never played this before.. it is hard, it takes thousands of hours to learn the recoil and gameplay, has not aged well, looks ugly and the gameplay can probably only be understood and enjoyed by people that have understood and enjoyed it at its time. 

Going back to the game for a little bit of time was something unique. The feels, the nostalgia, the sounds, the gameplay, everything sends me back to my childhood, to a time without adult issues and only free time to waste (or spend) playing CS and dreaming of becoming the best. And expected to start the game, join a server, die instantly and then leave. But it actually made me play more. And I actually started to enjoy it. But I also understood the reasons why I would never come back to the game. What I have once seen as masterpiece, I now see as old gameplay. I still find it fun, to a point, I just can't see it with the same eyes I once did. 

This is a relic, a masterpiece for its time. To a point it can still be for most people that have used to play it at that time. I think updating the graphics to today standards, and maybe meddling a little bit with the gameplay, would make this game appeal to new people. The fact that this game has never died after sooooo many years, and it still has such an alive playerbase, says a lot. Normally I would suggest you play CS:GO instead of this, but I see them as totally different games, for probably different players. This one requires way more skill and it is way more punishing. What this game needs is the same gameplay and feel, but with today visuals. CS:CO (Classic Offensive) is more fitting to suggest here, but unfortunately, at the time writing this, it is still in development.[/quote]

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero has always been, for me, the better-looking same Counter-Strike that nobody likes. And that's what it is to a degree. It looks a little better, has other sounds, some new stuff like singleplayer with bots and that's all. It is Valve's attempt to remaster it. Most players did not move to it, neither did the CS pro scene. I, for one, now after trying it again, like them both, but prefer the original. They both have pros and cons, but in the end they're both the same game. I see it only about preference and taste. I like the original more than this. CZ also has way tinier playerbase since forever, and while in CS I had no issues finding servers with players to play on, in CZ I struggled to find what I was looking for: anything not DM. And those that I found were using the original CS maps and models and stuff, I did not even feel like playing CZ. But there still are players playing, which really is something to applaud. 

There's then Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes. If CZ was an attempt to remaster the original, CZ DS is an attempt to make a campaign with story and all. And, although many were okay-ish with it, for me it was a disaster. Did only enjoy it because it was CS gameplay, other than that... boring, boring and... boring. Story is there like it isn't, and it's just like... the way the original CS works gameplaywise, movementwise and so on, it does not work as a singleplayer campaign. And this is a weird statement, since the same movement system is present in Half-Life, and dozens of mods of Half-Life, but that's how I felt. Boring and uninteresting. There are so many mods that use Half-Life and look & play one thousand times better than this wannabe game. 

So CZ is a yes, if you find it better than the original, but CZ DS is a big no, it should not have been made in the first place.

Condition Zero in my opinion is much better than the original Counter Strike, even though the differences between them arent huge. The main differences are Condition Zero has Bots built in, slightly better graphics, and maybe a little more features, but thats it. Everything else feels the same, the gameplay is almost the same. Today we have Source and Global offensive which are newer and have much better graphics, but for people who still enjoy the classic, simpler gameplay, Condition Zero is a better choice than the original Counter Strike, despite the fact the differences arent that huge between them.

COUNTER-STRIKE: CONDITION ZERO - Counter-Strike, the one Esport where players have peace of mind in celebrating the fact that the sport is PLAY TO WIN, not PAY TO WIN. as in another Counter-Strike review that i previously wrote, i must say here again that the only variance is skill. Although there are not as many servers in CS: CZ as there are in other Counter-Strike games, this game is a nostalgic, addictive and quite fun Online Action FPS game. Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is, to me, one of those rare Multiplayer online action games where you are driven by the perfection you are immersing yourself in. 
Think CS V1.6 meets excitement and addiction, as opposed to religion and competition. - Deokumar Gandharry

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero and the Deleted Scenes merge the fun of Counter Strike with the strategy of Half Life. 

Counter Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes comes bundled with the game, which adds a great campaign. The AI in Condition Zero was revolutionary for the time, and still holds up today. I hope that Valve remasters CS: CZ, as it was some of the most fun I have ever had.

Overall, I'd rate CS: CZ and CS: CZ DS 8.5/10 - The gameplay is enjoyable, even when you are losing, and the campaign is one of the best that I have ever played.

To start out, I've really got more like five hundred hours in this game. I started playing it obsessively long before Valve thought to add playtime records.

It's fun.

The bots are fairly competent as long as you disallow them from buying grenades and the list of maps that come prepackaged far outstrips that of the original Counter-Strike. (They're also far prettier, at least as much as they can be on the GoldSrc engine). Hostages are, as always, somewhat brain-dead, but they're nowhere near as bad as the ones in Counter-Strike: Source--although the fact they all wear identical orange jumpsuits makes me wonder who really are the good and bad guys. Isn't variety the spice of life?
Sound design and quality are improved slightly from the original game and many of the less generic maps lack that kitchen_rats look that's become so indicative of Half-Life's engine, so that's a plus. At the same time, a lot of maps have odd collision detection issues and I'm somewhat bothered by the fact that Counter-Terrorists are as chatty over the radio as their criminal counterparts.

The truth? If you can handle the truth. This is more of a collectors item at this point in time. Paid for game before it came out. No regrets. Source was performing poorly on week old 2 grand of hardware in it's debut just to see drunken rag doll physics and less than 20 frames per second whereas this I had 200. The bots can get a little manic over the radio. When you buy armor it makes some weird squeak. If the bots do not know the map it kicks all players in vintage style instead of calculate without kicks like more modern work. Back then it was very nice and is now still acceptable work looking back at how many way-points I made.  Joe bots were the best. They took orders and did not go off into AI tangents spamming the radio panicking making weird whistle squeak sighs and stuff. I've never bothered to test their voice synthesis capabilities. Hearing Sam do the national anthem in the 1980's and getting this 20 years later was a bit of a prank. Horrible voice work in some areas. Condition Zero comes across as a map and skin pack, built-in bots and single player which is great for those offline. It works as multiplayer also. The physics are slightly different and the weapons cannot be sighted in properly. At one point got head shots for a month straight now hardly ever get them. There is no way I can change that much. I make my own weapons, no spread. Dead on. So like all FPS. Double-tap! Short bursts. The chest gets headshots now? Odd.

When counter strike 1.6 came out, it came out as a mod, lots of people started trying it out, now its a official game.
But if you own counter strike 1.6 why should you get this game?
Well Condition zero is counter strike source mixed with counter strike 1.6 .


+ Gameplay :
The Gameplay is improved from CS 1.6 because maps have much better graphics, and there is condition zero deleted scenes, for just some single player fun.


+ Sound :
Sound hasn't been much of a problem in counter strike, it hasn't been a problem because all the the weapons make proper shooting and reloading sounds. When you kill someone the sound you get is awesome.
When you switch teams the noise you get is absolutely realistic, and its awesome, you get the whole dying effect.


+ Graphics :
The graphics still use the half life 1 engine, but the textures, models, weapons and maps have got much better graphics.

In all honesty, Condition Zero is actually my favorite CS. Millenials would probably say either 1.6 or Source is their favorite and zoomers would say it's CS:GO. So why the fuck am I saying it's Condition Zero for me? Well I always liked to play with bots because I was, and most definitely still am too shit for PvP, but 1.6 didn't have them integrated and my old ass PC from eons ago could not run CS:S. That's not a joke, I did not have the RAM nor GPU to actually be capable of running Source games, so my best option was to play CZ. The CT bots I enlisted to my team along the way in my many Tours of Duty were my compatriots. Gus, Kenny, Kent, Travis, Maverick, Rooster, Brent. These bots with the attention span of a goldfish fought by my side through many battles across the world against those terrorists always up to no good, planting bombs and taking hostages.

Ok now that I'm done with the Vietnam nostalgia part is is honestly the sole reason for me loving this game, let's shit on it. 
Condition Zero's AI and the game itself can really be janky as hell. Your team bots will probably not listen to you even more than the CS:GO bots already don't, and their pathfinding can be especially scuffed at times and lead to a lot of lost battles. I have far too many tales of events like this happening in maps like Militia. On top of that there's also a few little things like bots not attempting to refuse the bomb unless you're already dead (even if there are no T's left) and them fucking up the defusal process as if they were a player constantly pressing and letting go of the button.

Despite those issues, I still can't help but love CZ above all others, it's just fun. No Just the peaceful robotic sounds of "No sir." "Uhhh negative" "Nnnnope", followed by a lot of death choking and the many "and that's how it's done", "way to be team" and  "whoo"'s of victory.

tl;dr I'm a fucking anomaly that thinks Condition Zero is the best CS game.

DON'T BOTHER WITH THIS OR VANILLA CS AS THEY ARE NOT SUPPORTED AND WILL NOT EVEN OPEN!
I bought this as part of Counter Strike Complete as I wanted to play CS Condition Zero (Complete includes CS, CS Condition Zero and CS Source).
Both CS and CS CZ will not even open and run after lots of searching and trying to report a fault it became evident that STEAM DO NOT SUPPORT CS OR CS CZ.
I played CS Source on the day of purchase for a several hours which seems to play without any problems for me on Linux Steam.
Tried on the following day to get vanilla CS and CS CZ running to no avail and unable to get support from Steam, after searching online it became evident that nobody is supporting vanilla CS or CS CZ.
This begs the question why steam are selling a product which doesn't work and that they offer no support for (and neither does anyone else).
To make matters worse, when I requested a refund less than 24 after purchasing the CS Complete pack I received and email stating that as I played the purchase for more than 2 hours that my request for a refund was refused (well in fairness I had played a third of it for more than 2 hours as two thirds of the pack does not work at all).
If CS and CS CZ doesn't work then for pity sake steam, STOP SELLING IT - THIS MAKES YOU LOOK QUESTIONABLE TO SAY THE LEAST.

OH BOY! This review is gonna be split into 2 parts. The first about the main game and the second about the deleted scenes.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero, at its surface is just Counter-Strike. But after that the game is actually Counter-Strike, but with more stuff. You get a short campaign that is literally just starting an offline match with bots. The only positive thing about the campaign is that I like the AI and how you set up the crew. I know I don't have much playtime and that's because I didn't bother finishing the "Campaign". And it's just Counter-Strike with the multiplayer.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes is Condition Zero's older and cooler brother. It has an actual interesting series of missions. While it lacks multiplayer, whether that be because it focuses on the campaign or because its incomplete. I would honestly recommend this game just for deleted scenes.

The weird bastard child of Counter-Strike. It went through a bunch of versions leading to it being released just before Counter-Strike Source, meaning it was immediately obsolete. It didn't offer much reason to buy it over 1.6 at the time either, with most of the new features being backported into that game as well.

The main reason to buy this nowadays is to check out Condition Zero Deleted Scenes, which is an incredibly odd single player campaign that can feel like a slog at times but has some really cool ideas. The icebreaker level and final level are especially cool.

Maybe don't buy this at full price (even if it is already cheap), since the main game itself isn't really worth it. If you do buy this, it should be purely as a curiousity for Deleted Scenes.
I would love to give a Legendary Status to this game.

This was the First Valve game I ever played. While still a bit primitive compared to Today's games, Counter-strike: CZ is still really fun to play.  

I was surprised that there was still an active community for this, although I didn't join any servers, and stuck mainly to Single player. The AI in the single player isn't the best, but they get the job done, and when push comes to shove, they can somewhat hold their own. Its cool that each one has a minor personality, being named, having a weapon of choice, and some stats to them. sure, they're idiots, but they're LOVABLE idiots. x3

The Single player consists of many different maps, with different objectives besides shooting the bad dudes, defusing the bomb, and rescuing people. For example, one map might require you to kill 5 people, and make sure one of those kills is with a shotgun. Another may ask you to kill a person, and win the round within a minute. all the while, you have to be winning more rounds than the bad dudes.

Overall, its not the polished game that is Global Offensive, but it hits the right notes, and is pretty fun, even if playing with the bots.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is an expansion of Counter-Strike 1.6.

There are two primarily different games here: Condition Zero, and Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes (the latter of which I'm not going to go into.)

Condition Zero itself is an upgrade from classic CS. It has a singleplayer campaign system called Tour of Duty that can be modded in all sorts of ways. You can create campaign packs that have new allies for you to fight with, new enemies for you to face, an entirely different map order from the default Tour of Duty, or you can just outright create a completely new campaign with new maps and new allies and new enemies and new challenges.

Sadly, those are the primary selling points at this rate. The multiplayer playerbase, from what I've heard, is basically dead. It's not like I play on MP servers anyways: I absolutely SUCK at multiplayer FPSes.

My first game ever was CS:CZ which one of my cousins got for me, a cracked client. I spent countless hours in the game, since back then I did not have friends, or an internet connection to play with online, so I played the single player missions for hours on end. Nostalgia hit hard when I purchased a copy for myself and started playing it.
Old school FPS at it's finest.

Now most people who play Counter-Strike grew up with 1.6. I grew up with Condition Zero. I had both games on our house PC but I spent 95% of my time on CZ. Why? Because it had bots, and fantastic ones at that. We didn't have internet at the time so most my time was spent killing bots over and over on different maps. We got internet access down the line but, considering the time, it was very slow. So I used to browse FPSBanana (now GameBanana) for hours looking for maps and skins to download and then waiting an excruciating amount of time for them to finish. I would then install them and it's almost playing a new game! When people ask me what my childhood was in term of games, very few games spring to mind. Need for Speed 2, Virtua Cop 2 and Condition Zero.

Now obviously, people say this is just a reskin of Counter-Strike 1.6 with bots, which it is. But the fact that it is, makes it so much better for me. Who wouldn't want Counter-Strike 1.6 with better skins, models and textures? AND bot support?

Should you play it now? Well if you're looking for quintessential old online Counter-Strike experience, you should go with Counter-Strike 1.6, as its community is still thriving and is more active than CZ. If you want the most active Counter-Strike scene, CSGO is your place to go. If you're looking for the best single-player experience with community mods, maps and skins, or if you're stuck at home with no internet, which I wonder how you're reading this in the first place, Source is your game, since CSGO has limited moddability. But it doesn't mean you shouldn't give this a try, even if you're just buying this to complete your Counter-Strike collection, in which case you would already have this in your library. Condition Zero is essentially single-player CS1.6, and if that interests you then by all means!

Even though it's old, for me it's the first experience that was great, as you see 7h of nonstop playing is saying something, learning all the key binds and such, isn't hard at all, bought with cs bundle.

Basically, recommended.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero takes the classic gameplay from the original and cranks it up a notch with updated character models, weapons, and map textures. Many of the original maps felt like new and even the sounds were changed. While some of those changes were not necessarily better for the game, the concept of a new Counter-Strike at the time was really exciting to me. One of the most interesting parts about this release is that it included a single-player campaign. It's age definitely shows now but there are some hilariously silly moments in that campaign because of a few glitches and animation hiccups. This game doesn't hold up well due to its low player base but I will always remember the fun I had, especially when I ran one of the few active surf servers from the time. If you are looking for a piece of Counter-Strike history to remind you of how things used to be, then Condition Zero is no less than that. Game on.

This is without a doubt my favorite game in the Counter-Strike series. I've liked CS ever since I was first introduced to it (rather late, circa 2007). The thing is, I always preferred playing with bots or via LAN with people I knew (ideally in co-op against bots!) instead of having to deal with toxicity of online players and shaky Internet connection.

Then I discovered CS:CZ, a full-fledged Counter-Strike, but with extra single-player components. Introduction of bots was nothing new to me, because I was already familiar with Source (where bots were present), though bots must have been a great new feature back when the only CS was 1.6. It's worth to mention that bots in CS:CZ are actually very good, I wouldn't be surprised if Normal difficulty in CZ was harder than Expert in CS:GO. I spent a lot of time playing the Tour of Duty campaign and a-little-bit-generic-but-fun-anyway Deleted Scenes, which other CS games never offered.

What about multiplayer, though? Well, as I said, it's a full-fledged Counter-Strike. The multiplayer component is still there, almost the same as in the 1.6 iteration, but better. Improvements from 1.6 include better graphics, customizable weapon loadouts (you don't need to type 43828383 everytime you want to get your regular loadout anymore!), one extra faction (skin) per side and the aforementioned bots. Unfortunately, CZ is lacking in the most important aspect of multiplayer: players. With the game being very much forgotten, it doesn't have nearly as many players as CS 1.6. If I were to choose CS:CZ or 1.6 for a multiplayer match on LAN, however, I'd go with CZ any day.

Condition Zero is basically an expansion pack to 1.6, focusing a lot on single-player, but also polishing the classic multiplayer experience along the way. It fills a niche no other game in the series does by catering to solo players.

Condition Zero is the dark horse of the franchise. It was meant to be a Counter-Strike game with a proper single player experience, but sadly, the development hell it went through made that very hard.
In itself, it is not a very innovative game: the graphics are average (especially compared to CS: Source which was released shortly after) and the shooting mechanics don't change that much from CS1.6. But if you want some single player experience, then this is the best game of the series.
The single player campaigns are interesting, atmospheric and challenging. Some gameplay mechanics and graphic features also improved, though not very significantly. The additional missions in Deleted Scenes are also quite a nice bonus. Overall, the game is quite good, despite not improving much in a gameplay and visuals, and you still get a game with a nice multiplayer mode.
It is not a mind-blowing game, but Condition Zero might be fun for people who are looking for a more casual and solitary Counter-Strike experience.

She turns to me..........
[h1]The Pain Shoots up my Leg[/h1]
My knee bends, and I lean on the door frame.
Symbolic.
I'm leaning on this community again.
She rushes towards me.
And like a child I stop her.
Some dignity. Please.
I didn't choose this Condition.
And there are Zero individuals here that know how to treat it.
There used to be around 3 thousand in the community with this condition.
Now.
A little under 800.
She knows this.
[h1] Why did it Take You so Long to Leave?[/h1]
She asks.
You're complaining, but why did you stay here for so long?
Did you plan to meet Gary or-
No.
I cut her off.
My budget is strict.
And I've been saving up to leave this place for some time.
However...
[h1] My Time Spent Here was Valuable [/h1]
I learned a lot.
I say, coughing into my elbow.
I reveal the flask in my jacket.
I drink the last of my Eagle Rare.
I toss it at my Counter.
The Strike it makes is dull.
I wipe my mouth.
And continue.
[h1]I Learned the Games They Play. [/h1]
And this condition is what taught me.
I even found my companion.
Her face morphs from sad, to confusion, to wonder.
Before she asks, I know the words.
And whistle and yell, "Come'ere Bull."
A pup darts out from the back office.
And sits in front of me.
My good boy.
Her face seems solemn.
[h1] Did you Ever Finish Your Missions [/h1]
She asks.
I nod, and lift the pup into my arm.
I did.
They wanted an Expert.
And I did it.
It was fun. 
It felt near impossible at points.
But it was fun. 
I say turning back towards the door.
Can I at least walk with you?
She begs.
Sure, but...
[h1] I Don't Know What More to Say[/h1]
We begin to walk.
We reminisce about our younger years.
What brought us here.
Snoop Dogg's Drop it Like it's Hot.
A kid screaming to get off him.
Some Flavour.
There's silence.
Do you honestly think you'll return.
I chuckle.
But a sudden wave of realization flows over me.
I pass the pup to her.
I run back to my office.
I forgot.
I hadn't Deleted the Scenes
[h1] I Reach my Office [/h1]
I was so stressed, the keys dropped as soon as I opened the doors.
The computer illuminating the darkness in the office.
I delete every scene, the case is closed.
I finished my missions, but I'm not doing the paperwork.
I hear my door close.
Janitor.
Noise begins outside.
I walk to my door.
Locked.
I reach for my pocket.
Empty.
The keys are on the other side of the door. 
What kind of world must this be, for something as soft as this.
To lock me out.
Disappointment sets in.
The noise outside is louder.
I walk over to my window.
The mods.
They're back.
I never did find out where the source was.
I grin.
Command.
Tattooed across my left hand.
Is the last thing that collides with the glass of my office window.
I slide down the gutter...

This is the greatest Counter-Strike game in the series. You have the awesome gameplay of 1.6 with extra content. A single player campaing, challenge mode, bots, two new characters to play as, and new maps. Yes, this has a single player component, which was sadly not brought back for CS: Source and Global Offensive. It's great, and underappreciated. It's not as linear as many seem to say, but it's still a bit linear. There's bonus missions available in the world map, so it's not over once you finish the main ones. It's a very good experience, and one you should definitely play.

As I said, the game has new maps. It also has new versions of 1.6 maps, along with their original incarnations. If you prefer 1.6's Italy, it's right there for you. Of course like 1.6, you can download custom maps to play on. There's a ton to choose from online. This game has a challenge mode called Condition Zero. You choose a map and select your teammates. It's a ton of fun. Like with multiplayer maps, you can download custom challenges. 

Definitely get Condition Zero. It's a complete package that's spectacular. :D

I'm not going to shit on Counter Strike: Condition Zero. It was probably too late (even if it was released on time) to be any kind of retail replacement of the original mod. [i]Like, they invented Steam so they could patch Counter-Strike automatically.[/i] Furthermore, CZ was shuffled around to various developers, blah blah, and was basically used as some kind of business bargaining chip in the later days of the Valve/Sierra entanglement. See the NoClip Half-Life documentary for that.

I didn't really dig the Q3A style bot match part of the main product, and I don't think I've ever hopped on a CZ server. Nicer graphics aside, I don't think anyone would want to have two competing versions of (GoldSRC) Counter Strike, and they should have just shipped the single player stuff, now known as the 'deleted scenes'.

The deleted scenes are what you should take a look at. It is some damn fine looking GoldSrc. Awesome geometry and clean texture alignment abounds, in realistic looking environments. I haven't played some of the great GoldSrc mods yet, but I've played enough to be really impressed with what I saw. While the texture resolution isn't as high as you would like, it's all detailed and proportionate. Pick it up for 5$. [spoiler]There's this one kinda hand drawn bathroom mirror reflection that blew my mind. Check it out.[/spoiler]

[h1] Counter-Strike: Condition Zero [/h1]

An Iconic title among the line of the legendary series of Counterstrike games. Counter-Strike: Condition Zero (CS: CZ) a first-person shooter, action, multiplayer video game and the sequel to the original Counter-Strike. The game was released in 2004 via both retail stores and Steam and uses the GoldSrc engine. Published and developed by Valve. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1906154053

Unlike other Counter-Strike games Counter-Strike: Condition Zero (CS: CZ) comes with a single-player mission pack with the player unlocking maps and more. 

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero was originally designed to introduce a single-player Counter-Strike experience and therefore it has more in-depth single-player modes available than other entries in the series. In addition to two different single-player modes, the traditional multiplayer mode is also available

Even after 16 years of lifetime, this game still gets a daily player count, Which surprises me every time I look at that player stat. 

The gameplay I anything to write home about after so many years and playing throw all the Counterstrike titles, but The gameplay still holds up somewhat. 
Counter-Strike: Condition Zero (CS: CZ) was never a perfect game but it did its job well of entertaining us over the years. 
The game has many issues but the nostalgia punch never lets me focus on that. But which might bother someone whose not a fan. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1892152465

If you're a fan of the Counter-Strike line up, I would say give Counter-Strike: Condition Zero (CS: CZ) ago, you will enjoy this. 
This game still throws me back to my childhood me and my cousins kicking Bot asses in-game. 

Tho someone new to counter-strike won't care about Counter-Strike: Condition Zero (CS: CZ) but this game will always have a special place in my heart. 

Here are some more of my [url=steamcommunity.com/id/BiteMexD/recommended] Reviews [/url]if you're interested..

Condition Zero is odd. Aside from graphical upgrades to the base game, it's basically just a reskin of the original Counter-Strike. If you already own the original Counter-Strike and want to try Condition Zero, you'll be left pretty disappointed as I was, since it's just that - a prettier reskin. The single player "Tour of Duty" mode is a novel concept but it just boils down to bot matches where you do mundane tasks. I'd love to see that concept revisited in CS:GO with the whole "pick your team" thing just have it more fleshed out and meaningful.

As for Condition Zero Deleted Scenes - it's an interesting way to spend your time. It's just anything "fantastic", definitely not, but Deleted Scenes is about the only time when Counter-Strike tried to have a sort of "story mode". You play through various missions playing for various factions like the Spetsnaz or the FBI, and you simply go through a linear map and clear objectives. It's an interesting idea but the execution is very wonky. Still, if you're itching for something different - give Condition Zero Deleted Scenes a shot!

To start out, I've really got more like five hundred hours in this game. I started playing it obsessively long before Valve thought to add playtime records.

It's fun.

The bots are fairly competent as long as you disallow them from buying grenades and the list of maps that come prepackaged far outstrips that of the original Counter-Strike. (They're also far prettier, at least as much as they can be on the GoldSrc engine). Hostages are, as always, somewhat brain-dead, but they're nowhere near as bad as the ones in Counter-Strike: Source--although the fact they all wear identical orange jumpsuits makes me wonder who really are the good and bad guys. Isn't variety the spice of life?
Sound design and quality are improved slightly from the original game and many of the less generic maps lack that kitchen_rats look that's become so indicative of Half-Life's engine, so that's a plus. At the same time, a lot of maps have odd collision detection issues and I'm somewhat bothered by the fact that Counter-Terrorists are as chatty over the radio as their criminal counterparts.
If this game wasn't permanently attached to my account I would've sworn it was just a fever dream I had in 2006.

This is a review of Condition Zero - Deleted Scenes only. Original CS does not need a review - it is a legendary shooter, after all.

Imagine this - it's the beginning of the 2000s. War shooters are slowly becoming the new trend. And then Valve realises that and decides to cash in on their military franchise!
Condition Zero - Deleted Scenes was developed by Ritual Entertainment and released in 2004 to... OK reviews, to say the least. It is understandable - I mean, why would there be a single-player standalone game under the name of CS? The original game is not about the thrilling cinematics, great dialogue or the amazing plot - it's about improving yourself to be more skilled and simply having fun with friends or randoms through the internet.
Still, credit's where's credit's due, this game feels... OK to play today. I enjoyed spending my time with it, but part of the reason is because I actually wanted to beat this game during my childhood - I simply failed the stealth mission in Ventspils every single time. This time around, I didn't.
Besides having just the main missions, there are also "bonus" ones which you can access via the World Map section of the menu. There's nothing particularly special about them, just thought I'd note it.
Long story short, then - a simple game for its time which still feels good enough (at least for me) to play. There are worse ways to spend your money, trust me. I'd recommend buying this game on sale or with the Valve Complete Pack.

[b]WORTH THE PRICE [/b]

This is the perfect game if you like the Counter-Strike franchise and wanna enjoy it on your own. It's a very nostalgic experience. The missions are good, they're not too easy and not too hard. The different difficulties allow you to improve your mechanics gradually as you play and not just struggle from start to end. The graphics are good (within what you would expect) and I especially like that they made it different from Counter-Strike 1.6 with new animations and looks on maps. If you get tired of the missions or just finish them all you can always just set up your own game with bots and not only choose from the CZ maps but also the original 1.6 ones!
The AI is obviously not perfect but it's what you would expect from a game this old AND it actually scales pretty well between difficulties. In expert mode you'll be getting hit by some insane headshots and the bots will 360 noscope you from miles away but it won't always happen, and with training you'll improve your mechanics enough that you can be faster and have a higher headshot percentage.

[b]So overall: It's an amazing game, definetely worth buying. You'll have a good time playing it and the few bugs or downsides are completely understandable due to the age of the game. Smooth gameplay. [/b]

Condition zero franchise was shaded away because it was released the same year as source and half life 2 unfortunately. Living in the shadow of source it didn't got the attention it deserved and it got called out by community that it sucks. it becomes usual trend that people just say condition zero is lame without even trying it. This game has a Story campaign dedicated to it called "deleted scenes". The name is misleading thus many thought it's just normal condition zero but another version. The story campaign is just like a COD game but in Counter strike style, focusing on times where terrorism raged. It might sound bad but it can easily suck you in it with it's character development.  Gameplay is smooth although tbh it's an old game you may get frustrated in it but I never had problems running it on modern systems which is a really good aspect I might say. Each mission is located in different parts of the world where you are a different person assigned to certain mission to complete. It has smooth progress but in some parts although it is very very rare you might get confused. This game is worth every penny especially in sells. I am kind of disappointed that we didn't get another CS game like this. The deleted scenes alone is worth it. Now we get to the normal CS:CZ, it's improved CS 1.6 but didn't last long cause of source release. Valve killing their own game tbh. It's got fun CO-OP campaign missions where you assign a team from npcs which have their own cons and pros so you have to pay attention to that and go on vs terrorists and complete the challenges to progress, in each different map. This game has got so manyyyy maps! many you didn't get to experience in CSGO. It's worth playing in community servers for the sake of nostalegica, not other than that just like every game. Just imagine the whole thing as: Deleted scenes is the main game while normal CZ is a nice addition to it.

Condition Zero came out in March of 2004 after development since about 2000. Then Counter-Strike: Source came out in a handful of months. Also, Counter-Strike 1.6 had only just been released less than a year earlier and was still enjoying being one of the most popular online games ever, and would continue to be so for the rest of the decade.

So this game unfortunately was really overshadowed, despite being effectively 1.6 but with much-improved graphics and hit registration. The real gem here are the singleplayer modes. 

The first is "Deleted Scenes", a Half-Life-like singleplayer campaign in which you're a single counter-terrorist going on missions all over the world. It's a fantastic little campaign, a bit of Call of Duty 4 before its time, but unfortunately Deleted Scenes is just not worth playing unless you're on Hard or Nightmare (skill 0). On a higher difficulty the game actually begins to play like Counter-Strike: challenging, every resource counts, twitch aim mania. I have no idea if it was Valve who ruined the game's tuning and balance, but it's just ridiculously easy and boring on anything below Hard. 

The second is "Tour of Duty", and it's basically a large series of bot matches in which you go through each difficulty campaign at a time, building a team of counter-terrorists with unique attributes in order to fight terrorists on the classic CS maps, while meeting certain mission objectives ("Kill 4 enemies with the AUG"). This is actually pretty fun and amazing practice for actual online Counter-Strike.

Both campaigns are amazing and despite not being made by Valve (Ritual and Turtle Rock, respectively), are fantastic little experiences and great attempts at transforming Counter-Strike into a solo play experience. For this, the game is worth it even in 2020.

[h1] Counter-Strike: Condition Zero [/h1]

[b] A Very Sub-par, Single-player Focused Counter-Strike [/b]

[b] Counter Strike: Condition Zero [/b] sounded somewhat appealing to me on paper - a set of tactical missions with a customizable squad and loadouts filled with CS-style tactics. What I encountered instead was a very lackluster set of squad-based missions with irritating AI and a very pointless customization system.

This game has some nice ideas within it that should be a part of any modern day CS-style game. A squad-style mode with cooperative missions would be awesome to see in any title, especially one with the Counter-Strike gameplay loop. In this title, it is squandered on insanely irritable squadmates and very basic tutorial-esque mission setups. While there is some customization in terms of loadouts and squadmates to choose from, the standout guns remain obvious and overpowered while the AI proves itself redundant, serving little more as a meat-shield for the player to hide behind.

The map design is essentially just playing on every map from the base game. There aren't really any major changes as far as I could care to look for, and it felt lazy. Sure, they played alright, but why would I want to play on these maps with AI when i could play with real people? (Note: there were no multiplayer servers available to me that had less than 200 ping, and I live in NA region)

The audio is at least pretty good, and the arsenal is also pretty interesting to play around with. With more polish and work put into this title, it really could have been a stand-out, smash-hit for Ritual, Turtle Rock, and Valve, but alas it was squandered and remains as a very forgettable CS experience. In the end, I would [b] Not Recommend [/b] playing [b] Counter-Strike: Condition Zero [/b] unless you are a very big CS fan and are desperate for some old-school content.

[h2] Final Verdict: 3/10 (Poor) [/h2]

If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my curator page for my thoughts on a variety of other games!

The best (and only) single-player Counter-Strike game (I'm speaking for Deleted Scenes here).

A multitude of different missions, stealth, hostage rescue, bomb defusal, mini boss fights, storylines for each missions, the list goes on. Not only does it have a lot of replayability, it's also great for a quick time killer.

If you complete the missions and want more, people have made their own mission packs you can download and play. You can also make your own!

Remaking this in Source would give it more life and probably a larger player-base than ever and give the community better tools to use and create with. Recovered Operations aims to recreate this in Source, although it seems to have gone quiet for a year or two now, so not sure what's up with that.

Anyway, this is a fantastic game and definitely worth buying (worth even more if you get the whole Valve Collection for ¬£7).

This game is classic, and provided the foundation to many other FPS games today. What still makes it a great game is the fact that it is light, dynamic, and fast. It simply reacts well to user inputs. You don't need cutting edge hardware to play it. You can play on several built in maps, or you can play on custom community maps that are downloaded to your PC automatically once you connect to a server. You can send voice activated messages to your team. The game also allow you to create and publish your own maps, mods and tools. The bad side is that some servers (that are private, not owned by valve or steam), have cheaters and these servers rely on admins being online to ban those cheaters (VAC doesn't do a good job here). I have played it for 15 years, and I still enjoy playing it.
