This game is a bit weird. I've never been a fan of Counter Strike, but I do enjoy playing against bots. The progression of objectives with increasingly difficult enemies and smarter team mates is interesting as a game play loop. Perhaps this game is best for those new to Counter Strike as a whole and want to understand the game mechanics more before jumping into 1.6, Source, or Global Offensive.

It's the second Counter-Strike, it's lost quite a lot of popularity over the years, since now everyone plays CS:GO and forget about the old ones. This one is a little bit different, it's a singleplayer Counter-Strike with the attachment of multiplayer, this is what makes me enjoy the game.

It's got a team selection system as well, you have points, you start with few and work your way up, your team members have different levels of skill. Most of them have different levels of Bravery, Co-op and Skill. Your team members will start with a low level of skill, and as you get further into the game, their skill levels will grow higher.

I'd give the game a 8.14/10, because it's singleplayer, and it's old.
yes

The case with [i]Counter-Strike: Condition Zero[/i] and the deleted scenes portion of it is that it offers semi-valuable content, but it is baffling as to why [i]Valve[/i] thought it warranted a separate release.

I am very conflicted on this release, as I find value in the single-player missions present in the base game and even some bit of enjoyment in the campaign added in [i]Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes[/i], but as many have complained about during the launch of this version of the original, there isn't enough content here to warrant a separate price tag, and arguably a lot of what they added here should have been present in the original [i]Counter-Strike[/i] release, or added as a free update. Instead, [i]Valve[/i] released this three-and-a-half years after the original's debut, and failed to add enough substance to make up for this confusing and seemingly money-grabbing release. There isn't much here the original doesn't have, and what it does have either isn't worth the money or should have been in the previous installment initially. Valve seemingly backed off on this release after they realized the negative feedback and ratings far below their expectation, but in abandoning this project, much of what could have been improved was instead left in mediocrity, and so this game never got the redemption it could of had.

Although it doesn't have a coherent campaign in the base game, the eighteen provided missions separate from one another are actually not too bad of quality, I found myself enjoying them personally, and they also helped me hone my skills initially before going online and facing other players in the other games. This and this alone is a great part of the release here, but again this is really all there is good that [i]Counter-Strike[/i] doesn't have. The campaign in [i]Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes[/i] is not very good, or should I say it lacks a certain quality and motivation to keep the player interested, which makes the value of this drop even further down. This single-player campaign is not what [i]Counter-Strike[/i] is known for, and it shows us just how bad taking the focus away from multiplayer really can be. Since this game often comes bundled with the original, if you do decide to purchase it, you may as well take advantage of practicing on a few single-player missions, but besides that, this release will likely end up useless to most, and therefore is not worth the money.

[i]Counter-Strike: Condition Zero[/i] is a very confusing mess of a release that not only adds little to nothing new to the player, but came out years later and still had almost nothing to show for the time spent in development. Unless you are an avid fan or think you will find some value in playing through this, it would be best to skip out on this installment.

This is my third FPS game after IGI and CS 1.6 , that I played when I was 7 or 8 years old.  This game came just after CS 1.6, but still people forget about CS CZ most of the times and say that after CS 1.6 , CS S was the game that came out. 

Actually this game is the modified version of CS 1.6 with improved graphics and weapon models , with newer maps , and a new mode which is campaign missions( a mode where u have to complete certain objectives in a CS CZ map with a team of bots which are to be chosen by the player).

I bought this game in 2019 to refresh my memories, and yes this game is worth the purchase, the original AWP sound, the MP5 unsilenced, M4a1s with 667 ROF everything is here. When I get bored with CS GO , I play this game with bots and enjoy my life, rarely I play in community servers because there are very few servers near India so I cant get a decent ping for playing on those servers, and some servers dont allow players with high ping to join, so they kick me . Although I played very little on community servers, I can give a 100% guarantee that this game community is non toxic, and there are no scene of hackers, and people in the servers enjoy the game and have fun.

Although I am no longer a pro CS 1.6 and CS CZ, player I would definitely say to the CS fans and to those who are hesitating to buy this game, just buy this game during any of the steam sales, this game is worth the purchase.

This is the next version after Counter-Strike 1.6. The gameplay part is completely same. We have addition of bots, single player mode, some new/revamped maps, and better player model.

The single player campaign (Condition Zero Deleted Scenes) gets bad rap and I can't wrap my head around why - you get a world tour of counter-terrorist missions, played in anthology fashion with each level having a self-contained little story and premise (as a bonus, you get to see all your favourite B-action movie cliches of previous century)

It also has classic level design behind it by legends who've worked on stuff like Duke Nukem, and each level is having its own unique and strong thematic feel (albeit very stereotypical, when it comes to characters' regional accents and tongue in cheek writing). Good sound design and texture work that holds up surprisingly well - just make sure to type "gl_round_down 0" console command in-game or add it to autoexec.cfg file.

You get to snipe a stealth bomber with AWP rifle - what else do you want out of life?

Underrated Gem. 
This game was quickly forgotten due to the release of Counter-Strike: Source half a year later. It has been seen by many as a ripoff, due to the lack of brand new content. I will contend this by saying this is the best way to play Counter-Strike on the Goldsrc engine. It features everything that made 1.6 great, with more content. First, you can get the single player, which while not very long or in-depth, might be fun to go through. You also get bots included with the game, no mods needed. This is nice, because both this and 1.6 are lacking in players, and most of the servers have undesirable addons and plugins.

Maps are all intact from 1.6, and they also include versions of some of the classic maps that have updated graphics and art,  taken from the XBox version of Counter-Strike. New models are also included. Old custom maps designed for CS 1-1.6 will work great in CZero. Bot support can even be added in. Overall it's got enough new stuff that I would recommend it to anybody looking to experience classic Counter-Strike, because it has some advantages over 1.6 while still having everything from it available.

I doubt this will be too much of a
generalization if I say that almost every gamer in the world has played or seen
Counter-Strike. You take on the role of 1 of 4 characters from either the
counterterrorist or terrorist team. In each round, you and your team members
must seek and take out your enemies with the use of gun power and tactical
maneuvering. The first team that is totally wiped out loses, and the round
starts over. Your performance in the prior round, such as number of kills, will
determine how much cash you have to spend on new guns and equipment. Besides
eliminating the other team, terrorists can plant bombs in key locations for
detonation and counter terrorists can defuse the bombs or rescue hostages.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is quite hated by the Counter Strike community, and I can understand why. The game was released just a small time before Half Life 2 and proved to be way behind its time. However, comparing it to the original 1.6 one, this game is a nice improvement. Much better graphics and sounds, bugs fixed, better maps and a decent buy menu, I would definetly play this over 1.6. However, even if you have no internet, you can always play the campaign, which has challenging and fun missions, with interesting bots AI and a lot of different great maps, competitive-quality. Even though the game is pratically dead, there are still some nice servers running on it, so you should definetly check it out.

Counter-Strike:Condition Zero is an interesting one. At a glance, Condition Zero (CZ) looks similar to CS 1.6 but with better looking weapon and player models. However, the game actually has a few differences in terms of content.

There's the classic multiplayer mode that has official bot support for the maps that come with the game. This part of the game should be familiar to those who play CS 1.6. You can install new maps and the game will attempt to generate the navigation mesh for the bots. If the bots aren't playing well on custom maps, you can finetune it manually too.

There's also a Tour of Duty campaign mode where you are given "scenarios" that are using the multiplayer maps with specific victory conditions. Clearing scenarios gives you points, which you can use to recruit teammates who join your team as friendly bots. This mode is actually moddable as well, so you can create your own campaigns.

The bots can differ in their difficulty as well, which is kind of nice. Being older now (Man, has it been that long since CZ came out?), I always appreciate it when games have bot support. Sure, it can't replicate the experience of pitting your skills against real players but bots are great for warming up or for days where you just want to chill or mess around to relax.

Outside of multiplayer, there is a decent singleplayer campaign, called Deleted Scenes, that revolves around individual counter-terrorist scenarios, allowing you to play as the different CT units that are portrayed in multiplayer such as the SEALs, GSG9 and SAS. It's actually pretty fun, all things considered and it answers the question: "What if Counter-Strike had a singleplayer campaign?".

Despite being on the GoldSrc engine, there's just something about the pre-Source Counter-Strikes that I really like. Maybe its the nostalgia glasses here but I prefer the responsiveness of the GoldSrc engine to the floatiness that Source seems to have at times. And maybe its because I grew up during the GoldSrc era and I've gotten so used to the look of the game and the other GoldSrc games.

If there's another reason why I've stuck with CZ and CS 1.6, it might be because that unlike Global Offensive, one does not need to pay money for skins just to customise their game. One can go to dedicated modding sites to find weapon skins, player models and maps to enhance their Counter-Strike experience. However, do take note that because CS 1.6 is its predecessor, CZ has lesser mods available for it.

Overall, if you already have CS 1.6, CZ's multiplayer mode doesn't really add much but if you are interested in the singleplayer campaign, you could get CZ just for that.

Playing this just reminds you of how bad single-player shooters could get back in the day. What may have been ambitious at one point is now dated, old, and what was dated at it's release is now completely archaic. Some things are obviously bad because it's an old game, like the enemy AI, but there are also avoidable annoyances like the spawns of most enemies and the ammo given in levels. Not to mention level layouts which are kind of a mess. As it is, it's an FPS time capsule that I don't think most people would want to open up.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is practically Just Counter-Strike 1.7, if you know what I mean. There's literally no reason to say this is the worst Counter-Strike game in existence because it's just the original retail 1.6 but with some improvements. Also keep in mind that Counter-Strike for the XBox existed and it was a nightmare to play.

Condition Zero added HD reskins for all models, detailed textures, new high quality maps including original maps from 1.6, a bunch of little bug fixes and most importantly, improved bots that come with the game so that means you don't need third-party mods to install for bots. Would I say the bots are amazing? It's better than most bots I've seen on multiplayer games and it's pretty competent when properly noded and programmed for a map. It's fair enough but could be better especially when the game has a campaign based around fighting with offline bots.

This tour of duty campaign is boring, to say the least. It's a chore and there are loads of to-do-lists to complete. Some of the objectives you have to do are really specific and hard to encounter, making the rounds go over and over and over. Play it if you're so lame and have no life, but I'd rather do something more useful with my time. Let's be real, it's not like you were going to write the album of the generation by the time you could finish the tour-of-duty campaign. However there is one thing I did notice with the campaign that caught my attention. It seems to be that all the bots have different personalities and behaviors in game but it isn't explicitly described in the menu for some reason. Some bots choose to flank, some bots choose to run head first at the enemy after seeing a fallen comrade and some just camp and run away when seeing too many enemies. That was a really cool feature but it ultimately just gets obscured by the fact the the campaign is a load of baloney.

As for the multiplayer... it's just Counter-Strike. They literally did not alter the game mechanics in any way like they promised to do in the early previews for Condition Zero. No Molotov Cocktail, no CS Grenade, no Gas Mask and no LAW Rocket Launcher and so on. A lot of exclusive maps were cut from Condition Zero for no good reason but managed to leak into the internet and they're posted on Gamebanana and other mod sharing websites. Some of these things sound familiar to some and that is because they were reused in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive and Deleted Scenes.

As for Deleted Scenes, that game is a colossal failure. No wonder why it's called 'Deleted Scenes'. Valve didn't properly give the developers enough time to create what was going to be something new and interesting for Counter-Strike multiplayer but all of it just got thrown away. There was a campaign to go along with the fresh new Counter-Strike game which is now called 'Deleted Scenes'. It's really boring. It's bad because of so many reasons. The weapons don't feel satisfying or good to shoot anymore and the combat is extremely boring and whenever you're doing anything that isn't combat, it's worse. The story for all the missions are bland and boring, the voice acting and presentation is dull, playtime is short and the graphics considering it's release time is really outdated and unacceptable considering it came out the same year Counter-Strike: Source did. So yeah, Deleted Scenes kinda' blows. The only thing I found to be kind of great about Deleted Scenes is that it has a variety of locations unlike a lot of other shooters at the time.

I feel like if Valve and their developers got their sh*t together they could have made a good game. I believe based on what leaked materials came from the development of Condition Zero we could have had something like Global Offensive back then but Valve had failed to promise.

CS Condition Zero could be considered the retarded middle child of the Counter-strike series; loved by gearbox and finished by turtle rock studios while they were finishing CSS. Ignored by Valve. In its current (and final) state, the game boils down to CS 1.6 with bots and some might say [i]improved [/i] graphics, but I'd say they're different, even though they might be higher resolution.
The other part, the deleted scenes are an interesting experiment, being a single player campaign for Counter-Strike. They're alright, but not groundbreaking. 
All in all, 6/10

As someone who generally doesn't really like Counter Strike, i had some fun with Condition Zero's single player. You recruit your team based on the points you earn and then basically play a Counter Strike bot match with some additional challenges you have to complete. The AI isn't the smartest and your ability to issue commands to your team is fairly limited but overall it's still a enjoyable experience. I have not tried the multiplayer, but it seems to be Counter Strike with some additional weapons and gadgets.



The real "fun" however hides itself in the Deleted Scenes. There you get a weird mix of short, kinda over the top story missions played on some of the most confusing maps i have ever seen. It is pretty much a given that you will find a spot per mission where you will just wander around trying to find a way to progress. Some random computer you have to activate to open a door, going along a small path by jumping over a balcony, having to go back to where you came from without a clear indication to do so, jumping on a barrel to get over a fence that doesn't look like your supposed to get over and so on. Your ammo is very limited, resulting in a few situations where your just running at the enemies with a knife in your hand, hoping to survive. The enemy AI is pretty much nonexistent , they either stand around not reacting to gunfire right next to them or just run straight at you. To top all of that off there is also pretty much no delay for them to start firing at you, causing such fun situations where you go around a corner just to be immediately shot by a sniper or rpg. Going through a mission without running low on ammo and health seems almost impossible.

But somehow the absurdity of playing a Valve published Counter Strike single player with such bad game design makes this whole experience kinda enjoyable, at least when you bought that game cheap on sale.

Back when Counter-Strike tried a campaign mode.

The game is a series of mini-objectives against bots on various maps, while the Deleted Scenes extra is a full blown CS campaign with many elements of the online game being brought in with solo FPS gameplay mechanics (such as equipment) to make a fun and hilarious game (the stereotypical russian accents make me laugh every time).

The multiplayer part is quite similar to the original CS but with slightly better textures.

Overall, this isn't a game for people who like CS:GO, it's more for the fans of old school FPS games and OG Counter-Strikers. I do recommend it nonetheless, but keep in mind that the game is over 10 years old.
Still one of my favorite games. I just love to come back to it just to play the campaign. 6/10 but back in the days it would have gotten a higher score!

An absolute classic. Sunk many hours of my life into this, be it on LAN with friends, on the missions, or online (still some active servers in 2019, 15 years after launch). I personally find some of the graphically updated maps clearer and overall more beautiful than in the original 1.6.

V E R Y affordable during sales, it's a (by today's standards) simple game that you won't regret buying. As it is older (some may say ancient), it runs even on the worst of OS potatoes, so that may interest some buyers.

Counter-Strike - originally a mod to Half-Life, created by the well-known Minh Le (then a CompSci student spending more time on the mod than on his own studies) is best 
understood as a formula for a game rather than as a game in itself. It's a formula so ingrained in FPS games for many years afterwards - competitive, repetitive, harsh, unforgiving, simplistic, multiplayer/team-oriented, wrapped in a modern military flavour at that time only prior seen in a few games such as Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six (1998) and Le's own "Navy SEALs" Quake mod. Later, gamers would see how Counter-Strike's game modes and style would be copied by common games such as Sudden Attack (2005) and CrossFire (2007). In many cases, these games would even copy Counter-Strike's map layout, e.g. Sudden Attack's "Desert 2" is clearly a remake of Counter-Strike's de_dust2. Often these games are referred to as "clones" or "ripoffs" of Counter-Strike, even though they are quite distinct in their own way - especially in being geared towards a "pay to win" model, and blurring the lines between in-game currency and real money. Counter-Strike became a Valve product once Le and co-creator Jess Cliffe were hired by Valve, and since then, subsequent titles have been conservative (changing little of the gameplay, with most of the changes being graphical improvements) innovations on their original work, though CS:GO effectively "monetizes" the Counter-Strike formula as the various Asian (especially South Korean) "clones" and "ripoffs" have in the past. 

The premise of these games is rather simple - players are random combatants on a team in a series of brief military engagements (a match) repeating themselves in the same map. Each match is comprised of multiple rounds, and the team winning the majority of these rounds wins the match. After each round the map is effectively reset. In Counter-Strike, each match begins with players joining the T (red/terrorist) or CT (blue/counter-terrorist team). One team has a goal, the other team's goal is to effectively prevent them from achieving that goal. For example, in maps marked "de" (Bomb Defusal), such as "de_dust" or "de_dust2", a random T will spawn with a "C4" object which must be planted (by any T) at one of two bombsites. CT's must prevent the bomb from being planted (by killing the carrier before they are able to plant it, or defusing the C4 within 45 seconds of its successful planting). In Counter-Strike, all players start each round from a practically clean slate except money or weapons carried over from a previous round - there is no long-term progression or persistent items. Instead, items are bought with $ accrued from winning/losing rounds, killing enemies and other in-game actions. Some of these items differ by team - e.g. the illustrious AK-47 (weapons are known by different names in-game) - is exclusive to the Terrorists. Generally a unique item on one team will be countered by another on the opposing team, e.g. the M4A1 is exclusive to the CTs. 

Counter-Strike is largely about the speed and precisity of one's aim - weapon accuracy is heavily reduced by movement and automatic fire, and body shots are significantly weaker than headshots. This means that the game boils down to shooting heads as fast as possible. More proficient players will increase the chance of their team winning the round, and they will have higher incomes to attain better weapons and gear. This means that matches are hard to turn around once a team has an upper hand - since a losing team will largely be confined to weapons that are arguably underbalanced, as evidenced by the fact that only a subset of the game's content is frequently used, and players begin quitting due to the notable lack of respawns till a round's end. Most players will stick to a handful of weapons and new players will find themselves encountering players who use part of this subset almost all the time - the AK-47, M4A1, P90, AWP and Deagle in particular. Some weapons like the Grenade and MAC-10 are so useless that sticking with default pistols likely gives players are a better chance, especially as refraining from buying weapons whilst being on the winning team is likely the fastest way to accrue $. 

As the second iteration of Counter-Strike, CS:CZ uses the same, aged GoldSrc engine. There are minor map changes unique to CZ, but the game otherwise retains the same graphical ugliness largely missing from its sequels. CS:CZ includes the little known "Deleted Scenes", several single-player missions with no connection to eachother. The game can't run higher than 100FPS without issues. Sounds are largely Jess Cliffe's intentionally muffled voice along with low-quality gun sound recordings. UI is minimalistic and utilitarian. I have found no obvious stability issues. There are no "safe spaces" to allow new or deficient players to self-segregate, no tutorials. However, CS:CZ (unlike CS, but like CS:S and CS:GO) include AI opponents ("bots") which allow players to simulate most of the aspects of online-gameplay without the hassles of embarrassment, lag, long waiting times upon death (use bot_kill once you are dead), etc. Bot matches allow players to gain familiarity with the weapons, game modes and maps. Game content is all upfront - no DLCs, nothing locked by paywalls or time. I have not played enough in recent times to comment on the level of hacking/glitching or whether CS:CZ has an active player base. 

In general, CS games are likely best enjoyed with friends playing cooperatively. There are reasons that I might recommend CS:CZ when it's highly discounted - if you're a fan of the CS formula and curious about the series' origin, you don't mind underwhelming single-player content and "Deleted Scenes" appeals to you, or if your hardware is too deficient to play modern games properly. CS 1.6 was after all very popular in countries with low rates of computer ownership, where "net cafes" tend to be bustling. However, most players will be much happier with the better-looking, more refined Source Engine found in CS:S, or if a large player base and an in-game market are more appealing, then you should simply go to, or stick with, CS:GO. In the vast majority of cases, I recommend any curious reader of this review familiar with the later CS iterations to remain with them, and to instead sate their own curiosity with a YouTube video rather than a purchase they will likely regret. Here are a few of my own (note that the Elite bot difficulty is very punishing in CS:CZ), though there are plenty of gameplay videos that will suffice:

Have you ever wondered what does "condition zero" mean?

It refers to a condition of a firearm (primarily a handgun) and, in particular: full magazine inside the firearm, round in the chamber, hammer c0ck3d (if the gun has a hammer), safety disengaged (if the gun has an external safety).

What Is Counter Strike: Condition Zero ?

Useless, an utterly useless game, people who want the classic CS experience will go to the original 1.6 version, the ones who want a more modern and polished version will go either to Source or Global Offensive, this game, Condition Zero, is the "middle ground" that had no reason to exist, its primary idea was to be an improvement over 1.6 and look where it all went to, Source back then took its place just a few months after its release and left it with nothing, because CZ is what it is, a lazy game, the whole multiplayer experience is the same with slightly improved graphics, other than that the game gives you something new: singleplayer content, one is a series of matches with bots with objectives to complete which just sucks and the other is a campaign which probably inspired CoD and other games we have today in terms of campaign, you do a bunch of missions on different places around the world, playing a different nameless character, with something set up in the background like why the mission is happening, each mission goes into completely different concepts, some are stealth influenced, other are full assault, the thing is while some set pieces are good looking for the game, it just feels rushed and broken, there are so many bugs, AI pathfinding issues, the handling of the weapons here are horrid, the enemies you fight are horribly designed, there are issues with a mission fully glitching itself making you unable to proceed and start all over again, it just feels like a rushed experiment that failed at every possible level, a really bad thing, thing is, Source, came just a while after CZ and people play CS for the competitive experience, so all this singleplayer stuff is low-quality waste of time, Source did the competitive better, it picked the foundation of 1.6 and built a more modern and new take on it, CZ just copy paste it and did some minor improvements, today, it has the lowest playerbase of the 4 games and to be sure, theres no reason to waste your time with it, just skip this one its pretty crappy.

This game is one of the biggest suprises of my Life.

I owned this game for years and I'm sure thousands of people just ignored it like I did.
I completely played through the original yesterday, so I was still in the mood for some new maps, so I decided to play this game expecting the same simple Gameplay of the first one.

But this game blew everything out of the Water.

The Maps were really interesting and it looked really good in 4K 120 FPS. (On a 1080p monitor).

The Game has a lot of charm, especially the Voice Acting. So many different accents, from German to Japanese, I love this stuff. If you know some of these other languages, you'll have a fantastic time.

If you're looking for a challenging game with a variety of map locartions, this is for you.

(THIS REVIEW COVERS MY THOUGHTS ON DELETED SCENES ONLY)

Fun game in general. Should be treated as a basic tutorial for 1.6, but it's got some issues

>Some levels require you to use specific grenades and specific spots. Since the game refuses to give you any more than what you spawn with on Difficult (This is the only difficulty I've played on), and since some missions such as 5 have the player placed in a position where you feel inclined to use them, if you do, you gotta start the entire mission all over again.

If you have shitty aim, the mandatory SSG08 sections will absolutely get you to hate this game. Since I have decent aim these aren't a problem for me, but I can see how these will make some people angry.


There are occasional spots where you can get killed because you got stuck in the map.

The Arctic Avengers had a lot of missed potential to develop a story to this game. I think the reason why this game wasn't successful was because it had no story. The first opening missions could have been an introduction, and then the Arctic Avengers stronghold and more missions themed around their plot could have served very well.

Other than these, the game feels and works pretty solidly. Its just playing with bots on Half Life maps. I wouldn't recommend it though, just buy Source, GO, or 1.6. and have fun on those. All have great communities and workshop community gamemode support (except 1.6, maps and stuff for that game are a little less straight forward due to the age of 1.6)

After playing this game for a few hours there is two different components to this game. Tour of Duty (TOD) and Deleted Scenes (DS). I got this game in the Valve bundle pack and decided to give them a shot because they were just sitting in my library. 

[b]Tour of Duty:[/b]
This game is absolutely horrible! I'm not a great CS player by any means but I'm no stranger to the FPS genre so I decided to play it on hard. It's rather frustrating from the beginning as you're allotted points to assemble your unit with attributes such as skill, co-op and bravery which rank by a strength ratings bad, low, ok, good and high. As expected playing against bots your team is pretty much garbage while the A.I tracks you and kills you like a rabid dog while going against another A.I it's like watching Stevie Ray and Ray Charles having a gun fight. It seems that if you use commands the A.I responds to them. However, being that most of us use mics online I never bothered to learn CS commands. 

Missions requiring you to save hostages can be frustrating as your team A.I will seem to deliberately get good at finishing the round before you can save them. If you rescue them one or two at a time it appears to go over better than collecting all 4 in one go. On that note, the  requirements to pass a level are rather tedious. kill x amount of enemies, kill x enemies with [weapon] Finish round in x amount of time. I guess for the time this game was released it would have served as training but being that most people probably play GO the TOD didn't hold up to the test of time.

Apparently, there are some fun Zombie mods in this game and might be a selling point to you but that aside this game isn't worth getting.

[b]Deleted Scenes:[/b]

I actually had quite a bit of fun playing the DS. It's a linear CS story game where the story didn't make a any sense really just that you go and do a bunch of salvage, rescue missions. On the highest difficulty it's still pretty easy (funny how I complained about bs aim bots for TOR) The best way to describe it, is that it's a CS half-life game. With Puzzles, linear paths, and stuff you expect from half-life games. Is it worth buying? I wouldn't waste money on it alone but if you're going to buy the valve bundle pack it's a fun linear fps game.

Counter strike condition zero is a multiplayer optional tatical fps, so everyone knows the first real esport title, at least the first so well know by everyone, I know quake 1 and rts games was also esport games well know, but counter strike did more, moba somehow got some of the mmo fans, but the game still around, and I still like it a lot, most of it because its playable in single player, I hate the multiplayer part of this game entirely, there is a lot of coop gameplay to it, but I'm not talking about the sequel here, "counter strike go" have deathmach mode, and its all that matters to me in a mmo fps, this one in other hand only have the "bomb mode" where both teams have a goal, mixed with "last man standing" mode, I don't like that because you get stuck without gameplay for 10 minutes or more, but since this game have a single player mode, you can restart the match any time without many problems, loading times don't take much long, and in my opinion the graphics still holds up very well, biggest problem with this game is the sniper reloading animation using the quick scope technique, that being manually making the reload pressing twice the "Q" button, it doesn't looks good like in "counter strike go" it looks much much better in "counter strike go", definitively my second favorite counter strike game, and it could be my favorite counter strike if it had "free for all" or "deathmach" modes in it, but it doesn't, so second favorite counter strike game.

Basically Counter Strike 1.6 but with improved graphics and the addition of bots. The bots are amazing considering when this game was released (they're still inferior to human players). In addition, the bots are a great way for beginners to learn about the game in a more relaxed environment. There is also a singleplayer Tour of Duty, which is basically regular counter strike missions against bots, but with additional challenges (example: kill 3 enemies with a sniper rifle). Sadly, the Tour of Duty missions are Counter-Terrorist only. There are no Terrorist missions.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a fantastic game. It gets rid of all this modern junk and just gives you a gun and grenades. You have to win using purely your skills. The guns in this game feel great. The maps are good and you can get a ton of workshop maps. The game is far from dead with full servers and a decent playerbase. If you are looking for a great classic FPS shooter then Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is for you.

Random head shot simulator, now with a repetitive campaign mode containing a marathon of choke point maps. 

Even though this is the best game for new people who would want to learn the quirks of Dumpster-Strike, I would recommend that you should stick to the Easy or Normal difficulty missions of the campaign mode, if any higher then the game would just cleave your balls off and shoot you twice in the back of the head, the difficulty spike in this game is honestly staggering. 

Can't say anything about the online servers, since I already experienced the horrors of Dumpster-Strike: Source firsthand, so I guess it wouldn't be any different.

If you're still interested in playing Dumpster-Strike, there are honestly way better first person shooters out there. Highly skill-based or not, a game should be fun to learn and yet in the Counter-Strike series, it doesn't let you do that; it's not fun to learn at all. There's a difference between being challengingly fun to being plainly unfair. 4/10

This version of counter strike is really the bastard child of the counter strike franchise. it came out at a time when source was out (or around the corner depending on where you were) and while cs 1.6 still had a thriving player base. if you are buying it today and are expecting an active player base i'm sorry to disapoint but you wont really find it if you live in North America. If you want to play an older Counter Strike game with an active player base than try CS 1.6 (known as just "Counter Strike" on the steam store) or try Counter Strike Source as both still have a thriving player base and many active servers from the Americas as well as Europe and Asia. In terms of the game on its own it is essentially an updated version of the origional counter strike with some better visuals as well as a single player campaign (something that wasn't seen before or since this game)
Nobody plays anymore, but still good to chill on

[h1]Singleplayer CS[/h1]
So this is basically the original Counter-Strike but you: 
- Select your team members (bots) of differing skill and cost
- Play through different maps completing challenges during the rounds
- When you complete all the objectives you move onto the next map so they are as short as only a few rounds per map

Interesting twist on the counter-strike formula and not very long, only a couple of hours to complete. 
Nice relaxing break for any counter-strike player who just wants to play the game without having to rely on braindead teammates.

Multiplayer for this is dead so play regular CS if you want a Multiplayer experience. 

[h1]8.5/10[/h1] 
[i]- quick and fun solo cs[/i]

I love playing single player creations in the goldsource engine, since I grew up on Half-life, but condition zero deleted scenes was pretty awful. I can't believe people actually got paid money to create such a shoddy product. Sure the maps were very well done and the art direction was pretty reasonable considering the tools they had to work with...but the rest was way too cringe-inducing to make up for it. The voice actors, for example, have the most cheesy accents for whatever region of the globe the mission is in. the IRA is my personal worst favorite, followed by the Ruskis in a close second. The training mission was more basic than the one in Half-Life. The gameplay was very predictable, with all the enemies showing up exactly where you expect them to. I'm almost glad Valve put a stop to the project and gave it to another studio, to finish up a proper update to the original CS. If CS:Source hadn't come out shortly after this, Valve would've been a laughing stock.

That said, I very much enjoyed the maps and the art, and the comedy provided by the crap voice acting was enough to make me lol. Would recommend to anyone who likes playing in goldsource.

Ships with a broken OpenGL renderer that doesn't support detail textures. Valve removed the old D3D renderer a couple of years ago, breaking the game. You're better off torrenting this game (as you're likely to get a fully functional release) rather than buying it, as Valve decided to push a broken update.

As for the game itself, it's pretty much the same as original CS, but with HD models and bots (the reason to get it if you don't like playing on servers with 200 extra sounds and models that change the game completely). There are new versions of some maps with added clutter that makes them worse, but original maps come with the game as well. Deleted scenes are there as well, but it's just a generic single player FPS with horrible AI and weapons and recoil from CS as its only saving grace.

Gameplay feels very rough and unpolished, so play this ONLY IF you are very CURIOUS, or doing a research.

Imo CSCZ's idea was amazing. The idea of a CS-style fast shooter with real-life police siege tactics was so good, but CSS overshadowed CSCZ, simply because CSS had a new engine and CSCZ was using the original Half-Life engine. If CSCZ was actually a Source game, it would be so popular, but it isn't. If someone makes a new Tour of Duty CS game, it would certainly become very popular. You have to keep in mind that if we had a CS game with both singleplayer and multiplayer, you didn't have to complain about the gamemodes, you had lots of options. If i wanted to play with bots in CSCZ, i usually made my own server, added bots and simply just made it more fun and i used non-Tour of Duty maps such as 747 or Vostok and it was so much fun. But what was the past is kind of forgotten. I like that people actually are nowadays interested about CSCZ and its deleted scenes, it shows that old forgotten games can be even more fun than the hyped games. 

not to forget that this game had one of the best CS soundtracks/theme, unlike CSS which didnt have absolutely nothing.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a bare bones, single player focused mod of the famous Counter-Strike mod for Half-Life. There are a total of 18 missions (not including ones made by users) that you can tackle along with 4 difficulty settings. Each mission is set on a different map and the variety of locales is definitely a plus. There are three objectives for each mission and in order to complete the mission you must accomplish the objectives AND beat the Terrorists by at least 2 rounds. However, the AI can be completely wonky at times which is more of a detriment to you than the opponent (especially on the later missions when the teams are unbalanced, e.g. 8 vs. 6). It can be pretty infuriating losing because the AI spent 30 seconds crouched in a corner then walks right by a person from the enemy team without even noticing them. Due to this, trying to complete the later difficulties is an extreme undertaking and requires a great deal of skill to carry your team to victory while still accomplishing all the objectives. Especially since the objectives change with each difficulty setting and some of the later ones are ridiculous (e.g. "get a kill with a knife and survive the round", or "kill an enemy blinded from a flashbang and survive the round"). Overall, it's a fun unique experience for fans of the original Counter-Strike that are looking for a more single player oriented game, but that does not make up for the lack of content and poor AI. 

6.5/10

Now as for the Deleted Scenes portion....that part is fantastic. You play through 12+ missions each with specific objectives and settings that are surprisingly detailed (for the time this game was released). The set-pieces and little reactions some of the enemies have as they die, such as plummeting out of a window to fall on and be impaled by a spire, are really a great touch. This is where the love and care went when this game was made. Fans of Counter Strike should definitely check it out.

8/10

This is a review for CS:CZ: Deleted Scenes. This game is 14 years old and is better than most modern military shooters, you actually have to give some thought and solve problems to progress in the level sometimes. Steel crates can be moved by holding the E key. I got this with the Valve Complete Pack. Well worth a play.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a great game, it's a great multiplayer FPS and everyone knows it, so I'll just talk about the 'singleplayer campaign'.

It's just bots, you and bots vs some bots. It's very simple. But, I enjoyed it a lot since building your team up from just you and a few chumps is fun, I like the basic little stats system, and I think it's a shame that the game gives you so much money to play with that you never need to do eco rounds or anything, and it seems that there's no 'campaign' for terrorists, just CTs, but... ultimately, it's fun.

As long as you're interested in just playing some bots for a while, it's fun, maybe a good warmup. Very simple. I beat all of the 'tours of duty' and none of them were very hard, I think the AI tries to make up with its lack of skill with quantity, so you can very easily counter them by picking the highest skill level guys. If you're lucky, they can even solo rounds for you, as long as you do teh challenges.

Below is my review for Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes

Pretty fun singleplayer campaign, but it gets pretty repetitive and it feels like instead of the developer plotting and planning out a long string of missions to put together, everyone in the team just made a bunch of assets and then everyone went off and did their own thing.

There's a few issues.

The difficulty across missions is just all over the place, there's no ramp, some missions are hard, some are super easy. It's rare, but sometimes you'll actually just have to keep reloading saves or even reload a save from earlier in the mission if you have a hard time with something you didn't expect.

One example is the missile launcher guys. One shot from those guys is enough to basically force you to reload your save, either because you just died instantly to them or because your hp and armor are so low you're about to die anyway. The only instance I found this wasn't the case, I think, is the very last mission where there's a few missile launcher guys, but all of them are firing at you generally in locations where they won't hit something behind you. The real problem is the GIGANTIC explosion. It's just a pain since often you'll be reloading more than a handful of times.

The missions are all designed pretty well, I think, but again since it was clearly just a bunch of guys building a random assortment of levels, there's actually a lot of overlap between missions. There's quite a few missions where you have to chase down a target and shoot him until he dies. In one case, you actually have to cheese him by like nudging left and right while in cover so he doesn't fire on you while you just repeatedly headshot him. There's only a couple of stealth missions and they don't even remain stealth for very long.

The tutorial outlines a very large variety of gadgets that they want you to get accustomed to, like things such as remote detonated explosives, the defusal kit, a radio, a fibre optic cable like in SWAT for peeking under doors, and maybe one or two other gadgets I can't remember. Most stuff isn't really used that much, and not super well, the explosives are generally only used to open up a doorway so you can continue progressing, which is a shame since they could have been used for different and more interesting things, perhaps.

The M60 is absolutely busted. It has almost perfect accuracy, way better than any of the regular Counter-Strike weapons, and it recovers fast and does huge damage. As befitting a big LMG, but when in the hands of the AI it's just absolutely ridiculous, if you let them fire on you for more than a few seconds at any range, you're probably dead. While not every mission even has this gun, a few missions have them just all of the place.

A few missions are very railroaded and walking off the beaten track is either punished or impossible, but in more than a few of them you're all but required to do it just to find more stuff to keep on going. Sometimes it's just more ammo, but in some cases it's as much as a weapon drop, and in Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes, each mission only has each weapon ONCE. If you miss a weapon, that's it, you're not going to find it along the way if you didn't manage to find where it was hidden. It's not really a big deal since you can complete every mission without them, but it does make it a bit trickier when you're being given ammo for weapons you don't have.

The way armor/HP work is very punishing. Armor is usually difficult to come by, and with it most enemies will do next to no damage to you, but as it decreases, damage to your HP will rise, until at 0 enemies can kill you from full HP in only a couple of bursts if they're lucky. Headshots on you seem to sway the screen in such a way as to throw your aim off, which is extremely frustrating if you're just trying to shoot a guy and your shots all miss just because he keeps tagging you in the head.

The repetitive nature of some of the missions really kind of makes the game a bit of a struggle, and by the end they REALLY got carried away with the parkour. Having to crouch jump up a whole pile of crates to get to a ledge so you can get to a door so you can continue with the level, that's fine, but it's just weird to me that this kind of thing seems to be in ALL of the missions, numerous times, so often it feels like you're spending most of your time, most of the game in fact just jumping around cramped environments.

I have a lot of complaints, but honestly despite them all it's a great, fun singleplayer campaign, if you ever were thinking 'Counter-Strike would make a great singleplayer game' well, here you go, this is probably the best you'll ever get.
Honestly, this game is really underrated. It's like a "Campaign Mode" for Counter-Strike. There's a lot of effor put into everything here.

But the main selling point is the single player campaign; deleted scenes, it takes place fighting terrorism across the globe in exotic locations. Simular to 1998 Half-Life, the campaign is still fun to play and it's story is alright.

Recommended to people who like classic games, people who play multiplayer, and people who like Half-Life style games.

[h1] 10,000+ hours and counting. [/h1] 

[b] Pros: [/b]
[list]
[*] Modest on system requirements. 
[*] Consistent game play. 
[*] There's not too much visual overload for those prone to distractions. 
[*] Rounds aren't overly long whether you like to hold back and guard your objective or you like to rush your objective and possibly only last a minute. 
[/list]

[u] Parental guidance for online play. [/u]

There's lots of potential to take a mental break and have a laugh with your friends.   
The CZ community has a wide gradient of skilled players.

[b] Tips: [/b]

Your team mates are going to block you and/or team flash you at times. 
[i] Work on not letting that happen. [/i]

At times it will feel like other team mates are the cause of your demise. 
[i] Authentically taking responsibility for your level of effectiveness appears to be key to continually enhansing your game.  It appears to help with players overall happiness as well.  Counter-Intuitive. [/i]

The tactical squad-based shooter franchise Counter-Strike has had a long and storied history from humble beginnings as a GoldSrc deathmatching mod, to years of loyal followers as a title officially picked-up and supported by Valve, to the massive gaming icon and economic powerhouse that the most recent instalment - Global Offensive, has become. While having been surpassed technologically by more recent instalments, in this lowly reviewer‚Äôs opinion, Condition Zero remains the best in the series.

Controls and gameplay ought to seem familiar to most-anyone who has played a Valve title or have looked at a first-person PC game in this last two decades; all very basic and easy to learn - WASD to move, mouse to look, and a handful of other simple buttons to do things like bring up the score table and such. These simple controls and gameplay mechanics belie the massive upper skill ceiling which has kept Condition Zero veterans enthralled with the game for more than a decade. 

Gameplay objectives remain much the same as they were in CS1.6, pitting two teams of fully armed terrorists and counter-terrorists against each other across a number of tense bomb-disposal and hostage rescue situations in a test of strategic communication, flick reflexes, and tactical fund management. Where Condition Zero unquestionably excels over its peers is in all aspects of the singleplayer experience. CZ brings in full native AI bot support, and these cutting-edge-fourteen-years-ago opponents remain respectfully challenging in both organisational intelligence and in moment-to-moment gunplay. Furthermore, Condition Zero provides a new ‚ÄòTour of Duty‚Äô campaign wherein the player advances through eighty-four scenarios designed to test their mettle across every map and type of weapon. 

Despite a not-uncomplicated development cycle and sales figures actually along Valve‚Äôs lowest at release, the recognisable excellence of Condition Zero has ensured a healthy fanbase and playercount more than a decade later, and given the inexpense of this game, either bundled alongside the original 1.6 release and an admittedly poorer expansion-sequel, or as part of the Valve Complete Pack, this is definitely something to look out for during any one of Steam‚Äôs frequent sales.

CS:CZ has a long story so sit down and get some cup of Tea/Beer and Relax. CS:CZ has been Black Sheep for Counter Strike Family for a long time. CS:CZ¬¥s development had alot of issues. Rogue Entertainment started the development in 2000 but because of it¬¥s CEO or like that the Company went Defunct, Meaning the Development Was passed back to Turtle Rock Studios. Valve didn¬¥t really care much about CS:CZ because they were focusing more on Source Engine. Turtle Rock Studios did a great job updating Goldsrc engine¬¥s graphics. What do i mean by updating? It means they updated lighting,shading,shadows and gave Textures new breath by adding New Texture Compression Techniques. Counter Strike Condition Zero is split into 2 different Games: Condition Zero And Condition Zero Deleted Scenes. Ritual Entertainment had Deleted Scenes for their work and Turtle rock studios had normal Condition Zero. After it finally got on Audience¬¥s plates in 2004 ,They still didn¬¥t like it very much because of it¬¥s old Graphics and it felt similiarly to 1.6 . Valve Fixed this by releasing Counter Strike Source in late 2004. On the Bright side i find the campaigns/tour of Duties Entertaining and i recommend this game alot.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero really isn't anything noteworthy. It is an upgrade of the original game, having minor improvements in sounds, vocal performances and other regards. The main factor which separates it from the other Counter-Strike entries is it's singleplayer campaign, which is comprised of multiple missions and challenges to complete. These missions only offer similar gameplay scenarios that can be found in multiplayer.
Many of the top reviews found here consist of people's fondness of the game due to nostalgia or the missions and challenges. I would recommend this game to those who may enjoy completing challenges and missions otherwise overall I would stick with 1.6 as there are more people currently playing it.
I would not recommend this game to you if it were required to be purchased seperately from 1.6 although since this game comes with the original for a total of $10 I would recommend that you purchase this bundle to experience both entries for yourself.

Valve: well ritual i made it despite your directions.
Ritual: ah company valve. welcome.
Ritual: i hope your prepared for an unforgettable game design
Valve: yeah.
*Ritual enters the game design studio and their deleted scenes is scrapped*
Ritual: OH EGADS! MY GAME IS RUINED
Ritual: but what if i were to share the development to another studio? delightfully devilish, ritual.
*Valve enters the room*
Valve: RITUUUAAAAAALLLLL
Ritual: valve! i was just uh totally stretching my team on the development. isometric studio exercise, care to join me?
Valve: why is the design still being worked by you?
Ritual: uhhh its turtle rock, game from turtle rock studios were having, mmm deleted scenes.
*Valve leaves the backroom* 
Ritual: phew
*fast forward 2004*
Ritual: valve i hope you're ready for deleted Scenes
Valve: i thought your not happy with that?
Ritual: d'oh no.
Ritual: i said Deleted Scenes
Ritual: thats what i call this.
Valve: you cal- you know what? okay.
Ritual: its a new dialect.
Valve: uh-huh, from what studio?
Ritual: uh, gearbox software.
Valve: really.
Valve: well we know gearbox, and i've never heard anyone use the phrase "Deleted Scenes"
Ritual: oh not in gearbox, no its a turtle rock expression.
Valve: I see.
Valve: you know, this "deleted scenes" are quite similiar to the ones they have at turtle rock studios.
Ritual: ohhh no, patented ritual style, old gearbox design.
Valve: for Deleted scenes?
Ritual: yes.
Valve: yes, and you call them Deleted scenes despite the fact that you arent happy with it.
Ritual: ye- you know one thing i should- excuse me for one second
Valve: ofcourse.
*Ritual goes to the backroom and comes back in a few seconds*
Ritual: ah well that was wonderful, good game was contributed by me, im finished.
Valve: ah i shou- GOOD LORD WHAT IS HAPPENING IN THERE? 
Ritual: six unreleased missions.
Valve: unreleased missions!? at this time of the release in this part of the game localized entirely within your studio?
Ritual: yes.
Valve: may i see it?
Ritual: no
J.C: RITUAL THE MISSIONS ARE REMOVED!
Ritual: no sir thats just unfinished.
Valve: Well ritual you are an odd fellow but i must say you steam a good game.

Nostalgia. The first game I ever purchased and as a reward for myself after the Chinese middle-school final test. As a kid who had not been exposed to much games, I still remember the feeling of "enlisting" myself in the military game genre, despite that CS had been around even by the time I purchased it. Oh also, I bought it in my country China, where everyone plays pirated version of games. So yeah, It's obvious how excited I was with the game. 
And I wasn't disappointted. Despite several levels that have stupid design and had me stuck not knowing where to go(even till now I get lost in the first level), I am generally intrigued by the game and I had a good time playing with an old friend of mine. Good time, good time.

Counter-Strike Condition Zero.... what can i say about this game?.... well it's.... Counter-Strike (Original) with some added seasoning. Would i reccomend it? Of course! But let's crack it down a bit more. 

GRAPHICS: Great.
The graphics on this game are reworked versions of the orginal CS versions. They look fantastic and it's hard to belive this wasn't a source game.

SOUNDTRACK: Un-rated.
For obvious reasons, the soundtrack is limited to the main menu and shit. Because during the match every footstep is valuable information and music can get in the way of hearing it. So i'm not giving it a rating for the soundtrack since this isn't a game that should require a soundtrack. 

GAMEPLAY: Great.
The gameplay is about the same as the original CS. Which means it's great! 

CAMPAIGN: Eh..... it's ok...ish
Now here comes the kick in the nuts.... The Campaign of the game is just the same thing as regular matches with the added seasoning of Challenges like: 
"Kill 5 enemies"
"Kill an enemy with a sub machinegun" and stuff like that. 
It's nothing special. They could have gone for so much more, yet they decided on so little. 

STORY: Un-rated.
The game is story-less which means i can't rate it. Well "story-less" the story you all know, a team of counter-terrorists is sent to "negotiate" with the terrorists in an area. Same old shit, but it works. 

CONCLUSION: 10/13
The game is a great game and a worthy addition to your steam library..... unless you already have the original game, in which case, you are just buying the same game twice. If you don't have the original, get this one. If you have the original, Don't get this one, you're just wasting your money. Maybe not like that.
 
NOTE: Multiplayer was not taken into account when writing this review.

Original.

The good: 
-Bots are amazing and are better then those in most modern shooters
-The maps are very well designed,I never felt like I was playing the the same mode twice
-Intresting team building idea, alllows a user to have a team set-up to fit there preferences and getting one more point after completing a mission feels progressive and rewarding.
-Easy to access settings for local multiplayer with bots, for example if you want to have a massive machine gun battle or have a Sniper battle you can easily do so
-In the multiplayer there's is a vast selection of maps
-Runs well on terrible computers
The bad:
-Bots won't defuse if your alive and all the enemies are dead, this is my biggest criticism of the game as even if there are 7 bots on the bombsite yet your all the way across the map, they still won't defuse
-Bot performance is very inconsistent, for example bot Tex was extremely good on one mission, so I kept him in my load out for the next mission where he only got four kills
-There is a lack of diversity in the challenges you are required to do, they always involve either getting kills with a certain weapon, hostage rescues and total kills.
-The game seems to lack a proper skill curve, as certain earlier missions end up being harder then ones you receive later on.
-The last three sets of missions are overwhelming difficult because for some reason friendly bots performe very poorly so if you do not get 1. 4 or more kills per round and 2. Lucky these missions are almost impossible

Overall I would recommend picking up this game even with it's flaws, and would rate it as a 7/10 for it's genre

This is a review for the 'Deleted scenes', because Steam won't let me review it separately.

Fan of the old CS games? Try this out.
This game is pretty much just a singleplayer game, but with the textures and physics of the original CS:CZ, hence the name.
Now I won't go in depth about what happens in the game in order to not spol it for anyone, but the beginning has to be my favorite part. A helicopter drops you off into the desert, and stuff goes down.
Positive sides would be mostly nostalgic, but don't get me wrong, it's a pretty good game. Just not by today's standards.
The AI is clumsy and at times very annoying. Sometimes you have no clue about where you should go, what you should do etc., which isn't necessarily what you'd expect from a game in the Counter-Strike series. It's not a puzzle game, it's a shooter. Or is it?
Overall as the game is, I'd give it a 3/10, because while it's not a complete piece of garbage, it just doesn't work as we nowadays expect games to work. It's an old game.

It is a more refined and updated CS: 1.6. This fact was very disappointing when it came out because it was very outdated by 2004 standards (Same year that Half Life 2 and the Source Engine came out), but for today it acts as a vastly improved time capsule of early CS history and nostalgia with the added benefits of native bot support and a neat little campaign against challenging AI. One thing it has going for it is how much smoother the game is compared to 1.6. The graphics are a lot better, and basically everything related to gameplay has been improved. I'd say it is worth your money more than 1.6 only if you like playing with bots and want a better experience with that. Condition Zero does not have nearly the same playerbase as 1.6 does and there are not many servers. Great game nonetheless.
(Btw I have a lot more hours on this game that predate me grabbing a digital copy)

I got this game mainly for the single-player campaign, The Deleted Scenes. As a first-time Counter-Strike player, it took me a while to learn the shooting mechanics, but I found the game quite entertaining and only now can I fully understand why the series is so popular. Granted, the graphics are dated and the AI can be brain-dead at times, but the missions are diverse and the objectives are generally fun.
Then there is the base game and its tour of duty missions, with challenges that I found boring, and of course the multiplayer mode. I only have a limited CS multiplayer experience, but the servers were easy to find and the game itself was fun.
Despite some of its shortcomings, this game is definitely recommended, even for the Deleted Scenes single-player campaign. And besides, what other games let you play as a left-handed character?

I have been playing Counter-Strike since before the days of Steam and I can say that for me (I know, no one cares) CS:CZ was the very best form of CS. I may be biased because I was heavy into the community many, many years ago and played it competitively at the highest level, but generally I just think that the maps were the best, the models were the best, and the game felt the absolute smoothest any CS has ever felt. It's essentially 1.6 but less wonky and better looking (Though I know that doesn't really matter because we never loved CS for its looks). The nostalgia I feel for this game is crazy. I just discovered today that this game had trading cards produced back in the day which are selling for 30 bucks on EBay and I might just be crazy enough to go buy them xD If you are at least a little curious about the hidden gem in the CS franchise history and haven't played around with this yet, I recommend you do so and at least check out CZ's take on many maps (like Dust2_cz and Inferno_cz), it will not disappoint! #topcz

Ahh I remember this game... let me tell you my story...

>stroll into my local GameStop
>looking to pick up maybe a copy of just this game, my lust and passion has craved for 
>grab the game and gallop towards the register when my trained eye notice a charming maiden
>-"Pardon me, milady....but could you ring me up? A Shame I don't have your number, or i'd ring you up instead..."
>she giggles and takes the game, blushing as her fingers brush mine due to my fingerless gloves
>her eyes widen as she reads the game's title
>"Wow, I've never seen anyone buy this before! You must have a special taste!"
>I smile and ready a witty response when... SUDDENLY a voice rings out from behind
>-"AHAHAH look what this ****** is buying! That's not EA Star Wars Battlefront! What a piece of ****!!!11one"
>I quickly turn around, my cloak billowing behind me, to discern the source of the rude outburst..
>generic dudebro caricature with a sports team cap and "the guy that beat you up that one time behind the school in early October" shirt is standing there guffawing..
>-"Excuse me sir.....you may disparage my person if you wish, but it is untoward to swear in front of a lady"
>-**** you ******!"
>I smile quietly and tip my fedora low across my eyes, concealing them...
>-"As you wish..."
>I quickly swing my cane into his kneecap before he can react
>he bellows and charges forward
>I expertly sidestep him and the cashier screams as he crashes into the counter
>I draw my sword-cane and mutter a quiet oath as I drive it deep into his back
>-"...requiescat in pace...."
>As I clean my blade the girl walks out from behind the counter, twirlig her hair with her fingers, bumping up in front of me and I inhale as her lady parts jumps up and down like my heartbeat..
>-"So... maybe you'd like to come over to my place to play that game sometime...?"
>I smirk, and whisper "No thanks, milady. I prefer single player. Besides...."
>I sheath my sword..
>-"You're not my type."
>*grab my dew and dorros, skate away on my Heelys*

It's not the best game in the franchise of Counter-Strike, but the thing I like about this game is it's Singleplayer Campaign. I really wished CS:GO had a singerplayer mode with missions and all that, and this one does. Now, I am not talking about "Deleted Scenes", but the offline game with bots you can recruit before you do the mission. It really gives this game a little bit of replay-ability, replay-ab--, reoeroierjgoeljpji, or however you say it.

The animations are not bad, and the overall gameplay is really nice. I was expecting more to be honest but, the only thing we got for this game is some new models for both factions, new animations, sounds, and maps (by that I mean the fact that the maps looked different, but they were pretty much the same.

The thing is: is it worth buying? Eh.. if you can, try to buy it when it's on Steam Sale or something, since I won't pay ~10 euros just for CS 1.6 with Singerplayer Missions/Campaign. I really love the maps in the campaign, though it feels a bit inclosed for me. Would've loved if they were a bit more opened.

This game is very similar to the original Counter Strike, however it has some additions like bots, remade maps and slightly improved graphics. The game also has a single player campaign which took me around 27 hours to complete (across all 4 difficulty levels). It's nothing special, just 18 maps with bots and specific challenges that you must complete in order to pass the mission, however it's still a bit of fun and something to do when you have free time. The multiplayer of this game is not as popular as the original Counter Strike's, so if you're looking for populated servers, the original Counter Strike is the way to go. Overall this game is great - it's the good old Counter Strike, with some welcome improvements.

Easily the worst in the series. Counter-Strike Condition Zero is a buggy mess that has so many problems it ruins the gameplay for me. I tried to give it chance, but it keeps frustrating me with all its deffects. Was the game rushed? Or did the devs just not care. Well, it's been over 10 years and it looks like that's the answer! If this game has been patched I'm afraid to ask what did it look like before the "fixes".

It's only saving grace (although very buggy, too) is the Tour Of Duty campaign mode and the abilty to make custom campaigns yourself.
If you wanna enjoy a Counter-Strike game- go play CS 1.6 or CS Source, GO, etc.

p.s. I was wondering why almost no one of my friends owns this game and now I know why.

This review mainly applies to CS:CZ Deleted Scenes, as CS:CZ just adds bots and objectives like "Kill 3 enemies with a sniper rifle" and is generally alright.

As for Deleted Scenes: This is the most confused & confusing version of CS ever.

Walking through the training mission, everything starts out like you'd expect for a single player version of CS, standard M4A1 intro, AWP and grenades. Plus a RC wall explosive (why not...), a radio that you can only use in specific locations (which makes it more like a phone booth), a camera that follows the same rule, and a fiberoptic device to spy on people through keyholes (think Rainbow Six, but it only works on select doors).

Then the game starts, and it's a mess. A heavily stereotyped mix of guys in a white turban starts yelling in what sounds like Arabic and attacking you. Some of them are basically Psychos from Borderlands, attacking you with machetes. Others are snipers, but they first aim at you with a laser. You may be familiar with these concepts from literally no version of CS ever.
They go down like flies, as any good bad guy should, and then you get stuck because the level layout is fucking awful, 90% of doors don't open and of those that do, at least half lead to dead ends (after you've gunned down the enemies behind them). The first friendly "sniper" you meet then tries to melee enemies with his AWP and dies, failing the mission instantly.

This is not a good game. If you want a CS single player, play the regular CS:CZ or just add bots to any other version of CS.

A sequel to the venerable Counter-Strike, only this time with upgraded graphics, a singple-player campaign, and the introduction of a few new maps, essentially what Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is. I must admit, I was bewildered as to why such a game existed as it came in a Counter-Strike bundle I had ordered for ¬£7 - which included Counter-Strike, Condition Zero + Deleted Scenes, and Global Offensive - so when I booted up the game, I was in for what I could only describe as the story mode version of Counter Strike.

The game presents Tour of Duty missions, each in their own unique maps, and gives you the ability before the fight to assemble a team, with each soldier having their own statistics which will affect their behavioural and combat abilities. Once you get into the mission, there are different objectives such as "Kill an enemy with a sniper rifle" or "Rescue a hostage" which compliment the gameplay and add a unique sidequest while you actively seek victory for your team you compiled.

Being the sequel to the exalted Counter-Strike, there is still a multi-player option available, just don't be surprised with the lack of active servers, for that you'll want to return to Counter-Strike 1.6 or go up a generation altogether.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a polyphony of single-player and multi-player, with a wholesome single-player campaign which doesn't steer away from the game's core mechanics.

If you've never touched a Counter-Strike game before and want to have a go at one, you can't go wrong with picking Condition Zero as the starting grid to your Counter-Strike journey.

[h1]!!Important note!![/h1]
I have only played Counter-strike condition zero Deleted scenes


[u]What I liked about the game[/u]
[list] 
[*]	A surprisingly long campaign. It took me about 9 hours to complete the deleted scenes. 

[*]	 A Large selection of weapons, which are satisfying to use. 

[*]	The missions take place all over the world. You will Join different counter-strike squads from around the world (British, USA, Japanese and Russia). 

[*]	Plenty of gore and violence; Lots of head popping and bodies exploding. 

[*]	The levels are well designed with plenty of hidden secrets. The levels reminded me of the ones in Half-life. 

[*]	Awesome training level; better than half-life‚Äôs and opposing force‚Äôs training level.

[*]	I liked the equipment you got to use, like the welding torch and the optic camera. 

[*]	Good Varity of terrorists to kill; From a machete wielding nutter or a suicide bomber to a gun wielding terrorist. The A.I is also pretty good.      

[*]	Not overly realistic. It‚Äôs not like Rainbow six or Ghost recon, the gameplay is more like half-life. 

[*]	Good soundtrack.          

[u]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/u]

[*]	Its Shame you can‚Äôt use the iron sights on some of the other weapons, like the M16. 

[*]	There isn‚Äôt really a story. The missions aren‚Äôt connected in any way. Its just different counter strike operations. 

[*]	It‚Äôs a shame you can‚Äôt pick ammo from enemies. 

[*]	Some of the levels are quite short.

[*]	There‚Äôs no memorable protagonists or antagonists. 

[*]	Would have been nice if you could carry your own first aid kit and able to use it anytime you want.  

[u]Conclusion[/u] 

Better than I thought. The single player campaign was longer than I expected. I didn‚Äôt expect much, especially with counter-strike beginning more focused on online multiplayer.  You get three games; counter-strike, counter-strike condition zero and counter-strike condition zero deleted scenes. If you like military types games or half-life, then I highly recommend you play this game. I wish they would introduce a single player Campaign into the later games.

[b]Intro[/b]
Note: This is a review of the Deleted Scenes campaign only. The content/replayability score does take in other modes however.

[b]The Great:[/b]
++N/A

[b]The Good:[/b]
+Sound design's actually somewhat decent with some really punchy weapon effects and half-decent environmental effects
+There's something oddly enjoyable about Gold Source's engine despite its annoying quirks. I honestly can't put my finger on it, but I'm sure plenty of people can relate.
+There's some bonus levels outside of the campaign
+The combat isn't totally without its' merits

[b]The Okay/Not Too Big of a Deal:[/b]
+-The devs actually managed to do some impressive things with the engine. Animating dead bodies to look like true ragdoll as in other games for one, and animating crumpling paper and crushing boxes for some more. I don't know how they managed to do some of it on the engine, but it actually does a good job of mimicking
real physics. It absolutely doesn't save this game's presentation, though.
-+The voice acting isn't the worst thing in the world but it's certainly not good, and the phony accents don't help

[b]The Bad:[/b]
-If you're below 25 health, all you can really do is pray to the RNG gods that both the enemy will decide to miss you and that your weapons will be accurate, which aren't often the case. So sometimes you'll go around a corner and die over and over until you get lucky and the enemies decide to miss and your bullets
decide to hit where you're aiming.
-Hit detection is awful, and I know I'm not mistaking it for inaccurate weaponry
-Reload animations are annoyingly long
-Movement is as slippery as Half-Life's, but much slower. Given how many thin ledges and platforming is required from you, I have to wonder who thought giving the character roller-skates was a good idea.
-The campaign is very short. Under 4 hours even on Hard. There are some bonus maps, however.
-Enemy placement is BS sometimes, but especially on the last level
-There is no story. There are settings and objectives for each level, but they're totally self-contained.
-It's barely a challenge for at least half the game, but then the enemy placements get more annoying and it starts kicking your butt some more
-Music's forgettable
-The stealth sections work about as well as you'd expect on this engine. Thankfully, they're rare and cheese-able.
-There's a really annoying glitch where loading a save makes you fire automatically until you press the fire button yourself. It got me killed many times.
-The FOV is too small and can't be changed

[b]The Horrible:[/b]
--This game came out in 2004... two thousand and fucking four. Yet, it barely looks better than the original Half-Life, which ALREADY looked out of date 6 years ago! To compare this game visually to Half-Life 2, Doom 3, Thief Deadly Shadows, or, you know, ANY game released in 2004, is like comparing the U.S. healthcare
to any other first-world country -- it's nothing but a laughing stock.
--Counter-Strike's trademark nonsensical, ridiculous recoil system made playing this more and more annoying. It's often up to RNG as to whether you'll actually hit anything thanks to random weapon spread mixed with strong recoil. Sometimes you can get two easy headshots without a problem, and sometimes you'll miss
even with your crosshair clearly right on their head and even shots point blank at their body. It's just absurd.
--Incredibly repetitive. Shoot similar types of braindead enemies over and over while planting a bomb or pulling out a gadget every now and then.

Sound: 5.5/10
Graphics: 2/10
Gameplay: 4/10
Content/Replayability: 8/10
Overall: 4.5/10

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Not a dreadful experience, but I can't recommend it. Good for a nostalgia trip if you played this at the time, or just to kill a few hours, but that's about it. I'm sure you have better things to do and games to waste your life on. I don't, that's why I bothered to finish it.
