Lets start by saying that by buying CZ you get three games. Multiplayer Condition Zero & CS 1.6(If you don't have it already) and singleplayer CZ Deleted Scenes. As far as I'm concerned, for multi, it's better to play CS 1.6. Condition Zero doesn't even look that good with "better" skins and textures. More people play CS 1.6 so it's easier to find servers too. Also, i think that overall, 1.6 is a better game. Now... it's worth very much to buy this for Deleted Scenes. Everyone who ever thought to themselves how cool it would be if CS had a singlep. campaign... you will wonder no more. You fly around the entire world, there is a mission on almost every continent. It's hard, but good, plenty of meds and ammo lie around so even on the hardest difficulty surviving shouldn't be a problem, rather a challenge sometimes. There are around 18 missions and all of them are good/great. To be honest I expected much less from Deleted Scenes and I was pleasantly surprised. I would recommend it to anyone who still enjoys GoldSrc games. Just remember to switch off that damn vertical synchronisation before you'll start playing. It's on by default, made me move like an elephant with all that input lag ;) 

PS: If you decide to play on hard from the start, just remember to play it like regular CS. Don't rush, pick around the corners and obstacles alot and quick, reload only when safe, always aim heads, shoot mainly bursts or single shots, try not to get shot and this will be a walk in the park. Park full of terrorists that is. Also, after you'll finish all of the main missions, there will still remain few undone on the world map, bonus ones, be sure to finish them too, they are  interesting and a little different than the rest. Like "Run!" mission or "Miami Heat".

CS:CZ is simple, singleplayer Counter Strike fun. Although it's getting on 14 years old, I had a nice time playing this game. The bots are much more interactive and friendly than any bot in CS:GO, and the amount of maps included because CS 1.6 just adds to the diversity of the gameplay. There are also "challenges" in each mission, which are more like side objectives, making sure that you are never just running around aimlessly trying to win. You can also hand-pick which pots to get to suit your playstyle, like bots that aren't brave but are good at following directions. Each bot also mains a weapon, so if you need a sniper per se, you can pick one that suits your needs. Overall, this game is fantastic if you want to play singleplayer CS because CS:GO offline can go fuck itself. Definitely worth the $1 that I paid, and worth the $10 normal price.

Deleted Scenes however, is a horrible compilation of boring, derivative missions that removes all of the mechanics and weapon ballistics that made the multiplayer mode so unique. Utterly forgettable and not worth playing.

Never before has a multiplayer game blended all the elements of true competition and sweat-soaked-shirt anxiety as well a Counter-Strike (CS). You probably already know CS as one of the most popular modifications for Half-Life. It's been available for download for over a year, at least in beta form. But unless you've got a super fast Internet connection at your house, you may not have played it yet as the nearly 100 megabyte download may be daunting for those of you not fortunate enough to have a high-speed connection. Thankfully CS has turned into a full-blown retail game and, while the two versions of CS are identical, it certainly worth shelling out $30 for this stellar title...plus you get a few more multiplayer goodies in the retail package to boot.

Let me start off by saying that the Counter-Strike pack is a stand-alone product. You don't need the original Half-Life to play this game. In the retail package you get a full version of CS as well as Team Fortress Classic, Opposing Force multiplayer, and the Wanted, Redemption and Firearms mods. The entire pack is overflowing with multiplayer fun, but, of course, the real focus of the retail release is Counter-Strike.

There is a single-player component to CS and, while it provides a good primer, this mod is all about online action. You basically play a game of cat and mouse, with the mouse being a terrorist group and the cat a squad of counter-terrorists. As a terrorist, you're goal is to plant a bomb at a specific location or hold a group of hostages. As a counter-terrorist, it's your duty to defuse said bomb or rescue the ill-fated hostages. Taking out all players on the opposing side will also assure your victory.

CS is an action lover's dream, with games lasting only four or five minutes (if that in some cases) because, unlike Half-Life, one shot to the head can mean instant death. CS is the perfect mix between fast-action and realistic damage. You can't just absorb bullet after bullet and expect to walk away. Working as a team is a must and, while you're in the game, taking the lone wolf approach will often get you killed...and fast.

It's the team-based tactics that make CS so fun. I can't stress how important it is in this game to act as a team. If your team is on the defensive side you'll all benefit by creating a cohesive strategy. If you team is on the offensive side, you will all benefit by sticking closely together as well. I'm sure you've seen movies or television show demonstrating this "Conga Line" style of infiltration. Well, that's exactly how your team will have to act. This creates a fantastic game balance that will keep you coming back for more. It'll also keep you from thinking about your school work, your job, and interaction with your loved ones, and often work around the IGN offices will be put on hold so we can clog our network with CS.

Visually the game will not disappoint. While the Half-Life engine isn't the prettiest beast out there, there is plenty of animation that creates a smooth look and feel, and the gun models are some of the most realistic looking of any shooter available. The environmental textures look realistic enough and complement the provided camouflage well enough for you to be hidden, but not be invisible. As in real life, the distinguishable difference between good guy and bad guy is a little difficult, but the balance to this is if you can't tell who it is then you probably won't be able to hit him with your gun. Now, if you've purchased sniper rifle, you should have plenty of scope magnification to tell the difference between terrorist or counter-terrorist, but otherwise you may be taking out a team member from afar.

As good as it is, a couple of features of this game really stood out as frustrating... at first. But over a period of time they actually became enhancements to online multiplayer gaming. One feature is buying your weapons at the start of each round. This takes a little getting used to at first since, in most shooters, you just run around picking up weapons at your heart's content. Usually by the time you figured out which guns, grenades, and armor you were going to take in your early games, the bad guys would come over and kill you. But a couple of tries later, after getting the gist of things, you're off in no time. The other feature that took some getting used to was the "wait and watch" feature after you get killed. Once you sustain a lethal injury, you have to wait for the next round to start before you can join in again -- you don't just spawn again and start shooting. This actually adds a ton of anxiety to your efforts of staying alive and completing your objective. But like I mentioned before, the rounds are short, so you shouldn't have to wait too long before you can jump in the action again.

(for Deleted Scenes) Good game so far, a nice half-life style take on a CS campaign (better than the regular game, or I suck at CS in general...), however I did encounter problems with Building Recon: a staggering 4 headshots with the Scout in order to kill the leader. That's more than I can do at medium range behind cover and with a nuke beeping away. Tip: cheat code 'notarget'.

After completing the campaign, it is pretty hard but at least is a bit better than CS:CZ's one since I suck at Counter-Strike. As much as I suck, maybe it would be wise to list a few quirks in order to play this game: [spoiler]Use knife to get through vents, branches (Downed Pilot). On Hankagai, use the blue (crates? boxes?) in order to get over fences or to the vent.[/spoiler] When you discover everything you need to know about the game, it can be quite playable but there is still the problem of lack of armour most of the time (therefore a reliance on medical supplies) and that the enemies appear to be quite accurate, which only exarceberates the previous problem. Then again, I suck at Counter-Strike so what would you expect?

I love it for the missions. Yes, this counter-strike has single player missions. You get to hand pick your team of bots, based off of their bravery (tendency to rush sites or to camp basically), their cooperation (Their tendency to listen to your radio commands), and their actual skill to take out an enemy.

Though the single player mode is pretty fun and you could get a good 30 minutes at a time out of it, theres literally like 3 people playing online, and they all aimbot. I would give it a thumbs up, but its f*cking $10! if it was $5 that would be a thumbs up immediately. (btw I got this in a bundle with cs 1.6 so i bought 1.6 for $10 and this came with it, but this still shouldn't be $10.)

Condition Zero: 

The bots are actually difficult sometimes, but they can be pretty dumb sometimes. Don't bother going on multiplayer, it's either competitive matches between people who had this game since release in 2004, or dumb modded servers with custom maps that are also dumb. The single-player objectives hinder progress since it limits you to certain weapons and strategies, but it's really just a good training exercise for the custom games with bots. Lots of replay-ability. However, one map is much more significant than the rest: dust.

Deleted Scenes:

Now with objectives and a linear play-style, the game feels like you're going around the world stopping terrorists. The stories are a bit far-fetched sometimes, but it's still very fun. The voice acting isn't good (especially with the foreign accents), but it has some needed comic relief. You do some crazy stuff, too: stopping an ICBM from being launched, rescue hostages at an embassy, and kill some crazy crime boss Scarface-style. It's fun overall, and why not give it a try?

Released in March 2004 (a surprising 8 months before the release of Counter-Strike: Source in November) after 4 YEARS of trials, tribulations and delays, Counter-Strike: Condition Zero + Deleted Scenes is... a mixed bag of sorts, mostly because the main game isn't even the best part!

Condition Zero is a series of missions that don't really correlate or connect with each other, but Deleted Scenes is a full blown story mode! Given the time that this came out, the story is very reminiscent of the early Call of Duty games. (and that's not a bad thing!)

This brings back a lot of memories, i've been playing Counter-Strike since Beta 5.2 or so, when there were vehicles and the Aldi maps with the objective to blow up a freezer full of Pizzas and Condition Zero is the closest thing to the madness since 1.6 is more "advanced" than this, Source and Global Offensive go in entire different directions, the madness of original CS (once called realistic!) is here to stay with this fine piece of wacky gunplay, wacky gameplay, wacky developer history that is also shown with the deleted scenes, an entire different piece of Counter-Strike: Missions that barely work, with weird AI and no wonder it was cancelled (i feel old by saying that i lived through the entire sad story of this as it was portrayed in gaming magazines) 
Anyway this is really old school Counter-Strike with some weird hit boxes and a single player experience, in the main game you have to do objectives like "kill 2 enemies with a sniper" or "defuse a bomb" ot get points with which you can get some better bots, altough better sure is in the eye of the beholder, they talk to you a lot but they sure can't kick ass
As a bonus the deleted scenes are included a try to get a coherent single player story into counter-strike that was cancelled by Valve before it was even in a proper beta stage, it's actually better than you might expect but not great because of its age.
This pack is only for those who have a big nostalgia feel toward the good old days of CS or those who are curious at to what a single player CS looks like. For a low price and it's usually on sale anyway, it's worth to try, so i give a thumbs up, since even the regular price is low and on sale it's cheap enough so even a McDonald's employee can afford it.

Maybe someone who likes solo play games i would reccomend this.

This game is arguably the best game in the series, with an amazing singleplayer mode and its fun gameplay. There's also something very charming about late 90s and early 2000s game graphics that makes the game enjoyable. In the singleplayer mode, you lead your own counter-terrorism team, which is great, even if you enjoy playing on the side of the terrorists. The teammates will have three attributes: Skill, Co-op, and Bravery. I don't know what these do, so you'll have to put up with my thoughts. Skill determines tactics, Co-op determines how likely they will respond to and obey commands, and Bravery determines if they camp or face the enemy head-on. I haven't played multiplayer yet, but if you suck at multiplayer (I know I do), then this game is for you. Even if you enjoy multiplayer, I still highly recommend this game and that you play it's singleplayer.

[h1]COUNTER-STRIKE: CONDITION ZERO[/h1]

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is more of a modification to 1.6 rather than a game in it of itself; it uses most of the same animations and only retextures a couple of maps, but it gets less credit than its due.

For instance, it has a far superior buy menu, with a more extensive loadout customizer that works way better than the one we have in Source.

The graphics are also way better and way more stylistic than Source's, which is literally 1.6 on the Source Engine, like a slightly less lazy HL:S. The sound design is greatly improved and the changed guns sound a lot more like an accurate depiction of what a real gun sounds like. Nothing even reminiscent of PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds's but closer than any of the stock assets used in the other games. The model, lighting and texture quality was also made better, and both teams not only have a new faction each but also all have new stylized designs that stray farther from the real deal but still gives each of them a character of their own.

Not to mention that the controls are in this void between Source and 1.6 where it has recoil and less absurd penetration but the accuracy and shooting system in general is still 1.6's, which is very fun to play with.

Along with the usual simple offline bot match, this game has a few sets of 3 maps you have to clear by having at least 3 round wins and exactly 2 more than the terrorists, against a varying amount of opponents with different skillsets. It proves to be a good challenge to anyone and a great way to get good at the game while passing time and having fun. This mode also adds more depth to the CT factions, with each having a tendency to certain characteristics, for instance the Seals and the SAS are braver, while the GSG-9 and GIGN play it safe.

[h1]DELETED SCENES[/h1]

A very memorable experience, worth a replay or two. The large majority of the missions are fun, most of the enemies' deaths are animated with few exceptions, there's a lot of destroyable scenery and the battles are very ecstatic. The weapon, equipment and enemy progression is very well structured but the way the game tells how this worldwide conflict came to be or when is it all going to end is too loose to form anything concrete. My guess? Resonance Cascade. The game lasted 8 hours for me, but you can probably beat it in 6 on an easier difficulty.

There are a few references to Half Life, albeit probably unintentional, where loot is found inside those small green canisters Black Mesa employees use to store ammunition and weaponry, or in certain places where there are those ceiling turrets you see everywhere around the facility, even if a hell of a lot weaker.

A lot of the maps are very well detailed to the point of it not even looking like a GoldSrc game but rather an early Source engine game. Some of the textures leave a lot of room for improvement while some leave barely any. It uses a lot of flashing lights and other lighting effects so I recommend playing through certain missions like DrugLab or the final skycraper mission in Software mode. Both look better in a some places and in some not, with similarly varying performance, so its mostly up to choice and hardware compatibility. It's an old game, and so there's a chance you'll encounter lag no matter how pricey your rig is.

The factions consist of most of the OG, the Elite Crew, the Arctic Avengers, the Guerilla Warfare, and a few other ones, such as a few generic Islamic grunts or gangsters. All of them give the impression of Middle Eastern crazies that think nukes = less oppression, though, so the only real difference between them is that some hold hostages and some hold bombs. Basically the same as the multiplayer game, just a lot more exciting and real. The 1337s appear wearing all black with blue jeans, though, unlike their usual green shirt and brown jeans. The heads are all the same for every faction, except all use a different texture. For example, the factions that use the Guerilla Warfare model have different beard types, and the others rarely share the same body.

There's a lot more cinephys in this game than any other game from the same era. If it hadn't been so overlooked we might've gotten that juicy BF4 levolution a lot sooner than we asked. For example, certain characters that you kill fall out from whatever platform they're standing on and onto crates which break apart in a realistic manner without using any sort of simulation or gib effect. Another example is on the mission "Building Recon", when air support flies over a terrorist, blowing him out of the roof he's on and collapsing both his building and the one beside it.

Level exploration isn't a cryptic must such as in Poke646, where it's harder to find the way out of wherever you're in than to find a hidden cache, or the original HL, where there was barely any encouragement to exploration apart from Office Complex. You're rewarded with OP guns such as the AWP or the M249, which is as useful as it was in 1.6 instead of the crappy crap crap we got in Source and especially GO.

The player isn't talked much about and isn't voiced by anyone, but he seems to be always shifting, never a single person, as if you were really just a random soldier fighting through the waves of less trained opponents that happened to do a thing that saved a bunch of people, or in some cases just 2 or 3. And yet the game makes you feel proud of what you've done. I admire that. It's a very interesting take on the whole badass soldier vibe that most games nowadays and back then had. You'll probably remember that same mechanic from DICE's latest Battlefield game's campaign, just more pronounced and not ignored.

What happened to this game was unfortunate. Very unfortunate. It would've done just as much if not more than what HL did to the gaming industry if it hadn't launched so close to Source and had been properly advertised.

I fully advise you to buy this game if you're looking for a challenge that isn't too hard, but let me warn you, play it on easy. Playing through it on medium had me getting very frustrated in certain parts of the game for simply not being 1% faster than the AI. It's that hard. It's as if the HL1 grunts gained an eye on their back, sneaking is impossible in this game unless if you're told to, and grenades are rather unpredictable. Just make sure to keep in mind that grenades in this game are just like HL1's or 1.6's, even though they can deal a lot of damage if their ray casting doesn't catch their target its not gonna deal any damage at all, even if the target in question is behind a 1 unit thick wall or a on a slightly raised part of the scenery. Best case scenario, its right under their feet.

Wasting ammunition isn't an issue in this game. At all. I constantly find myself underwhelmed with ammo until I get something that deals some damage like a Kalashnikov or an M4 or even an AWP or a machine gun. Its like the game really wants you to use everything, but as always the M1014 is ignored due to its shittyness. Oh and don't even bother with the M3 Super 90, they nerfed it so hard its as useful as it is in CS:S and nowhere as cool and neat and super as 1.6's. Everything else is fairly meh.

Some of the mission concepts get tiring after a while; chase the VIP, defuse the nuke, kill the VIP, protect the VIP team, go after the guy that tried to assassinate the VIP, kill him, rescue these people, rescue yourself, repeat. It's repetitive as fuck and some more variation like in the mission Secret War, which I believe is the second one, would've been nice. I had to take 3 breaks before finally completing the game despite my will to do it in one continuous run. The voice acting is ok for the most part but it gets laughable at some others ([spoiler]"We could always throw icicles at the intruders! HOHOHOHOHO"[/spoiler]).

A very well deserved buy and another great mark on TRS's, Ritual's & Gearbox's past.

This is Counter Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes (Beta) Remastered: Reimagined Resurrection II: Electric Boogaloo: Revenge of Saddam Part 3: Osama's Redemption: The CIA's Plan: The Train Mission: Operation Black Tango: Gunship Down: Insurrection Stage 2: Insurgency: The Revenge: 9/11 part 2: Firefighter Spec-Ops Stories: The Pentagon: Zombies: Resurrection II: Time Machine: Aborting Hitler: The Butterfly Effect: Nazis In Space. It is probably my favourite game in the Call of Duty franchise aside from LEGO Star Wars II: Anakin's Repentance. This game is very good if you want an experience similar to playing CS 1.6 with mentally deficient small children that have bad voice acting. My favourite part of this game was the mission "Miami Heat", in which you play as a gambler named Nick Jonas who is in search of his long lost lover, but ends up rescuing hostages instead. Or the mission "Run!", where a bunch of samurais chase you for your gemstone adorned amulet. Overall I would reccomend this game, if you enjoyed the competetive "community" of CS:GO, this game will feel like a big 'ol hugbox.

The story isn't even there, you play as a cop, then another cop, but never the same cop, but in exchange you do feel badass, saving the world from terriost, or the Irish.  I say give it a go, if you are tierd of mutiplayer, and need a fun campain.

The black sheep and middle child of the infamous Counter-Strike series, Condition Zero was the follow-up to the original eponyous game, and in a way, it was a sort of a forerunner to the modern warfare genre of shooters, when the heart of WWII-themed games beat strong.

The core gameplay, although prettied up with crisper graphics and a slew of inventive new maps, was exactly the same as before, but with bots in case playing with real users is just not your cup of tea. Alongside this was "Deleted Scenes", a Half-Life-like spin-off that had an interesting premise, but is unfortunately bogged down with levels lacking in replayability, poor AI, and atrocious foreign accents.

Overall, it's an oddball of a title, but it's a worthwhile investment to toy around with if the somewhat elitist attitude of the esports meta-crazed fanbase threatens to turn you away from the series as a whole, as the in-game bots are aim-botty yet forgiving and there's always the Deleted Scenes to take a break with, if you can just bear the corny dialogue of your enemy. Oh, and rushing B, there's always that.

This is what happens when you have 3 cooks in the kitchen and take too long to get a game out. Compared to Half-Life 2 and Counter-Strike: Source, which both came out in the same year as this game (2004), Condition Zero offers practically nothing. The game was so bad during development that Valve even reverted its "gold" status and changed developers on the project 3 times. The result is that very few ideas feel consistent and connected. 

Single-Player experience? You just get a bunch of bot matches with arbitrary and unimaginative restrictions and goals to complete missions that are not connected in any way (there isn't even any pretend story). The nicest word I can use for the sense of progression is "limited". Also, when you finish the game, there's just... nothing. 

Multi-player experience? This game plays exactly like Counter-Strike 1.6, but partitions the players instead of just offering the campaign as an expansion (similar to Diablo II and Diablo II: LoD, which also came out around the same time). There are some exclusive maps, but I failed to see how any of them were an improvement to their CS 1.6 counterparts. Even if the maps were enough of an incentive, it was a pretty low effort endeavor for someone to copy-paste them into the CS 1.6 workshop. This means that you essentially had 2 versions of CS going on at one time, except one of them costed extra so people just stuck with 1.6 instead lol.

Graphics? They look like hot garbage compared to the other games from Valve that came out at the same time (Half-Life 2 and CS: Source). The game looks like it was made in 1998.

I got this as part of the Counter-Strike complete package during a Steam Sale, and it felt like an incredible chore to finish. There is a video from a recent CS:GO major talking about the history of Counter-Strike, and they mention how "[url=https://youtu.be/tUtNDLo9chQ?t=4m6s]Source is almost forgotten in CS history[/url]". Funny how they comment on that while actually omitting CS:CZ from CS history. Honestly, this game is an embarassment.

When you get Counter-Strike: Condition Zero, you are actually buying two separate games, Condition Zero, which is the final product and is essentially a bunch of bots matches, and the Deleted Scenes, which is a series of unconnected singleplayer level and is essentially the remains of an older version of the game before it was completely redone. The irony is that the final product seems to have less content and not be of as high quality as the Deleted Scenes.

Condition Zero itself is simply an ordered series of bot matches across many counter-strike maps. You can recruit bots using points won by winning matches which is pretty nice as it allows you to have some level of control over team management.

Within each match you have individual goals you must complete like 'kill a certain numbers of enemies with a particular weapon' or 'rescue a certain number of hostages'. These are presumably to try and force the player to vary their gameplay, but most of them end up just being frustrating and annoying to complete. 

Another frustrating feature is that if you die, there's no 'control bot' option like in CS:GO, you are instead forced to watch the bots play out the rest of the round. As I'm sure you can imagine, watching this can be very painful indeed, and it is also very frustrating and time-consuming. 

There is also a multiplayer component to Condition Zero, which is simply the same as in the original CS. There are surprisingly a significant number of populated servers, and it is very easy to simply jump onto a server and start playing. However if the multiplayer is the main component you‚Äôre after, it would be wiser to look into .6 as its playerbase is a lot, lot bigger.

Despite its flaws, Condition Zero is overall still a pretty fun game though.


Deleted Scenes however is a very different game entirely. It is a group of many call of duty style singleplayer missions. Although they are in the style of newer games call of duty, they still retain all the elements of classic counter-strike games, such as hitscan weapons with no aiming down sights and a fixed health percentage with no regeneration, as well as that classic GoldSrc ‚Äòfeel‚Äô. This in my opinion means that the game has a really interesting and unique feel to it.

The missions can be played in a pre-set order, however they aren't related in terms of context or story at all, each is its own separate unrelated 'episode' if you like. This might sound like a flaw to the game, but personally I believe it is a benefit as it means that each level can go in a different direction and is unique from the others. 

The gameplay mostly consists of call of duty style missions. Although the main overall gameplay is the same in all missions, the individual nature of each mission means that are all varied in terms of settings, plots and structure. For example, some missions contain lots of stealth sections, some require you to use various tools and gadgets like snake cameras, radios and explosives to progress whereas others contain boss fights against enemy leaders or vehicles. 

The levels are all of a perfect length too. You can easily complete a mission in one sitting, yet it'll still take you a reasonable amount of time to do so, allowing them to have a structure. 

In conclusion, if you're looking for the classic counter-strike multiplayer experience or the opportunity to play bot matches, while Condition Zero will allow you to do those, it would be wiser to look towards 1.6 or GO respectively. However if you are a fan of games like Call of Duty, Half-Life or just GoldSrc games in general, then Deleted Scenes is an underrated fun experience.

Before screaming 12 year olds, before 30 dollar day one dlc, in the shrouded mists of my boyhood, there were actual good games. CS:CZ is one of them. My best friend and I used to play this game for HOURS just taking turns killing bots. 

It may be that I have my nostalgia blinders on, but I genuinely believe that this is the most fun Counter-Strike, precisely because it's the LEAST SERIOUS one. It's essentially CS 1.6, with updated graphics and some really fun bots thrown in. You can even edit the bots and make your own bot leagues if you are so inclined. Also, if you Google search "Condition Zero botprofile", there are people that have already edited botprofiles and uploaded them so you can download them. If you don't have time to edit your own bots, then these files will make the bots better without you having to do the footwork. 

In summary, if you are a person who wants to play some CS, but you don't have the time to invest in becoming a 1.6 tryhard, or if you are just an old school CS player, (like me) who won't buy into all this CSGO skin annoyance, or if you simply don't want to listen to 12 year olds tell you about how many times they've slept with your mom, then pick Condition Zero up. It's really great.

Fixed many of the bugs and glitches of CS1.6. Updated graphics, models, maps, guns and sounds. Grenade damage didn't hurt you through walls anymore, but packed more punch.
For me, Condition Zero was a better game than 1.6, which i why i played CZ more than 1.6. Just had more fun playing that game, instead of being wallbanged by a guy from the other side of the map on 1.6. A bit more realism, so it helped.

Yet, Valve rarely ever talks about the game. In a recent youtube video called; "The history of CS:GO", they only talk about 1.6 and Source, and act like CZ never existed... but for me it was a huge success. Better game than 1.6 in every way!

[h1]Overview[/h1]
Counter-Strike: Condition Zero or CS:CZ is a team based FPS where teamwork and strategy is everything. One wrong move, one stupid decision, one badly handled recoil and you're dead. This game, and like the other versions of it, is very challenging.


[h1]Pros[/h1]
-Fun and Addicting
-Teamwork
-Realistic
-Challenging recoil and aim
-Single-Player missions
-Mods
-Variety of game-modes
-Loadouts

[h1]Cons[/h1]
-A bit glitchy and laggy, but what do you expect from a game made in 2004?
-Not a game for scrubs. Get good.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I honestly love this game, and the other versions of it. I would recommend you try it out to atleast see what the old Steam was like and how things worked. But as far as the series goes, I have to recommend that you get into CS:GO rather than this.

So, as it seems, CS:CZ is suppose to be a singleplayer game, along with traditional multiplayer mode almost identical to one found in the previous CS instalment, the infamous 1.6. 
As a player who actually likes playing against bots in online games, such as Counter-Strike (any), Team Fortress 2, FoF, Quake Live, Quake 3 and Quake 3: Team Arena, the whole "singleplayer element" found in CS:CZ is really, really bad in my humble opinion.
The gameplay is just like your traditional Counter-Strike but with predifined number of bots and "tasks" instead. The player is given several tasks which MUST be accomplished in order to pass the mission. Unfortunately, majority of these tasks are absolutely what the player SHOULDN'T be doing in a regular CS match. Here are some examples:
1. Kill x players
2. Kill x players with a specific gun
3. Kill x players with a specific gun and survive the round
4. Win below x seconds
5. Rescue x/all hostages

So, here's my explanation to the following points respectively:

1. Barely any progresss will be made if player's playstyle won't be shifted from cooperative towards tryhardish, with the former being much more welcome in online games. That means, in CS:CZ campaign the player must play aggressively, lone-wolfing, making him prone to dying. Of course, the player may remain cooperative but it will very likely result in a rather unwelcome prolonging of the mission.

2. In order to perform well, players should always use weapons they feel comfortable with/high tier weapons, however in this case the player MUST use a specific weapon (usually a fitting one for the map though). Sure, game forces us to try out different guns but in reality the players usually stick to Deagles, AWPs and M4/AK47 for the most of the time anyways. Perhaps that's the task, but still a crappy one, considering players have their most favorite and hated guns, which will never be chosen in an online game anyway.

3. Same as above but this time with an opportunity to actually fail the task, forcing the player to be stuck with whatever gun he/she has to stick with for even longer until he/she finally manages to score required amount of frags and also survive the round.

4. Another tryhard gameplay promotion. Frag opponents in shortest time possible, meaning, the player must rush B like a cyka blyat in order to pass the mission. At least it is somewhat challenging at times but again highly discouraged in traditional CS matches.

5. The absolute worst of all tasks, since AI controlled hostages can easily get stuck, yet the task will be only ticked off when all of the hostages are rescued. Here's a number of things that can easily prevent player from accomplishing this task:

a. Hostage gets stuck and it is no longer reachable (like jumping from a balcony/roof but the hostage doesn't follow). Even if reachable, it's extremely tedious to go back and it also increases chances of encountering an opponent, which can make player's ordeal completely null and void.
b. Player manages to get to the hostages, takes them with him/her but bots suddenly frag the very last terro, triggering the win-by-elimination victory.
c. hostages get in the way during gunfight, potentially making player stuck, giving terro an opportunity to score a frag and obviously preventing player from finishing this task in this very round. The loss might have an impact on the next round, reducing the chance of accomplishing the task even further.

Summary:
CS:CZ is a lazy attempt at CS singleplayer mode, full of solutions that are plain wrong and boring. Better stick to a regular game with bots and play as you wish. It could have been much better if it would have taken Half-Life's approach. Instead we have a game. barely different from any of the other CS games but instead with bots and boring, forced tasks. Tedious. That's all that can be said about the campaign. As a singleplayer game I do not recommend it. As a multiplayer game, you better off stick to CS 1.6 instead.

This game is more fun with the bots. Granted, the AI is sometimes terrible and glitchy for many maps (even cz ones), but the most fun is to edit the botprofile.db and make your own unique bots (it's very easy to do) and essentially form your own match league. I have created around 700 bots each with their own clan tag, track standings/stats etc. Granted, it's a lot of bot-simulated matches which would be boring to most people, but has kept me occupied as I am a stat junkie. Captures some level of competion for me, as I am way too old to participate in any ladders or really be any good anymore, whereas most people could dominate any of the bots very easily. But for me, a fun little throwback to my younger days. Now I'll go put my false teeth back in and take a lap around the retirement center on my motorized cart.

[h1][b]This part is for The Deleted Scenes Part![/b][/h1]
This is what Half-life should of been. You play these mini missions and your goal changes on each mission. Sometimes you have to recurse a hostage or defuse a bomb, or stop a drug lord. Each mission gives you different weapons and tools to use. Also some of those weapons have a flashlight on them so use them in dark areas if you want. Each mission has its own small story to it and its own cast of characters. Also each mission takes place in different areas. You could be in the U.S for one then in Japan in another mission. I had more fun with this game then I did with HL1 .
[h1][b]This part is for stock CZ![/b][/h1]
Single player mode has you playing on maps with a set goal(s) in which you have have to complete to move on to the next one. Unlike Deleted Scenes which hands you the weapons, you have to buy the weapons yourself just like in a normal round of CS, also you can hire AI controlled npcs to help and each have their own pros and cons. Some listen to commands better while others don't, some are good with weapons and some are more braver then others. Other then that its normal CS and I had some fun. Your mileage may vary tho.

Counter Strike Condition Zero is an odd one. Caught in between CS 1.6 and Source, it came very close to CS: Source's release, and was brushed aside. At the time, it graphics were outdated, and its single player content was lacking. Today, the single player content is just as lackluster. The regular campaign is literally offline bots with some slight customization. It's bland, boring, and the AI is pretty terrible. There's also the "Deleted Scenes", which is actually an entirely other game. It's a single player CS Campaign that plays nothing like Counter Strike. It feels more like a fast-paced Arcade shooter. It's plagued with poor map design, cheesey plot that desperately wanted to blend with games like Halo at the time, and gimmicky spy gadgets that while intriguing at first, are poorly executed. 
    Where Condition Zero does shine is its multiplayer. It's graphics are dated but timeless. It feels like an updated CS 1.6 in visuals, and plays in a way thats really unique to Condition Zero. Ammunition is expensive and money is tight, so you really have to watch your shots in this game. It still has a very large playerbase, and holds up much better than the classic 1.6 
   While Condition Zero failed to capture a single player Counter Strike expirience, it did create a pretty fun Multiplayer that's still fun to hop on today. It's by no means a masterpiece, but it isn't a bad game. If the CS Anthology pack ever goes on sale, I'd say pick it up and try it out. But on its own, I'd say it's a pass.

Nutshell: 8/10 - Not the best of singleplayer campaigns but otherwise an amazing classic FPS game for a decent price. 

What is Counter-Strike: Condition Zero? - SWAT Team Simulator 2004 is the short answer, if you've played the original Counter-Strike, then this is basically the same thing, with a singleplayer campaign.

Will it Run on My Computer? - 10/10 - Probably, unless you got a really outdated computer (if your computer was made later than 2000 I'm sure you're fine, really it doesn't take much to run this game)

Parents Guide - I'd say it's 13+, you can turn off blood, and deaths in this game aren't very graphic when blood is off.

Graphics - 6/10 - I'd say, for being made in 2004, it's really lacking, only thing that noticeably improve over the original Counter Strike is better textures, otherwise graphically it's identical. 

Singleplayer - 6/10 - There is a singleplayer campaign, though it's really lacking, as with most first-person shooters, though it's better than not having a singleplayer campaign at all. 

Multiplayer - 9/10 - Pretty much perfect, though I will point out this game is 12 years old as of this review, so there are not as many players as say, 5 years ago. Player count aside multiplayer is awesome.

Is it Worth it? - 8/10 - Pretty good, not much more I could really ask for in an FPS that's only $10, mayber slightly better graphics, but really it's worth every penny.

The main issue people found with Condition Zero was that it looked a lot like 1.6; although that claim is true this having mild graphical enhancements and plenty of bug fixes, it's still a great game. The multiplayer is like 1.6 but the true fun is to be had in deleted scenes - which if you don't know is essentially a counter strike 1.6 campaign mode and although not revolutinary now-a-days it's still a whole lot of fun. If you push aside the graphics there is a lot of fun to be had on this game and for all the hate it got it's still good old counter strike. So if you have some time spare or your getting sick of Global Offensive give this a try ( I recommend going on hard mode for the most enjoyment).

TL;DR

[h1]Combine CS 1.6 and COD and what do you get? Condition Zero. [/h1]

[b]Tour of Duty Mode[/b]
     In Condition Zero, Valve have improved the CS formula by adding a story and squad mechanics. In the Tour od Duty mode, you're presented with a paragraph or so explaning your mission before you play a few rounds of CS 1.6 on all your favorite maps. Though the Tour of Duty mode can get tiresome, it's kept somewhat fresh by managing your squad. Before each mission, you can choose which squad members to bring, and you can see your team grow from a rag-tag team to a crack squad.

[b]Deleted Scenes[/b]
     The real meat and potatoes of Condition Zero lies in the Deleted Scenes extra content. I can only assume that Deleted Scenes was an early version of Condition Zero, hence the name and rough edges. Deleted Scenes plays much more like a COD game than CS. Your character is a lone badass hero, who guns his way though rooms of enemies, until he finally completes his objective. Each mission has it's own maps. You won't be playing on de_dust2 here. Instead, you'll be infiltrating a secret warehouse where some terrorits have taken a stolen nuke, or stopping an ICBM from launching. Deleted Scenes is definetly a diffrent exprence from the typical CS game, but it's also a great one.

Cory in the House is a television show, which aired on the Disney Channel from January 12, 2007 to September 12, 2008 and was a spin-off from the Disney show That's So Raven. The show focuses on Cory Baxter, who moves from San Francisco, California to Washington, D.C. with his father, after Victor Baxter gets a new job in the White House as the official head chef. The series marks a Disney Channel first, as it is the channel's first spin-off. This is also the only Disney Channel spin-off series to be broadcast in standard definition for the entire length of the show. Reruns of the series have not been produced on Disney Channel, or on Disney XD; however they continue to air on the Family channel in Canada. Raven-Symon√© guest-starred, reprising her role as Raven Baxter in one episode. In 2014 Disney Channel started airing a weekly block called Disney Replay on Wednesdays nights, during which episodes of Cory in the House air alongside That's So Raven and Kim Possible, among others.

Counter Strike Condition Zero is an interesting game to discuss not because of it's merits as a game but largely for it's history. It had a surprisingly troubled development and changed hands between 4 distinctive developers before finally becoming finished. 

The game was originally designed by Rogue, the developers behind Strife and American McGee's Alice. However the developer went out of buisiness so Valve instead gave it to Gearbox, who Valve had previously worked with on Opposing Force and Blue Shift. Much of the game is based around Gearbox's version, which focused on creating more impressive graphics and remaking many of the classic Counter Strike maps in better detail.

However, the project changed hands again and the game was handed off to Ritual entertainment. The guys behind SiN. They remade the game as a pseudo singleplayer title before Valve decided to hand the game off to Turtlerock studios. Who would years later create Left 4 Dead. Who finished the game and completed it based on Gearbox's version. The content Ritual made would be released as the "Deleted scenes".

The final game is very much inspired by Counter Strike 1.6. It plays very similarly albiet with nicer graphics and a very different art style. It was also the very first Counter Strike game to ship with bots by default. The game also contains a singleplayer separate from the Deleted Scenes, however this is just an Unreal Tournament style ladder featuring botmatches. 

When Condition Zero came out, it was seen as outdated. It released two years too late, and the very same year as Valve's own Counter Strike Source. As a result it isn't often talked about when compared to the other games. Since you do get it by default when buying 1.6 it's interesting to play for curiosity's sake, but you'll likely find more players for 1.6 or Source.

This game actually has better bots than the latest iteration of this game series, good graphics that is reminiscent of CS 1.6, a nice game which actually isn't affected by nerfs or buffs, which is nice, most modern computers should run this game, it's still very dark in certain parts of maps (a well known one being lower tunnels leading to B palace or CT mid on Dust 2), this does offer single player missions so if you want a game of CS without the graphics but with the nostalgia, CS:CZ is one of the games you should play. If you buy this game, you get CS:CZ, CS 1.6 and the "Deleted Scenes" version of this game, for the price of CS 1.6 alone, which is a nice bonus and one of the better reasons to buy this game if you want empty servers and bad graphics, but it's nice to relive CS 1.6 again.

Earlier I had the non-steam version which I had gotten from my friend, but I formatted my computer without backing up, so I lost all my data, including the game. I decided to purchase the Steam version, after much thought between this and Source, since I've never played the latter. I also own CS: GO, but I've always preferred older games, simply because my computer isn't graphics heavy, and newer games tend to lag quite a bit, which is the last thing you want in FPS games.

I'm playing this after a long time, and I must say, this is much better than Global Offensive in so many ways, I regret purchasing it. If you are in doubt of which to buy, go for CZ. I definitely recommend it over GO. I'm yet to play Source, and I will write another review once I do.

The missions are decent -- they don't add much to gameplay, but each mission gives you a sense of satisfaction and joy of completion. I'm yet to set up a LAN server and try to play with friends, but past experience with the non-Steam version was great. 

PROS:

Good maps? Check.
Amazing servers? Check.
Good weapon choice? Check.

(Personal favourites: Maps - Havana, Prodigy, Dust, Dust2, Nuke; Servers - Normal Terrorists vs. CT, Zombie servers; Weapons - AK-47, Machine Gun, Magnum Sniper Rifle)

CONS: 

Good graphics? Nope, but decent enough to thoroughly enjoy gameplay

All-in-all, I completely recommend making this cheap purchase - you get way more than what you pay for!

The more polished, better looking cousin of Counter Strike, Condition Zero is the version of Counter Strike to not only play, but for developers to beat.  The addition of the much-required shield has an important balance factor; it counters the usage of the AWP.

The hit detection is once again, superior to CSGO, much like the previous Counter Strike, and the aim for the weapons isn't cartoonishly exaggerated where you have weapons like the M249 and the shotgun being actually viable.

Online play is head-and-heels above CSGO's.  In CSGO you feel like everythings a waste of time unless you're playing in competitive matches, while in CSCZ, and CS, pubs rule the game (like all classic multiplayer games).  I can't say how sweet it was when someone who was clearly a CSGO player who looks like he just started playing CSCZ, killed a team mate to defuse the bomb himself, and then got perma-banned by the moderator.  It was also the moment where I realized that the behaviors of players in CSCZ compared to CSGO are not just different, but the CSGO behavior is just fucking awful and counter-intuitive to team work.  You have people competing fo points to get a higher rank quicker so that they can unlock more skins, which they can trade/sell for a hugely over-priced margin (some skins being worth more than CSGO itself).

I guess it just goes to show that if you're someone who actually wants to enjoy playing the game, CSCZ is the game for you.  CSGO is just another "competitive" game with nothing more to it than popularity, driven mostly by the market economy the game has created for itself, suffering the same fate as TF2 and Dota 2.

I would recommend CSCZ over CSGO any day and not because it's what I used to play (since I have none, as I barely ever touched it for more than a few minutes back in the day), but because the balance, design, and overall aesthetic is just so much more satisfying and fun to experience compared to more modern online FPS games.

[h1]OVERALL SCORE[/h1]
Recommended

[h1]REPLAY VALUE[/h1]
Very high

This review is for the deleted scenes. Scroll down a bit more to read the review for the released gane,

It's interesting that they had a story mode for this game. I've already played the non-steam version of this game and the game looks unchanged. All the campaign seem to be how I remembered it as. But nevertheless, no idea why this part of the game was removed but hey, more hours to be spent on it!

The AI are the same from Half Life. Sound appears to be stereo only, and was able to play this game at 1080p, didn't have much settings customization as Half Life 2 and other games that run on the source engine though.

But yeah.....according to steam, it apparently took me a good 8 hr to finish the entire deleted scenes campagin on medium difficulty. I enjoyed it, though not as much as I did when I first played it, which was from the non-steam version of this, but good nostalgia playback though. I did idle for bit, whilst on breaks (dinner, lunch, etc,.) so it didn't actually take me 8 hrs, would have been 6 hrs as apparently I've clocked in about 2 hrs before I started from scratch, perhaps I was idling or already did the entire thing on easy or something before.....can't remember...but I've definitely now completed the game on medium difficulty - oh and I didn't even have to cheat either! I remember raging on the last level at the helicopter part so I  typed in god mode and sat back and relaxed.....hahahahaha, perhaps I was playing it on hard mode before? Because I did remember it being a bit harder last time I played it so maybe I did....or maybe I was just playing like shit before,......? Hahahahaha

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

As for the release CS CZ game, there is also a campaign mode you can play, the AI in this is much more advance and smarter and not so dumb as the ones from the deleted scenes. However in this version, you get to spend points to recruit members onto your CS team. They also have stats that you may base your picks on. The difficulty ranges from Easy to Expert(when you first start it), so once you finish up on easy(or you can go straight to expert and work your way down to easy?), you get a badge on that and you can start on Normal and finish that and get a badge on that diff and so on.

Once in, the gameplay is similar to that to the multiplayer of the usual CS deathmatch, except that you are given objectives to do and you must carry those out in order to complete the map and then move on to the next until you finish the entire thing on whatever difficulty you chose and the rinse and repeat on a different difficulty if you so choose or if you''re bored from it, you can just start messing around in mutliplayer.

Other than the single player campagin mode, there's also a multiplayer game mode, if you've played CS 1.6, this is what this game mode is pretty much. CS team kill Ts and rescure hostages/defuse bombs whilst Ts kill CSs and plant C4s/hold hostages from CS team. There are many maps, more if you choose to add some custom made ones.

The graphics, well...the non-steam version I used to spend hrs and hrs on as a kid, looks very much more like CS 1.6 but with the usual CZ upgraded stuff and new additions too. [strike]In this steam version, the graphics look like they're from the deleted scenes.[/strike] I swear it was last time, just did another sample run and no it looks nothing like the graphics from the deleted scenes Not sure why the different graphics between the non-steam version and the steam version, but I guess this team version would also have bug/glitch fixes that the non-steam version doesn't have. But I'm sure if you google, there would probably be some offline patches you can run to update the non-steam version as well...Also there are a couple or so new things in the steam version vs. the non-steam version I used to play on as well. I must have got the first release of CZ where it looked very much more similar to the CS 1.6 now than the steam version of itself currently.

Also, vs. CS 1.6, this has bots! and not those dumb ones from Half Life! :P But of course that doesn't really add if you're not much of a PVB (Player Vs Bot) kind of person.

Audio is usual, stereo only, not much else to say here...there are other options like change to high quality or low quality sound.

Yeah, not sure what else I should say about it. Oh, they added another class to both CT and Ts which wasn't there in the non-steam version I used to play. And the crosshair mechanics are different too. But I suppose this version, at least the steam version of CS CZ is like a downgraded version of CSS, in my opinion from what I've just experienced and I've played CSS before this steam version of CS CZ and it's significantly different to the non-steam version of CS CZ I used to play.

==================================
Played on "The Beast"
i7-3970x, 64GB RAM, 2x GTX 770s 4GB VRAM, WinXP x64 Pro, 4x SSDs, 2x HDDs, Rampage IV Extreme, X-Fi Titanium Fatal1ty Pro, custom water loop, 2x BD-drives, TJ07-BW, 850W PSU, and many fans! Resolution: 1920x1080
Just classic :D

This is stupidly frustrating. Easy is.. well... easy. Insultingly easy, that is. Medium and Hard? Almost impossible. Enemies fire the moment the see a single pixel of you, and rules constantly change about what surfaces you can and cannot shoot through. Ammo is rediculously scarce, with enemies not dropping a single bullet for you to pick up. 
Don't get me started on the fucking enemy weapons. They range from pistolarios, shotgun fuckers, assault rifles, MP9 users, and snipers. On medium and hard difficulty, they all do rediculous amounts of damage. Especially shotguns. Man, do I hate shotguns. The point of a shotgun is to do heavy damage at close range, right? In this game, enemy shotguns shave of 30 HP on Hard or Medium when in close range, and they take off 10-25 HP AT ANY DISTANCE ON HARD OR MEDIUM! I frequently found myself dying due to these fucking shotgun assholes; if not losing tons of health within seconds. It would be manageable if they had the pmup action, but no! They are equipped with the AUTOMATIC SHOTGUN! Your best hope is to stun them or get an instant kill... But wait! This game feels the need to treat NPC's like players and give them lots of fucking health! Enemies rarely flinch, and even more rarely die with headshots. The only 3 weapons that gaurantee an instakill with a headshot are the magnum sniper rifle, deagle, and LAW bazooka.

This game can also be stupidly buggy. Aside from enemies shooting me through walls and materials I can confirm could not be shot through by the player, I experienced a bug that made me quit playing Deleted Scenes(Minor spoiler warning!). During a chase sequence in which you have to capture the bad guy who has a nuke (how predictable), there are segments in which he will stop to order his man to come and assist him. Now during this part, the head honcho cannot be damaged. However, he and his fucking M60 can damage the player and slice off a nice chunk of health. In a hallway, I got sick of him and his goonies' shit, so I threw a grenade that killed all his men but him. Apparently this angered him to the point where he stormed down the stairs and stood defiently in front of me, as if he was about to give me a piece of his mind. Fate smiled upon me it seemed, as it allowed the flinching to work with every bullet I unloaded into his stupid flapping mouth that screamed russian profanities at me. After having exhausted the magazines in all 6 guns (You know how long CS weapons take to reload) that I had, the AI essentially said "Nice job. My turn, faggot" and fired A SINGLE BURST INTO MY FACE... I then quit the game, and have uninstalled it.

Unless you're sadistic, a fan of hardcore twitch shooters, or one of those CS gods, stay away from this.

Synopsis:

[h1]With its extensive Tour of Duty campaign, a near-limitless number of skirmish modes, updates and new content for Counter-Strike's award-winning multiplayer game play, plus over 12 bonus single player missions, Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a tremendous offering of single and multiplayer content. [/h1]

My thoughts regarding Condition Zero are pretty much Identical to the original CS 1.6. This is basically due to both games sharing the same engine, with Condition Zero being different only in the texturing and meshing department. With CS 1.6 showing its age, Condition Zero might be a worth a squirt if your feeling nostalgic. 

Basically once the game Is bought you have to two installation options, Counter Strike Condition Zero and Counter Strike Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes.

[b]Counter Strike Condition Zero:[/b]

This is essentially the CS 1.6 variant of the game which allows for traditional CS 1.6 style online gameplay and a somewhat enjoyable mini campaign which spans across most of the original maps, where objectives are the same as multiplayer however you can build a team for each map with bots of varying skills with more powerful bots costing more resource which you will unlock as you complete the maps. This single player should be avoided since it offers no real value and you are much better off playing on servers with real players.


[b]Counter Strike Condition Zero Deleted Scenes:[/b]

This installation covers the actual single player campaign for Condition Zero. Each theater consists of you playing as a different counter terrorist unit: 

GIGN, GSG-9, SEAL Team 6, SAS and Spetsnaz

You in turn fight againest a variety of different terrorist factions:

Arctic Avengers, Elite Crew, Guerilla Warfare, Phoenix Connexion and Midwest Militia.

I rather enjoyed the single player campaign since it deployed a large variety of maps and global locations ranging from fetid jungles to war ravaged cities. Most missions have a pre deployment briefing but these just offer simple intel and not much else. Most missions range from hostage rescue, bomb disarmament to assassinations. In most respects the campaign is somewhat reminiscent to Call of Duty MW which often puts you in the boots of a different soldier serving under a different army.

In conclusion CS CZ is worth your time if you are a hardcore C.S 1.6 fan like myself. It is pretty much HD 1.6 with a enjoyable single player campaign.

Holy cow.
I'm not really sure how to start this review because I started off with the game being a crappy and basically I had boughten a basically different modeled CS-1.6, lets get down to it?

Multiplayer:
I didn't get to play too much of this, mainly because there are not too many servers with players, I didn't get to play a few skrim matches though, fun stuff, basically 1.6 (I believe 1.5 was out when this game was available) I don't have too much to talk about here, maps are somewhat different from the original texture wise, there are a few added items like a shield w/ sidearm.

Single player:
Mainly the reasons why I was interested in this was because of talk of a campaign, when you buy the game, you will find two games in your library, Counter strike condition zero and counter strike condition zero 'Deleted scenes'. 

Huh, deleted scenes, does not sound that interesting in a game without a story, sounds like something a goldsrc modder would use, open up the regular game to come to a familiar titlepage, when you open up the single player, you are only basically taken to what operations we get in csgo, killing boats for challenges... No story, no different maps, same deal with increasing difficulty, there are plenty of these missions because each difficulty you can select has missions of their own. This was very disappointing and was not worth the $2 price tag, I groaned to myself and probably played five missions before giving up. It was the silliest idea ever. Looking at the games screenshots, there looked like there would at least be  some characters and an okay plot! But sadly what we were given was this "Bot killer simulation 1997". I was greatly disappointed and would have been bothered even more if I had bought this on CD format. Untill. 

The deleted scenes, who would want to go through that? Well I mean I would, I like to see beta content or removed items and such and that's all I was expecting. Most people are not into that, but I installed that puppy anyways, on the title you are given the option to go to a map screen and start a new game. What I saw five hours that night was one of the best games I have experienced in awhile. WE were actually given a story! Well not really, you were basically pulled into a quick briefing and pulled into chaos, my eyes were glued to the screen. Honestly it felt like I was playing a half life game with realistic environment for its time, wait a minute. What's that say on the wikia for CS condition zero? The game had three development teams? The deleted scenes were made by gearbox?!?!? No freaking wonder the missions were awesome, I have poured five hours into the game and I'm not even half way done, there had to be at least 20 missions all taking place in different environments, one moment you are American in an middle eastern city underseige, the next you are shooting your own comrades in an russian mission plant. Literally, this game (deleted scenes) was amazing and I feel that valve really should had reconsidered gearboxes version of the game.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is one of the more intriguing installments of Counter-Strike (Not including CS Neo, CS     Online, and CS Zexon Zombies) Its basically just a single player campaign for Counter-Strike and it shows this in two different fashtions. First there's Condition Zero where you go through Counter-Strikes multiplayer maps pairing up with a group of bots against other bots. The bots AI aren't the worst as they can be useful as depending on there cooperative abilitys, they'll alarm about any incoming enemys. But the bots aren't perfect like how enemie bots will take a couple of seconds that your right in front of them and that they should shoot. Each mission includes its own set of missions that are required to beat before completing the mission like kill a certain number of enemies, rescue a hostage, kill a certain number of enemies with a shotgun, and so on. This also includes multiplayer with the new maps and textures with it, but nowadays its rare to find at least two servers with a decent number of players. However getting the game on steam will give you the original Counter-Strike so its not a huge loss. 

 Then there's Deleted scenes, which was originally Ritual Entertainments idea for Condition Zero. The 18 missions are very Half-Life based with Counter-Strike theming and and assets. Each mission has you going through hoards of terrerosts that act like the military from Half-Life, and complete your objective to complete. The engine has been given some major improvements like enimies having special knockback deaths and high resolution textures. It does show some parts where the games not finished, but it's preety hard to notice. The voice acting can range from mildly cheesy, to chringeworthy with the rediculous accents. Overall, the difficulty can be preety challenging for newcomers, but pros of Counter-Strike shoulden't have much of a problem.

 If you're a fan of booth Half-Life and Counter-Strike, then you should definatly check out Deleted scenes. And Condition Zero is also a great excuse to play Counter-Strike offline, but otherwise you should just play online with the newest installments.

 Final Verdict:

 Condition Zero: 7/10

 Deleted Scenes: 8/10

[h1] Is Counter-Strike: Global Offensive worth to buy? [/h1] - [b] Yes! [/b]

[i]Even if you are not really into the shooter genre, CS:GO is probably the best game to get things started. Not only does it have a huge variety in game modes and also community mods, it is the best game to reach a decent aim you can profit from in other shooters.[/i]

[h1] What mods can you play in CS:GO? [/h1]

[i]There are plenty, the mods variety is huge. I really have not played a lot of mods, since I am more into the competetive Counter-Strike, but I for example played zombie-mods, hunger-games-mods, surf maps (with and without rpg mod), bunnyhop and awp_noscope. [b]BUT[/b] there are many more mods to that.

[h1] What are the key aspects of the game? [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Casual: Bomb/Hostage Maps
    [*] Demolition: Bomb Maps
    [*] Gungame
    [*] Deathmatch
    [*] Competitive (Matchmaking)
[/list]

[b][u]Casual[/u][/b]
[i]In casual play mode, you will basicly spawn every round (1 life per round) and fight agains the opposite team (10 vs 10). You can play either bomb maps (where you have to plant/defuse a bomb) or hostage maps (where you have to defend hostages or rescue them). You can choose between the official competetive map pool (which does not include hostage maps) or reserve group (where you have both types). You will usually spawn with kevlar+helmet, and defuse kit (not on hostage maps).[/i]

[b][u]Demolition[/u][/b]
[i]In demolition play mode you play 5v5 on small bomb maps and you also have only one live. You spawn with kevlar+helmet and a weapon that will change ever round where you have killed an enemy (+grenades if you make multiple kills the same round).[/i]

[b][u]Gungame[/u][/b]
[i]In gungame play mode you will play 10v10 on small gungame maps, where you have to kill an enemy with a pre-set weapon (everyone starts with the same weapons). Once you killed two enemies, you will progress to the next weapon. You win after you reached knife level and killed a player with the "golden knife". [b] Note:[/b] Every player must go through the same exact weapons to win and the weapons are randomized.[/i]

[b][u]Deathmatch[/u][/b]
[i]In deathmatch play mode you will play 10v10 on the same maps as on casual play mode. You will spawn with the weapons you choose through the buymenu (kevlar+helmet are already purchased for you). You have multiple lives and can always change your weapons after you died. One game ends after 10 Minutes and the winner with the highest score wins. You gain points by killing enemies or assist in killing them OR by killing chickens (which gives 1 point only per chicken).[/i]

[b][u]Competitive (Matchmaking)[/u][/b]
[i]In competitive play mode, you will basicly play like casual but different. You will play 5v5 with people of your same skillgroup on the same maps as on casual (You can choose specific maps!!). If you want to get serious with Counter-Strike this will be the game mode you are looking for, BUT keep in mind that you need a lot of knowledge about the game for this type of play mode (and you need at least community rank 3 to play competitive).[/i]


[b]>> Note: [/b] [spoiler] Keep in mind, that the game changes a lot, so do the game modes. I wrote this 29.01.2016, so any changes after I probably did not predict ;) [/spoiler]

[code] So all in all Counter-Strike is at the moment my favorite shooter, since all others (even new ones like "Rainbow Six Siege") are not as much fun as Counter-Strike is. Especially the competitive aspect of the game is way better than others. [/code]

Condition Zero comes with 2 modules:
[b]1. Condition Zero (CZ)[/b] - Provides a slightly different MP experience to that of CS1.6, mostly graphical changes with a few gameplay changes. Also has a player vs. bots singleplayer mode, which is essentially just multiplayer with bots instead of humans, but with added objectives to make it a bit more difficult.
[b]2. Deleted Scenes[/b] - A scripted single player campaign similar to something you'd see in Quake or Unreal Tournament.

For simplicity's sake I'll go over the changes CZ introduces, just keep in mind this isn't something I've thoroughly researched or anything of the sort, just what I know from playing multiple versions of CS for around a decade now. If you don't know the core gameplay of Counter Strike to understand these changes... well then go buy 1.6 and then consider picking up CZ.

[u][b]Changes[/b][/u]
[list]
[*]Lighting - Lighting is updated to be more smooth and natural, shadows and darkness is generally not as harsh and saturation looks much more natural, in my opinion this is a good change both aesthetically and gameplay wise, excluding the saturation change. I would prefer deeper saturation to make things easier to see and more colorful. You can somewhat counteract this by using a setting called digital vibrance in the NVidia control panel. If you have an AMD card they have a similar setting, though I do not know what it is called.
[*]Gun Models - Gun models are updated to look more realistic and metallic, most have changed color palettes or just added color in general and a select few have new animation, mostly just moving parts, for instance the bolt on the FAMAS/Clarion now moves when firing. Also the knife has a new animation which I think looks awful. Overall this is a positive change though.
[*]Character Models - Character models are completely changed. They are higher resolution but in my opinion the new models look lame in comparison to the 1.6 models.
[*]Textures - Pretty much every texture on the maps have been changed and made higher resolution. For the most part the changes are welcome to me, though they do effect the visual feel of the maps a little. I think I'd consider this a positive change.
[/list]

Outside of the additions I mentioned at the beginning of the review, that's really the extent of the changes. Mostly all visual changes.

So the question is... do these changes warrant a purchase? Not in the slightest. For various reasons, if you're buying this for multiplayer, you're better off just playing 1.6.

In my eyes, the only reason to pick up CZ is for the Deleted Scenes. However I don't believe Deleted Scenes is actually worth the $10 CZ goes for.

Basically the campaign is a collection of missions with no overarching story or really anything of interest in the way of plot. They are all linear. They take place in different locales around the world. They are all played on the CT side, although the factions will differ. They offer a very small amount of puzzle solving. They have boss fights. They have forced stealth sections.

Here is what I dislike about Deleted Scenes:
[list]
[*]Linear as hell, wouldn't be a problem if it didn't give you the illusion of choice with multiple hallways and doors just leading to dead ends, often without an item reward.
[*]Secrets are hidden pretty lazily and without thought, even when you go out of your way to look for them you probably won't find a majority of them, and when you do find them, they are mostly useless.
[*]Enemy placement has very little thought, often times they are placed in dark corners or closed doors. If they are placed somewhere that requires a scripted animation, they are completely invincible until the animation plays out.
[*]Boss battles are awful, all of them but the final 2 bosses are insanely easy. The 2nd to last boss is just a bullet sponge that can take literally several AK clips to the head and numerous grenades before he dies, but he can kill you just as quick as any other enemy, not to mention he's surrounded by 2 shot kill snipers AND you are on a timelimit to kill him. Just awful. The last boss is actually pretty good and a satisfying finale, but he also has 2 bullet sponge troops that will kick your ass if you don't cheese them somehow.
[*]The game is incredibly easy, even on hard. The only time I was challenged was the aforementioned bosses and when I had to escort the retarded AI.
[*]Escorting AI is just plain awful.
[*]The most fun guns run out of ammo quickly.
[*]You can get trapped by AI very easily.
[*]Some puzzles are very difficult not because they require you to use your brain but rather because they require you to go around knifing random things (MULTIPLE TIMES) until something breaks, and it's rarely obvious what you should be attacking.
[*]Allied AI is useless
[*]Enemy AI is braindead. Most of the time they just stand in one spot and shoot at you, never trying to get to a better position.
[*]The forced stealth is AWFUL. It's dreadfully boring and boils down to crouching behind a box, waiting for enemy to turn back, moving to next box, waiting for enemy to turn back, rinse, repeat, rinse, repeat, over and over again and it always left me wanting to just quit playing it was so boring and uninspired. More guns, less sneaking. PLEASE.
[/list]

With that said, I think Deleted Scenes is a fairly average FPS when it's at it's best. When at it's worst it is just plain bad. Unless you're a die hard CS fan that wants to experience it, there are so many other games to spend your time and money on.

Oh and I didn't even mention the fact that this came out in 2004. Half Life 2 came out 7 months after this. Take a second to think about that.

Counter Strike Condition Zero is the sequel to the original Counter Strike and now it includes a Single Player Campaign, so let's take a look shall we ?

When I mentioned that this game has a single player campaign, I didn't mean a story mode. The single player campaign is a very short bundle of missions where you have few objectives during each missions. Like rescue hostages, defuse bombs and take out terrorists with a specific weapon.

The missions are incredibly short and you can finish all 12 within 2 hours. 

The AI will make the hostage missions a living hell. Once the round starts the AI are on the hunt to find any enemy player on the field and will not help you so don't expect any help from the AI. Getting a hostage to a drop off, before your team kills the entire enemy team.

The gameplay is not much different from the original Counter Strike so don't expect a major change.

Now for the feature everyone cares. THE MULTIPLAYER. It's almost completely dead. I had trouble finding a match and when I did get into a full lobby match, I felt bored and it's not as good as the original Counter Strike.

This game is not good, but it's not horrible either. The campaign is short and not worth the money and the multiplayer is slowly dying out. In the end only get this if you're a hardcore fan, otherwise get any other game in the franchise.

Final Rating:
6/10 - Okay

Back when Counter-Strike tried a campaign mode. 

The game is a series of mini-objectives against bots on various maps, while the Deleted Scenes extra is a full blown CS campaign with many elements of the online game being brought in with solo FPS gameplay mechanics (such as equipment) to make a fun and hilarious game (the stereotypical russian accents make me laugh every time). 

The multiplayer part is quite similar to the original CS but with slightly better textures.

Overall, this isn't a game for people who like CS:GO, it's more for the fans of old school FPS games and OG Counter-Strikers. I do recommend it nonetheless, but keep in mind that the game is over 10 years old.

Counter-Strike 1.6: The Phantom Pain is a Single Player First-Person Shooter that takes you through the lives of numerous Counter-Terrorism units. 

The story is linear and all counter-terrorism units depicted are not connected. Most gameplay is a tutorial for a mundane version of VR missions, a prime example being your very first sneeki beeki-like S.A.S mission, where you, the main unoriginal protagonist of Dissappointment Ops 3, is instructed to infiltrate and exfiltrate from Prague or something to stop a train from going boom and to locate Metal Gear Supercomputer.

Ah, Condition Zero. The red-headed stepchild of the Counter-Strike world.
Pity that, it's a really good game.   Since I have a damaged computer at the moment, with limited 3d accel.  I can't
run Source-engine games.   This one uses the original Half-Life/Counter-Strike mod's Goldsrc.

This version is a bit nicer than CS 1.6, and is quite a bit more polished.   There is some activity on the servers, if you're into multiplayer.  The maps are quite nice-looking for a old quake-engine game.  The included versions of Cobblestone and Aztec look great are a blast to play.

I got it as part of a bundle, and it's been one of the best buys I've made on Steam.   Absolutely recommend.
(don't get me wrong, CS:GO is great, but don't pass this one up because it's old).   For n00bs, its a great intro to the
CS world.
