Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is basically 'just' a slightly improved version of Counter-Strike 1.6.
If you happen to be unfamiliar with the CS games series, the concept of the idea is simple.
Players play against eachother in online matches, choosing to play either a terrorist or a counter terrorist. The team that completes their objective or eliminates the opposing team wins.

Counter-Strike is a fairly old game, built on the Half-Life engine, that became extremely popular years ago and is one of the best known shooter games (series) ever made, alongside eg. Unreal Tournament, Doom, Call of Duty and other such classics. And thanks to a large community, there is a huge amount of custom content available for these games. As long as you have some people to play with, it's hard to get bored in the world of Counter-Strike. And Condition Zero is no exception to this.

What most people familiar with the series can tell you is that while CZ is a decent game, it is highly underrated compared to both older and newer installments. Why is this? Well there may be several reasons, but the easiest way to put it is this: it's the middle child of CS games.
CS purists will prefer to play the original Counter-Strike, versions 1.5 and 1.6. And the newer games draw a big crowd because they're flashier and fancier. Since Condition Zero is situated in between the older 1.6 and Counter-Strike: Source (which started using the new Source engine), it doesn't get much of the attention it deserves, in my opinion. However, I can tell you that it is definitely a game worth playing if you're into slightly older shooting games.
--------------------
More information...

-=Gameplay=-
Q: How is it played?
A: After joining a server, you have four options. You can join one of two teams, you can let the game decide for you which team you'll join or you can spectate the game, basically existing as a ghost, watching others play. You can play as a counter-terrorist operative or as a terrorist. The moment you spawn (when a new round starts, or within seconds of a round starting) you're able to open a menu that allows you to buy weapons, protection and various equipment. If the round has not yet started, you are unable to move. If you picked a team seconds after the round started, you will instantly be able to move. Everyone spawns with a basic pistol and a little bit of money. Once you're able to move, your goal is to move out of the spawn area and attempt to complete any of your objectives to earn more money and to win the round. When the round is over, everyone respawns in the same area as last round and the game is repeated. If you died, you'll start over with your gear, otherwise you keep what you had before. You will keep playing rounds until the server changes to a different map (level), usually after 20 minutes. There are a couple of standard game types, determined not by server options but by the type of map that is being played. The three main types are bomb defusal, hostage rescue and assassination. There are other types, but those are only featured in custom maps. Completing just ONE of the listed objectives will win a team the round and earn additional money for all of it's members.

*Bomb defusal
-Terrorists must plant a bomb in one of two possible bomb sites and make sure it explodes. (the team still wins if the bomb explodes while all it's members are dead)
-Terrorists must kill all counter-terrorists.
-Counter-terrorists have to kill all terrorists.
-Counter-terrorists must defuse the bomb if it is planted. (the team still wins if all CT players are killed after the bomb has been defused)

*Hostage rescue
-Terrorists must stay alive and keep the counter-terrorists from rescuing all living hostages.
-Terrorists have to kill all the counter-terrorists.
-Counter-terrorists have to rescue all the living hostages.
-Counter-terrorists have to kill all the terrorists.

*Assassination
-Terrorists must keep the VIP from the rescue zone while staying alive themselves.
-Terrorists have to kill the VIP.
-Counter-terrorists have to kill all the terrorists.
-Counter-terrorists have to get the VIP player (picked at random) to the rescue zone within a specific time limit.

-=Experience=-
CZ is an old game. It runs on an old engine. It looks, feels and sounds old. Quite simply, if you can't stand anything but HD graphics, realistic water effects, decent ragdoll physics and other such things, this is not the game for you. That said, there's enough to keep it interesting. Weapons all sound and behave differently and it takes practice to get good with each (type). The maps are diverse enough in types of environment. It's worth mentioning that in a game like this, the maps are relatively small, forcing players into confrontation to keep the game going at a decent pace. Because the action is usually fast and intense, you will usually be too distracted to really notice what your surroundings sound or look like. For some interesting experiences, try a few custom maps! Made by members of the community, you'll find the craziest levels. Themed ones, maps based on popular films or tv series and just insane maps that seem to be all over the place. Shake things up by customising your game and trying out new things.

-=Technical, controls, etc.=-
Again, CZ is a fairly old game. As long as you can get the game started, you're not going to have issues with this. It's pretty stable and even if you do suffer a bug or error, you will easily find a solution for it through Google, thanks to the large amount of players who have played this and other CS/HL games over the years.
It's extremely small compared to modern games and will take up very little space, even if you start adding custom content to it and customising it further. For anyone with a normal internet connection you can download this game very quickly.
Controls are what you're used to in PC shooters. Pretty intuitive and unsurprising. Thankfully, if there's anything that is not working how you want it to, you can change it. Controls can be changed in the options menu and if there's anything not listed in there, you can always find a way to fix it by using the developers console. This may sound complicated if you're a casual PC user/gamer, but again, the community has made sure that there's enough information for you to figure things out without spending a lot of time doing research and basically missing out on actually playing and enjoying the game.
Besides regular user controls, there are also enough options and commands by default for server owners (you, if you're hosting a game) to keep control of the match. These can be expanded upon greatly by installing an administrative modification on your game (server) and again, there's enough information for anyone with limited computer knowledge to succeed in this endeavour.

Pro's:
-Basically an improved Counter-Strike 1.6
-Extremely and easily customisable with a lot of custom content available
-Easy to learn, hard to master
-Features working bots (not brilliant ones in gameplay, though) and the game can "learn" custom maps and make waypoint files for the CZ bots automatically. They work in multiplayer too
-Comes with Deleted Scenes, separate game on the same engine that has you playing a proper SP campaign, going across the world to stop terrorist activity in scripted missions.

Cons:
-Highly underrated and not well known, will not have as much players as other CS games (best played with friends)
-Somewhat pricey, unless you're planning on playing it a lot, despite the content available and given with just the game itself

------------------------

A "single-player" version of Counter-Strike 1.6 that offers 2 campaigns: Tour of Duty and Deleted Scenes. Deleted Scenes plays more like a conventional single-player FPS while Tour of Duty retains most of the multiplayer experience. It is worth noting that Condition Zero does come with multiplayer matchmaking as well.

Tour of Duty has you play traditional Counter Strike matches on each of the 1.6 maps. To win, you must win at least 3 rounds with a 2 round lead, and complete certain "challenges" including stuff like "Get X kills with [certain weapon]" and "Rescue 4 hostages". Each map you complete gets you a "reputation point" that you can use to choose which bots you want on your team. Each has differing stats (Skill, Co-op, and Bravery), and a different preferred weapon. This creates some fun decision making even before entering a match. Do you make a team with only a few strong, but expensive bots? Or do you get a full team of weaker ones? There are also plenty of tradeoff bots with high stats or weapons, but have notable weaknesses. For example: the "Maverick" bot is the cheapest one with high skill and high bravery, but he also has low co-op, meaning that he'll generally ignore you and do his own thing. Another example is "Alex", who has an AWP, and good skill and co-op, but bad bravery. This means that he will run away from certain situations like 1v1s. While the core that makes 1.6 so beloved is already here, the team-building that Tour of Duty introduces makes this game surprisingly fun for solo play.

Since this runs on CS 1.6, all of the jankiness comes with it. The hostage maps were particularly annoying since you have to somehow get all 4 to follow you back to your spawn without getting stuck on anything for a round win (besides just killing the enemy team, but usually for a map completion one of the challenges will be to rescue 4 total hostages). You also better make sure to buy a defusal kit on defuse maps because your bots won't.

The deleted scenes portion of the game doesn't hold up as well IMO. It plays more like custom Half-Life maps than CS, as you're fighting through linear levels instead of CS matches. There's no overarching story, instead each mission has it's own self-contained "story". Story is a strong word though because for the most part it's just an excuse for you to go somewhere exotic and shoot terrorists in the face. Any sense of grounded realism that the regular CS games portray is completely gone here. The premises of these missions feel much more like B movies with all the cheese that entails. People who enjoy those will likely get a kick out of these missions, but others will be disappointed. 

Another note, playing hard mode isn't fun at all in deleted scenes. Due to your limited health and the unnatural reflexes of the bots, it feels more like a memorization game than anything remotely resembling fair. Also making matters worse is that the second mission is a major difficulty spike for no good reason (the next few levels aren't nearly as bad). I'd only recommend picking hard if A: You want to get really good at CS 1.6 (aiming and reflexes), or B: You're a masochist.

If you're interested in playing CS 1.6, but don't want to deal with people who have been playing 1.6 since 2000, or want to play maps that aren't Dust II, then I recommend this game. I would buy it for the Tour of Duty, but not the Deleted Scenes. You can get an arguably better experience just playing custom Half-Life maps (free downloads online or Sven Coop). Both of Condition Zero's offerings aren't too long, but the bundled CS 1.6 should give you a lot of bang for your buck if you're looking for retro CS.

This game is the successor to the 2000 shooter called Counter-Strike. Now this game was released in 2004 and it came packaged with essentially two games, one being the base game and the other being the deleted content that was created earlier in the development of Condition Zero. Deleted Scenes is basically a Counter-Strike game that focuses on single-player missions loosely tied together. It‚Äôs just like playing Call of Duty or Medal of Honor but in Counter-Strike. The graphics for this game hasn‚Äôt aged well either for both the base game and the deleted scenes. The textures were low res and washed out in some areas. Even back then the graphics didn‚Äôt look good because Half-Life 2 came out not too long later and it looked so much better than this. The music for this game is pretty good though and the gameplay maintaining the routes of the original Counter-Strike. The deleted scenes content is actually pretty damn good to be considered deleted scenes compared to the base game. The base game is just the original Counter-Strike but with bots and more slightly more detail in the environment. Both games are both relatively easy and normal but wait until you get to the sixth tour of duty. OMG is it ever f****** hard! Unlike the previous tour of duties that were relatively easy to get through on normal difficulty this one just spikes the difficulty so high that it will rip your head apart and feed it to you because there are more enemy bots and for some reason they started to have 5x more accuracy and can spot you with eagle eye vision. It‚Äôs just like playing with players that use aim bot and wall hack to some extent because there reaction times on the sixth tour of duty is like 1/10th of a second. If you can get through that last one without cheating on max difficulty than you really deserve a medal. The multiplayer is just like Counter-Strike 1.6 but with slightly better graphics. Now you might be asking is this game worth it? Yes it is so long as you can get it cheap because it‚Äôs neither a good game nor a bad game and is just above the lines of mediocre. The only reason I recommened this game was because of the deleted scenes content. It's acutally quite unique for the series and this is the only game that did it.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a follow up to the original Counter-Strike game. This game was released in 2004, so almost eleven years ago. Condition Zero uses the Half-Life engine. 

What we have here is a CS game which includes a single player mission pack. When it comes to playing Counter-Strike, I am more or less a newb at it. This game gave me the perfect opportunity to learn the guns, maps and mission types without the pressure of feeling like you are letting your team down by sucking. The campaign took me about four hours to complete, but this was only on Normal mode, you can go back and replay the missions on a higher difficulty to eventually work your way up to playing online. 

I also found the squad management system to be a nice little feature which isn't seen in other CS games, at the start of each mission, you can choose which squad members to take with you on the mission, each of the team members have their positive and negative stats so you can really get stuck in with min-maxing them. You start out with three members and you work you way up to having a full blown squad of about eight men. 

On each of the missions you also have to complete specific challenges, these can be goals set around killing a certain amount of people, winning the match in less than ninety seconds, rescuing a specific amount of hostages etc etc. This added a little variety of play, especially the challenges where you have to use a certain weapon in order to complete them. This allowed you to learn how to use other guns effectively rather than sticking with your tried and tested Rifle and Deagle. 

While the graphics do not come close to looking like games we have in the current day, the game still does look nice. I wasn't put off by the dated graphics one bit; I guess that just shows how good the Half Life engine actually is!  

The difficulty levels completely rely on how hard you want to make it. I started out on Normal mode just to get to grips with the game as I am newb like that; but you can work all the way up to playing as if you are in a match online and have the brutally hard experience if you want to. Easy mode is complete walk in the park though, enemies can be standing in front of you for about three seconds before they realize they should shoot you, and even then they spray bullets randomly all around you without actually hitting, so I wouldn't recommend you start out on Easy mode. 

Like I said, the campaign took me about four hours to complete, but there are two or three more difficulty levels to try out, and I can see this adding a lot of variety into the game play, so I can easily see the single player alone taking about twelve hours to complete it fully on all difficulties. 

I found no technical issues what so ever while playing, I would assume all the bugs and niggles would of been ironed out years ago.. 

In conclusion I can easily recommend Counter-Strike: Condition Zero for anyone looking to get into the FPS or CS scene, it will easily give you a worthwhile experience, giving you the opportunity to learn all of the CS maps, guns and game modes in a pressure free environment. 

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Boring... Just boring, since I'm neither a really dedicated CS gamer, nor am I really good at FPS games, maybe I'm not the right to judge.

The AI is not really good, and sometimes buggy, some enemies didn't even bother shooting at me, while other just hat lightning reflexes. That doesn't matter, because even on Medium the enemies bullets don't really do any damage. The same applies to your bullets, but since you got about 2 seconds time to aim, you can simply do all headshots, which kinda works.

Ammunition is always a problem, which adds some kind of difficulty to the game, since you are forced to engage close combat with sniper rifles and long range combats with shotguns, just keep one mag an a long range weapon and it shouldn't be a problem.

The grafics are like Condition Zero grafics, not fancy nowadays, but better than CS1.6 and are well enough.

The main reason I dislike this game is the complete lack of any story. There were some minor "plot" - like parts, where you are told why to go there and kill all those guys, or sometimes sneek past the guards you could easily overwhelm. Another thing is the sometimes really hard to find routes through the level, some pathways are blocked by a locked door, others by invisible walls, and the worst kind are the pathways, which actually are blocked by some kind of fence, which you are supposed to climb over, but you are never given any hint to do that.

All in all it is a training program for CS: Condition Zero and maybe some other counter strike games, but does not really have any motivational aspects for me.

For some reason I really really like the campaign of Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes. I think it's because every mission takes place in a new environment with different people and everytime the plot seems to include a ton of action-movie tropes. The multiplayer is dead and the singleplayer for the regular game sucks, but I'd still get this game if only for the deleted scenes.

This is the same game as Counter-Strike, except it includes single-player mode, slight graphical tweaks, and new maps. I mostly play it for the single-player mode, as the effectiveness of the AI makes it for a really fun and engaging experience for a while. Hardly anyone plays the multiplayer (as most players either play 1.6 or Source). But within its lengthy development time, all the developers did significantly was add bots to an already made game. You can't help but feel disappointed, but nevertheless, the game is included with your purchase of 1.6 (which is worth a purchase) and for that, I recommend it.

The unwanted, unadored and underappreciated installment of the Counter-Strike franchise. The single player story campaign is decent for it's time but the bot matches with objectives are a woeful and misguided attempt to mimick  multiplayer. The game lacks the purity of 1.6, the innovation of Source and the great facility of Global Offensive's competitive matchmaking and yet there is still a lot to be said for Condition Zero. It is, at its core, Counter-Strike after all. The game is still trundling along in 2015 thanks to some dedicated, and often small, communities.  You will also find a great number of maps which are unique to this version of Counter-Strike.

This game is all about the mission and the offline campaign that was created with it, called the "Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes". It was way easier than 1.6, headshots and spray kills happens way easier than in 1.6, and whereas some spam points has been removed in the old maps (and in the added CZ maps), it doesn't really change the layout all that much. It's still the same game - just easier, imo. 

I don't recommend it, since the campaign is dull and boring, gameplay answers to 1.6, just easier, as previously mentioned, and lastly, the "Call of Duty" offline bot campaign is so boring and repetitive, you might want to just beat expert, never to come back. It's that terrible. 

Buy 1.6 instead if you want the game in it's entirety, because CZ, while Source added some new elements and better graphics, is just a blatant copy with extra features thrown in there, for people who doesn't care.

CZDS is the franchise's first and only take on single-player campaigns, and it turns out pretty well! It's definitely a fresh new take on the game when it came out over ten years ago, and it still is today.

Although most campaigns feels like your usual run and shoot, the pacing is quite balanced with a few puzzle and hostage/defusal/boss shootout battle scenarios insterspread to break the monotony. The maps are also well-made.

A few downsides: the NPC's aiming sometimes feels inhuman, and the game incorporates a few stereotypes which are not to my liking.

Huh... I always assumed this game injected some sort of Rainbow Six-ish story into Counter-Strike, if you figured the same then you'd be wrong too! :P ...Instead the game simply leads you through 18 maps of CS each with a set of challenges. In general the challenges are nothing special, on Normal difficulty they keep engagements from seeming too repetitive, while on Expert they can potentially extend your playtime (for better or for worse). The only bummer thing about the difficulty levels is that they are tied to the campaign which you start, not the individual missions, so choose wisely. Unfortunately the game only lets you play as counter-terrorists, including terrorist challenges would have made it feel more complete. In it you get to assemble your own team but choices are shallow, consequenceless, and thus meaningless. The bots aren't impressive by far, but they get the job done. Oddly the game was surprisingly buggy on my Windows XP machine, but it worked perfectly on Windows 8. So that's it, classic counter-strike, against bots, plus challenges. It's a shame they hadn‚Äôt created a narrative to interestingly drive you through the maps, as I mistakenly imagined; or devised a more complicated and meaningful team building and progression system. As it turned out though, I just can't think of any reason to recommend it, other than if you're stuck on a craptop and really, really, need to scratch your classic CS itch.

It's like Counter Strike and Call of Duty had a baby, except whichever was the mother did dope during the pregnancy.

In other words, it's not very good.

Still, it's not quite horrible. You can still enjoy it. I certaintly am. Just not that much.

It's a mission-by-mission game with overly linear levels. Doesn't sound terrible, does it? Not very Counter-Strikey, but not terrible, either. The real problem is the combat. It does the Counter-Strike thing where your guns are only acccurate for the first shot, but now they do a lot less damage than they did in the original game, making combat a somewhat frustrating ordeal. It takes way too long to kill people, which, in a series about killing people as effeciently as possible, kinda messes with the experience.

Like I said, it's not horrible, but it just isn't Counter-Strike. I'll still reccomend it, because there isn't anything inherently wrong with the game. It just wasn't what I was expecting from a Counter-Strike game.

Counter Strike: Condition Zero is a great game. For a game that was released on the GoldSrc engine the graphics are not that bad. Don't get me wrong they are still outdated but they were pretty impressive for its time. This game has basiclly everything the original Counter Strike had and much more. For starters there is the tour of duty mode which is a singeplayer campaign (NO STORY) where you go around famous counter strike map and have to complete objects such as defuse a bomb or rescue hostages. You will also be given mini challenges to complete in that mission (Challenges change depending on what difficulty you select) Along with that you can also download extra 3rd Party Campaigns made by players around the world. Now we move on to Counter Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes and this is actually a seperate game that games with the base game and CS: CZDS is also a singleplayer campaign mode but unlike the tour of duty campaign mode this is actually more of a missions because your not playing clasic counter strike game modes but are rather faced with what appears to be Half-Life singleplayer with counter strike elements. And unlike classic counter strike you can't buys weapons instead you have to find and pick up weapons as you go alone and while it may stray far from the classic Counter Strike Formula you will find that it still actually feels like a actualy counter strike game while at the same time give a quite refreshing start to the game. In the end I would reccomend CS: CZ to old CS fans and even new comers as this is a great game and still has a large community to this day.
You have no friends? You have a bad pc? You are are socially awkward? Then this game is just for you!!!

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero was and still is the best FPS for me. To me, it is better than COD and far more entertaining (as you can see in my hours spent in it). It has many servers which have many active players still (to this day) and their servers contain the default gamemode + many different modded versions such as zombies and whatnot. It is pretty similar to CS 1.6 but features improved graphics, a campaign and bots in Singleplayer. You will not regret buying this game. Do not judge it by its graphics but instead by its gameplay. Remember, if you don't like the default gameplay there are still MANY modded servers for you to play on! Also, it doesn't have a case opening simulator so you don't have to worry about wasting your money on gun designs and people judging you by which gun designs you have.

Score: 10/10

Counter Strike: Condition Zero comes with two games:
1. Condition Zero
2. Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes

1. Condition Zero
Basically Counter Strike 1.6 but with improved graphics and the addition of bots. The bots are amazing considering when this game was released (they're still inferior to human players). In addition, the bots are a great way for beginners to learn about the game in a more relaxed environment. There is also a singleplayer Tour of Duty, which is basically regular counter strike missions against bots, but with additional challenges (example: kill 3 enemies with a sniper rifle). Sadly, the Tour of Duty missions are Counter-Terrorist only. There are no Terrorist missions.

2. Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes
This is a singleplayer game. It uses the same weapons and game mechanics as Condition Zero, but with some additions, including the awsome fiber optic camera. Level design is one of Deleted Scenes' greatest strengths. The AI is passable. The story is where it fails, in that each mission is its own self-contained story with practically no connecting elements. I suspect you don't even play as the same person in each mission. Immersion takes a serious hit because of this. It helps to pretend you are playing as the same person. I recommend Adrian Shephard before Black Mesa.

I had a lot of fun playing Condition Zero and Deleted Scenes. I highly recommend these games as well as any other Counter Strike game (or any game by Valve for that matter). By the way, check out the first screenshot on the store page. Really take a close look at the plane...

Once again, the AI needs polishing for todays standards, but the enviroment still does its job even to today by giving you a slight unsettling feeling as you battle enemies. Deleted Scenes campaign is SINGLEPLAYER so you can play Counter-Strike offline, which is cool as hell in my opinion. Counter-Strike campaign offline. However, just like every other CS game you probably need experience with the FPS genre. Don't let easy mode fool you because it is really tough. Any CS fan will love CZ.

CS just like 1.6 but... with small map changes and... same shit all over again...
EXCEPT: great awesome singleplayer campaign
These 80 hours i played this game was 95% spent on single player campaign, which gives unique experience of small missions besides the match. There are 18 maps to play on those campaign (classics like dusts or aztec but also forgotten maps like chateau). Games are pretty much about getting better score, just like in any other CS with some changes:
- Teammates Selection - Before the match starts, you get an option to choose up to 5 teammates. Each teammate costs points, which you get for winning the maps. Each bot is prefering different weapon, has different skill level, differently play as team, different bravery. So if you are playing map like aztec, you should get some snipers and on office get some guys with higher teamplay skills.
- Mini-Objectives - While you play the match, you have usually 3 main mini-missions to finish during the match. Easier ones are like to get few kills with specific weapon, harder are to kill flash-blinded enemy. Sometimes you will have to kill two guys with pistol and survive the round, one of the hardest is even to kill an enemy with knife. To win the match, you have to finish all those objectives and be 2 wins ahead of terrorists. However, if you let them be 2 wins ahead, you loose and you can start all objectives over.

Campaign is only playable as Counter-Terrorists, but there are a lot of downloadable campaigns, you can even easily make your own with your own bots and custom maps.

+++ Single Player Campaign - you wont find anything like this in any other CS
+- Its pretty old game, so graphics is just fine.
- Forget multiplayer, i guess its not alive in this game

This was my very first Steam game. I never liked first-person shooters until this game. Call of Duty was unheard of. This is where it was at for first-person shooters and player vs. player. Simplistic in play, I have put in many hours playing this game. I know there are newer Counter-Strike games out now, but coming back to play this game takes me back. The offline mode was a good place to practice, because I would get owned big time online with real players. People had a lot of free time to play this game and time to get really good. After a while I got the hang of it and became pretty good online. I wasn't the best, because there was always someone better. Using a headset was new to me. It really made things a lot better and I only bought a headset for this game but it was worth it. If you like this game, Counter-Strike: Source has better graphics and gameplay, but this game will run pretty decent on slower computers. I don't like Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. I have a gaming computer but for some reason my graphics card doesn't like the game anyway.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is the first official sequel to mod Counter-Strike, released in retail in 2004. It was pretty much same Counter-Strike on same engine and minimal changes when it comes to multiplayer experience, but it had more to often to solo players, with addition of bots and "Deleted Scenes" pack of single-player missions.

Now, for multiplayer community... Is as good as ever. While it's not on the level of Counter-Strike 1.6, you will still be able to find few almost-full servers, whetever it's yet another De_Dust2 map or some server that actually rotates maps. Just more smaller tighter community. BUT it's kinda way too high-skilled by now for newbies to be able to enter in easily.

So, when it comes to the main, expected, multiplayer part of the game, it didn't recieve many changes. Explosive grenades are stronger. Hostages are a bit more realistical. The end.
Oh, and you will ntoice that graphics got a small boost, as far as HL1 engine goes ("GldSrc"). Models got more detail to them. Few tweaks here and there. Maps are much interesting as far as graphical design goes. If you are going to play de_dust2 non-stop then better do it at the less bland one.
And yes, I don't really like Counter-Strike realistical gameplay much here either.

Now, for single-player, you finally get some bots to play with. Which are less frustating for new people than online play and helps to hone aiming skills as well better. Though, while they navigate through default maps quite nicely, they don't always make best decision. As a protip, always send them a voice command to stick together, team. They also try not to steal your fun of defusing bomb, waiting for commander to do it, even if said commander is in opposite end of map. Yes, it's a flaw.
And like Quake 3 Arena and UT, CZ single player consist of repeated matches with bots, as you will progress through trio of maps, being able to pick less and less stupid teammates over time, always being on side of Counter-Terrorists. And on each map, you have to have more than 2 wins over score of Terrorist team and have to complete each of three objectives, which go like "rescue <x> hostages", "kill <x> amount of Terrorists yourself", "finish some round in <x> time" and "kill <x> terrorists with <y> weapon".  So, fun for a while, but more of "just so something was there".

And now for Deleted Scenes. This is what Counter-Strike: Condition Zero was supposed to be at some point, a full-blown single-player campaign. It was "cancelled" once Valve saw magazines giving it low ratings to preview, just to have it put along as bonus into final game. All just to get low ratings once again due to being "more of same". Deleted Scenes had 12 missions in retail release, with Steam version adding 6 more that you can select anytime from World Map.

Now, Deleted Scene is a mix of good and bad. The excellent level design and repetive core gameplay.
First, good things. Level design is quite good one. You will have to take control of unnamed heroes of counter-terrorist operations all over the world, with missions having great variety, with enough lenght to keep you playing, having to stop terrorists from taking over nuke in snowy part of Russia, defending yourself in Arabain town or fighting your way through the jungles. Seriously, some of the missions just have a bit of that scripted hollywood love that would make them worthy of being in Call of Duty and alikes, quite epic! Levels themselves are also build with knowledge of pacing and a bit of exploration, albeit linear.
And it really tries to push GldSrc engine! In order to make it look like it's capable of more than expected, developers made a lot of animations of death for terrorists as well as destruction animations. Hell, I was amazed to see a stack of boxes getting squeezed by a door in the third mission, it's all quite joy to look at even if it's scripted. And well, it does hurt occasionally when it comes to enemies deaths. Like, when you shot with pistol at melee enemy into knee and he suddenly teleported half-meter away to the door, swirled and fell toward the door, just to get it open.

But core gameplay of Counter-Strike doesn't translate well at all into linear levels of single-player. What you bassicly will do, is to shoot few bullets into heads, while taking some hitscan bullets back. Repeat it on every enemy. Until the end of the game. It really is repetive and boring. Weapons don't matter much, all of them are good enough for bursting enemy again and again. Grenades aren't given often and flashbang don't seem to be as useful as in multiplayer. Smoke grenade is more offensive there though, making enemies cough instead sometimes. There is little enemy variety as well, you just got whatever hitscan stupid enemy, stationary snipers with laser, whatever melee enemy that rushes you and terrorist with freaking bazooka that is pain to avoid too! So, burst headshot, and burst headshot, repeat repeat repeat.
It also finally get to have some music there. For once. So, something definitely good.

Counter-Strike Condition Zero is better offer than Counter-Strike 1.6 and has more value for solo players, but it's still not good enough to get me much interested in such twitchy realistical shooter. I still wouldn't recommend new people, especially with newer CS titles out there, only those who already play Counter-Strike should check out this one.

I bought 1.6 and I noticed "Condition Zero" and "Condition Zero Deleted Scenes" popped up in my library.  That's a plus, it comes for free with the original counter-strike.

Condition Zero is amazing.  It's the Counter-Strike gameplay we all expect, but with a teambuilding menu and a campaign that bears similarities to Unreal Tournament 2004.  Across all the different maps, you'll be fighting the terrorists with your co-op bots, all of which have custom statistics, weapons and stats for Skill, Bravery, and Co-op.  The AI is competent and even unforgiving, minus the annoying standoffs between T's and a riot shielding bot, and the game remains a lot of fun as you have a 'tour' of each map with multiple side-objectives and a round counter.  If you can win three rounds and be ahead by two, and complete your objectives, you move onto the next round.  Trying to balance out easy victories versus, say, completing a round in 75 seconds or getting three tactical shield kills, is surprisingly difficult at times and gives the game a lot of replay value as each difficulty has a new set of objectives (don't even bother with Expert).

Now, let's talk about CZ Deleted Scenes.  I've always wondered if Valve ever considered making a Half-Life style campaign for Counter-Strike.  It seems like such an excellent idea... and this seems to be a direct message to me saying "Been there, Done that."  That's right, this is a campaign, complete with events and mission-specific objectives.  In Counter-Strike.  That's where the praise ends, becuase Deleted Scenes is atrocious.  Don't get your hopes up like I did, it's one big steaming turd of broken hitboxes, amazingly horrible voice acting, and OCCASIONALLY showing a small amount of promise as a good game before more turds go into the fan.
--
These two games along with 1.6 knock GO out of the park.  If you want a Counter-Strike game for both online and offline, look no further than the CS 1.6 + CZ bundle.  Probably some of the greatest $10 you'll ever spend.  Also, there's no chance of an MP shutdown, since Valve holds the servers up with Steamworks to this day-- not that it would shut down, 1.6 is 20,000 concurrent players strong at all times.

EDIT: Okay, maybe [strike]30,000[/strike] 50,000 people... not bad for a game from the 90's.

As dated as this game may be, compared to Global Offensive. Condition Zero is a mainly singleplayer focused Counter Strike title oddly enough. Which its the very old unreal style campaign, not the story driven one we now see in a regualr shooter. So; is it as fun as newer Counter Strike titles? Yes, maybe even a bit more. Has it aged well? No. It a very love hate relationship between me and the campaign style here. I like the ai team mate selection gimmick, allowing you to choose better, people to be with assuming you have the right points to buy them before the match begins. The stat's on them which are skill, co-op, and bravery actually matter and can have very noticable effects on how they move around the map. Me, I personally think Travis, the riot shield weilding badass of 300 confirmed kills is someone that is a required team mate. Where as one may go with Pete someone who as balanced stats across the board, but only has a smg. There is actually a pretty good amount of tactical feel to this, as many times I was stuck on a level I could switch out team mates and DESTROY. BUt this campaign style is a little.......... frustrating? In each match there are a certain preset requirements for you to complete. These are the BAIN OF COUNTER STRIKE, as some on the expert difficulty are masochistically made. Kill and enemy with a knife and survive the round? Fuck no. Besides that, I recommend this game. Also shotguns are much better in source.

One of the worst FPS games I've ever played. Weapons feel terrible and behave very differently compared to the multi-player versions of those exact same weapons. AI is horrible. Visuals are decent for a game running on top of the goldsrc engine but at the same time visuals are not very optimised causing slowdowns now and then. Sounds and music are low quality stuff. Voice acting is ridiculously bad. There are plenty of issues to talk about. But all this is mostly forgivable stuff.

Why you might ask? It's because of the mess that is the development history of this game. It was originally conceived in 2000. It was announced in 2001 at E3. However the studio that started the development, Rogue Entertainment, went defunct later that year. The development was then handed over to Gearbox Software but they were not allowed to complete this game after missing out the 2002 deadline. Then the bits and pieces were sticked together in a rush by Ritual Entertainment in 2003 but that work was for naught. It's a miracle that CS:CZ was even released at all. The fourth studio to work with this game, the newly founded Turtle Rock Studios, abandoned the whole single-player campaign to make their own thing. CS:CZ was eventually released in 2004 as a multi-player focused training game with bots.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=311274615

CS:CZ:DS offers a curious peek into the future of what could have been. More refined version of CS:CZ:DS is what the grand single-player Counter-Strike game should have been. Instead we got a campaign about series of matches against bots with challenges in CS:CZ. That's all fine and dandy but that isn't very interesting. What's interesting about CS:CZ:DS is that here we have a game, that's more of a precursor to Call of Duty, and a game that has a lot in common with the Call of Duty: Modern Warfare games, and other "Modern Military Shooters" in-general.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=311286905

CS:CZ:DS is a long pipe FPS, that features series of disconnected missions, extremely heavy scripting, NPC interaction similar to the Call of Duty, similarly boring repetitive gunplay, vehicle battles against Hind helicopter, explosions, terrorists launching nukes from old Soviet missile silos, and all the other stuff except the high quality craftsmanship that goes into the Call of Duty games.

I bought the game when it was originally released in 2004 and it was pretty bad even then. I just installed CS:CZ to replay it since it was release for Linux in 2013 and I'm mostly spending my time in Linux thesedays. The CS:CZ:DS can be an interesting precursor for the modern military shooters if you're interested in playing that kind of stuff but in-generally people should avoid this game for what it is. It's an unfinished single-player Counter-Strike game that features normal Counter-Strike multi-player mode with slightly updated graphics and bots.

First of all, I would like to say that following comments are releted with neither "[i]Counter-Strike: Condition Zero[/i]", nor "[i]Counter-Strike 1.6[/i]"; the comments are soly about "[b]Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes[/b]". Both CS 1.6 and CS:CZ are great games regardless...

If you check the Wikipedia and Wikia articles of CS:CZ, you will find out loong story of the development of the game; it was a disaster... Valve ordered the game to Rogue Entertainment in 2000, however the departure of the producer of the studio to Sony led the company defunct. After that failed startup, Valve gave the project to Gearbox Software which made a remarkable progress however failed to meet the deadline. Therefore, pissed Valve took the project from them and gave it to Ritual Entertainment. The "clever" people in Ritual decided to remake the game instead of developing well designed job of Gearbox. Then, ta taaaa; the gold version the game was boring, dull, unpolished and even clunky. The critiques were so bad that Valve decided to pull the game back and ask Turtle Rock Studios to complete the job. Turtle Rock restarted the work of Gearbox and completed the game that we have now as CS:CZ which is quite nice. But how about "Deleted Scenes"? Well, that single player game was released as a free addon to actual CS:CZ with the name of Deleted Scenes.

Yeah, that was the story of the development. But, is it worth to play Deleted Scenes? Not at all!

All 19 missions are totally uninspired and dull. The game shamelessly respawns enemies to the locations that you have already cleared. Worst, you killed a guy in the corner, you want to take that corner as a cover, right? Na na na na naaa; a new enemy is likely to be respawned right back of you. The developers did not even bother to respawn those enemies to a fairly distant location. If you are annoyed with the instant back spawning of Arch-Vile in Doom 3, you will be pissed in this game which is not even a fantastic horror FPS...

Deleted Scenes has one of the most linear level progress ever; it can even compete nowaday's modern shooters such as COD in the case of linear level progress... I can understand the need for linearity in order to have scripted events which are pretty much the curse of nowadays' shooters. However, the game does not let you backtrack most of the times. It is not like "hey, you fell down from that roof which is not reachable right now" scenario; you pass a door and after a short loading, that door is now cannot be openned in the very same level! You are simply caged between the loading points. I do not play nowadays' noob shooters, thus I have few information about their level progress but that does sound even foolish for those games. Gold key seeking in the mazes of Doom 1 is way more innovative even for "today"...

Conclusion;

I cannot say "do not buy" Deleted Scenes; it is bundles with Counter-Strike and Counter-Strike: Condition Zero. But I can easily say that do not bother to play that game. If you are too bored and looking for something to kill you time, grab one of the F2P games... The only reason that I played and even finished all the levels of this game is my current computer is so crappy that it can handle very few games; that is one of them. That is it...

Peace...

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a first-person shooter game from Valve. It is the next installment of the Counter-Strike series. Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is basically a slightly improved version of the original Counter-Strike, but with many addition to the game, it can also be considered as standalone expansion pack.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero gameplay is 100% the same with original Counter-Strike. But Counter-Strike: Condition Zero has new Tour of Duty mode, more maps and the new singleplayer campaign named Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes. Tour of Duty is a singleplayer mode game that is basically has the same game mode, but has some challenges objective that needs to be completed to win the map. Counter-Strike: Condition Zero also introduce offline multiplayer bots, where you can play against AI controlled player in offline game.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero graphics is also basically the same as Counter-Strike, only has some improved models, textures and maps, but older maps are still included in the game.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a good improvements to Counter-Strike. I recommend this.

Bought at Price: $100 (for Valve Complete Pack)

Single player Counter-Strike was always an interesting concept to throw around. So much in fact, a small studio completed it.

A quick reminder, this game was designed around Half Life. Linear gameplay in a compact space should be expected. This doesn't mean its bad - plenty of single player games are linear - it just takes time to understand if you haven't played Half Life. Level layouts and item interaction are not going to be what you are used to. Is the game perfect? No, and no game is. Due to the for mentioned old game design theories, certain pathways and mechanics will seem odd. Getting players to do a 180, and come back the way they came can be confusing.

I've always been a Counter-Strike fan. There's no denying that. If you are well, you will have a blast with this title (and the Deleted Scenes). This title brings you back to the roots of CS, which allows for a neat experience. Would you play it again and again because of that? Probably not, because I completed the game in 4 hours and that felt like it was enough. I can only really see someone playing this if they are using an old machine with poor internet connection.

Being an old engine, AI isn't very good either. The way around that is to place environmental hazards everywhere such as trip mines. Because of this, it feels more like Half Life then Counter-Strike.

To wrap this up, if you are a CS player, you are missing something by not playing this. If you aren't, go on in life, there's nothing demanding here for you to play.

Out of all the Counter-Strike games, this one is probably the most underrated. However, that doesn't make it a bad game in anyway.

For one thing, CZ doesn't deliver anything really new into Counter-Strike compared to 1.6.

There are a few things they did add.

+A Campaign Mode
+Re-decorated maps
+New Maps
+A Mission Mode
+New sound effects
+Slightly beter graphics

And when you compare 1.6 to CZ, they're nearly IDENTICAL.

I would only get this for the Campaign and the Mission Mode. For Core Multiplayer CS gameplay, get 1.6. However, if you want to try out the Deleted Scenes campaign, this is worth your time.

Though the game is outdated, its pretty damn good.  The first 3 hours of failing were rough and i gave up on it for like a month....the singleplayer and harsh community helped me improve and though I'll never be as pro as them, you'll find the fun. The community is rather small being dated but is fun, nice, and absolutly crazy. Beats any other modern gaming community i know. The core gameplay still works awesomely. And nothing is better than pure chaos in  16 v 16 fight. I'll  eventually switch to   CSGO when I get a better hardware but if the community is still there I wont mind hoppin on in the future. It's worth the buy if your willing to commit yourself to the learning curve, but don't expect much. This is a true example  of how older games got it right and continues to worl with it. Graphics are'nt everything. That said I should probably due the same for CS 1.6. It's great if your willing to commit with little expectations but not if your all graphics and a big community and constant new things. Its really the community that won me :) See ya!!!

The gameplay is basically the same but with new maps, updated old maps, AI player or bots and better buy menu. I recommend this.

Condition Zero was the last GoldSource game published by Valve. The development of CZ began in 2001 by Rogue Entertainment and was passed to Gearbox Software (Half-Life: Opposing Force), then Ritual Entertainment (SiN), and finally Turtle Rock Studios (L4D/L4D2). 

While Turtle Rock Studios' later collaborations with Valve, the two Left 4 Dead games, were a big success CZ didn't turn out so well. This hyped singleplayer Counter-Strike title gave us nothing more than a mappack, most of which were just remasterings of 1.6 maps, which had to be completed with the aid of friendly A.I. You have to assemble your team of counter terrorists in CZ, the better bots being more expensive in in-game currency than the weaker ones. Once your squad is all set you're off to beat terrorists X amount of times on a certain map to continue to the next map to do the same exact thing. The main flaw with this campaign is that in order to progress the player must often partake in counter-intuitive challenges, such as killing three enemies with the auto shotgun while surviving the round. It takes what could have been a nice simple campaign and making it very tedious and overly long. Hey, if Turtle Rock wanted a longer game, they easily could have whipped up more maps. Most of the maps in this game are slight redisgns of Condition Zero Deleted Scenes. Oh, speaking of which:

Condition Zero Deleted Scenes is an unfinished but functional version of Ritual's CZ. It's a mission pack of 18 levels and 99% of its assets are recycled in Turtle Rock's CZ. Deleted Scenes is a great campaign with mod support.

In conclusion, Condition Zero isn't that good but it's a worthy buy for Deleted Scenes. Valve must have known CZ wasn't as good as its Deleted Scenes since most of the advertisements show Deleted Scenes levels.

One of the buggiest games I've ever played. It seems a joke. These are the reasons to not buy this game ever:

1. Very repetitive
2. Non sense puzzles to solve to make the game last longer: Stupid like a switch does not work until you kill an enemy that is hidden somewhere.
3. Everything is scripted: Sometimes there is friendly fire and sometimes not, some enemies can be killed with barrels some not, enemies will teleport infront of you.
4. Very poorly scripted: NPC can block your pass to finish a mission so you have to load a previous save to finish a mission. NPC are ridicously exposed so they can be killed and missin fails.
5. Very buggy: Sometimes you cant climb a ladder or sometimes you have to load a previous save because something that was supossed to happen didn't happened.
6. No realism at all: Things like killing bosses with 5 headshots with an sniper rifle, enemies shooting behind bushes where you cannot see through, enemies shooting you in darkness, etc.
7. Really poor difficulty level: I played in hard mode. The first missions were just fine in difficultie but for some reason, the more I played, the more overclocked the enemies are: yes, overclocked. Enemies will run faster, shoot faster and need 3 headshots to be killed. The last mission I played (in japan) was so ridiculous that enemies could kill you in 1ms after you cross a wall, or walk 30 meters in 1 second, just like the first half life ninjas but with bigger guns.
8. The saves are broken: I've never seen this in my life. The save files have two major bugs. The first one is that each time you load a save file, your weapon starts firing until you switch weapon. This makes you loose a lot of ammo. The second bug is that when you load a file, you dont appear exactly were you should be and you dont have the same ammo and health. Actually I got stuck in a situation where I was appearing in front an enemy who killed me in 1 millisecond after loading.

An obscure sequel to CS 1.6 that failed to match the same level of success in it's multiplayer. Hardly updated anymore, contains more maps, a Tour of Duty campaign, basic bot support and basically could be said that its CS 1.7 but is seriously inferior to CS 1.6's gameplay due to the bigger hitboxes having less focus on mods since 1.6 was taking the helm for one thing and the fact its simply put - an expansion pack to the great game in the first place.

Put your money on CS 1.6/CS:GO which has much more concurrent players, official and unofficial support, recognition and stability. This was a waste of money even if purchased alongside the VALVe pack/Steam Sale. Jess Cliffe (the pedo) and Minh Le would agree. Even Deleted Scenes (which this game is a part of) felt more of a finished product than this despite the campaign (both Tour of Duty and Deleted Scenes) being nothing short of frantic explosions, tight gunplay and versatile tactical action.

In Counter-Strike: Condition Zero, you play a cop named Carl Winslow. As Captain of the Chicago P.D., you are the best of "the Prairie State." President Clinton drafts you into S.E.A.L team six, a promising squadron of the United States' finest. Your mission is to kill as many sand terrorists as possible. 

*In the game, you get to do awesome things like: disarm bombs, rescue hostages, buy weapons, and kill. 
*The graphics in this game are true-to-life, and require today's bestest and beastiest PCs to play it.
*Counter-Strike: Condition Zero has a spin-off (and less successful) game called "Counter-Strike 1.6," a fan mod. The mod's *latest version, v 1.7 has been in nine years in development and is yet to come out.

Counter-Strike is a first-person shooter in which players join either the terrorist team, the counter-terrorist team, or become spectators. Each team attempts to complete their mission objective and/or eliminate the opposing team. Each round starts with the two teams spawning simultaneously.

A player can choose to play as one of eight different default character models (four for each side, although Counter-Strike: Condition Zero added two extra models, bringing the total to ten). Players are generally given a few seconds before the round begins (known as "freeze time") to prepare and buy equipment, during which they cannot attack or move (one notable exception is that a player may receive damage during freeze time. This happens when a map is changed to spawn players at a certain height above the ground, thus causing fall damage to the player. This is a method map designers use to alter the starting "HP" of players on a map). They can return to the buy area within a set amount of time to buy more equipment (some custom maps included neutral "buy zones" that could be used by both teams). Once the round has ended, surviving players retain their equipment for use in the next round; players who were killed begin the next round with the basic default starting equipment.

Cs 1.6 with graphical improvements and bot mode.

Graphics
Same as CS but a few improvements. New player model 1 for each team. Slight improvements to weapons and such. But This is 2004 And Halflife 2 came out about the same time with the source engine. BUT this is on Goldsrc engine for a game that was realeased in 2004. 

AI: 8/10 
Has a "Campaign" which is basically matches against bots where you try to complete goals like
"Kill 4 enemys"
"Rescue 2 Hostages"
"use a Flashbang"
Makes a nice Practice mode for singleplayer because the original CS didnt come with bots. The enemy AI is quite good if you arent a CS Pro and I had to reapet level quite a few times. 

Sound: 6/10
Slight Improvements but overall the same

Gameplay: 8/10
Same As the original counter strike but i feel the hitboxes are a bit bigger. Recoil is still there so Spray-and-Pray isnt the way to go.

Overall 7/10

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a first-person shooter game from Valve. It is the next installment of the Counter-Strike series. Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is basically a slightly improved version of the original Counter-Strike, but with many addition to the game, it can also be considered as standalone expansion pack.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero gameplay is 100% the same with original Counter-Strike. But Counter-Strike: Condition Zero has new Tour of Duty mode, more maps and the new singleplayer campaign named Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes. Tour of Duty is a singleplayer mode game that is basically has the same game mode, but has some challenges objective that needs to be completed to win the map. Counter-Strike: Condition Zero also introduce offline multiplayer bots, where you can play against AI controlled player in offline game.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero graphics is also basically the same as Counter-Strike, only has some improved models, textures and maps, but older maps are still included in the game.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a good improvements to Counter-Strike. I recommend this.

Buried beneath the successes of Valve's blockbuster titles, Condition Zero is a hidden gem that boasts both singleplayer and multiplayer entertainment. The main reason you should consider this is for the Deleted Scenes section, which contains a variety of content not used by the base game. From a legitimate story mode (with rather cinematic and interesting moments) to fun new weapons (M60's and blowtorches, to name a few), it pretty much is worth the price of admission. The base game is decent as well, but it can be easily replicated by playing CS:S or Global Offensive with bots. Deleted Scenes features a story mode with, well, a story. 18 unconnected stories, sure, but the variety of locations ingame makes up for the lack of consistency.

Overall, it's a fun diversion when you're yearning for another story-based game from Valve. At a price of 5-10 dollars, you're basically getting two high-quality games for the price of one. I would recommend it to Counter-Strike and Half-Life fans alike.

Right, let's try this again shall we? But first, cast your mind back to issue 132 of PC ZONE. It was the one with the words 'Exclusive Review: Counter-Strike: Condition Zero' emblazoned on the front cover, replete with a balaclava-clad man about to be unwittingly run over by three helicopters. Inside was a six-page review - or should I say lamentation - about how the game was nothing like we'd expected it to be.

The thing was, right up until the moment the review code plopped onto our desks - and despite development having changed hands from Gearbox to Ritual - we'd been led to believe that Condition Zero would comprise of a group of ever-harder missions, in which you and a team of intelligent AI-controlled counter-terrorist bots would battle it out across a set of maps against terrorist forces in either bomb defusal or hostage rescue missions. So basically, just like online Counter-Strike, only with bots and personal tasks to complete in each map.

Picking this up is at least worth it for the Deleted Scenes missions.  But I know what you're thinking - "Counter-Strike done Cawadoody style?"  Surprisingly the missions are well done, with just a few misfires (like the Obligatory Stealth Section and one mission with lots of rocket launchers and snipers placed where you can't avoid them often).  Basically, it's a great excuse to use those nice CS weapons without having to deal with bunny-hoppers and AWPers.  Also, the main game's multiplayer practice missions are nice exercises to bone up on your skills with.

Singleplayer is relatively simple and straightforward; fun, though. The names on your teammates are a nice touch, but I get worn out rooting for Cooper when he's the last one left, because he can't hit the broadside of a barnacle.

Counter Strike: Condition Zero seems good at first. A single player Counter Strike experience? A campaign for one of the most played games ever? BOTS? Sign me up, right? Well, it would have been absoultely good if it was made by one company and published by Valve. You see, it was going to be made by one company, but for some reason that I don't know, they gave it to another company. Than ANOTHER company. It just finally ended up at whoever made it today.

The game itself is NOT bad. It's actually fun. I quite enjoyed playing the campaign, even though I had no idea what was going on. The only thing that lacked was the "tour of duty" thing where you play with bots. It was really short and I beat it in, what, 2 hours?

I don't know why people always diss this game. I liked this game.

Overall, this game gets a 89/100 for me.

Edit: Still playing it in 2018

To start out, I've really got more like five hundred hours in this game. I started playing it obsessively long before Valve thought to add playtime records.

It's fun.

The bots are fairly competent as long as you disallow them from buying grenades and the list of maps that come prepackaged far outstrips that of the original Counter-Strike. (They're also far prettier, at least as much as they can be on the GoldSrc engine). Hostages are, as always, somewhat brain-dead, but they're nowhere near as bad as the ones in Counter-Strike: Source--although the fact they all wear identical orange jumpsuits makes me wonder who really are the good and bad guys. Isn't variety the spice of life?
Sound design and quality are improved slightly from the original game and many of the less generic maps lack that kitchen_rats look that's become so indicative of Half-Life's engine, so that's a plus. At the same time, a lot of maps have odd collision detection issues and I'm somewhat bothered by the fact that Counter-Terrorists are as chatty over the radio as their criminal counterparts.

Counter-Strike: Condition Zero picks up the classic CS formula, and takes it to a new level with the addition of a singleplayer campaing; Deleted Scenes. It also features another singleplayer mode in which you can play missions in the classic maps from CS. As for the multiplayer itself, well, it's basically the same as the original CS, with two new character models for each faction, and, for the first time, built-in bots.

However, as this game was released shortly before the release of Counter-Strike: Source, it suffered from that: most CS players would stay with the classic CS, and the new players (or those willing to switch) went to Source. Due to this, this game is not as popular as every other CS game.

This was the very first PC first-person shooter game i have ever played on PC (way before Half-Life and the original Counter Strike) back in the year when it came out. I remember when my uncle's friend gave us the CD back then. And i started playing it with my sister, she took charge of the keyboard arrows while i was aiming and shooting with the mouse during the first mission "Recoil". 
I don't think we got past the second mission and after sometime later i started playing the game alone but never finished the whole singleplayer campaing myself until several years later.
I always liked the singleplayer missions, soundtrack and the goldsrc feel, even if the game might be "outdated" for the time it came out (2004, same year as Counter Strike Source and Half-Life 2)
In terms of multiplayer gameplay it is pretty much the same as the original Counter Strike (1.6) with graphical changes, new maps and other stuff but i'll always prefer 1.6 when it comes to style and gameplay.
I do recommend it if you wanna have a singleplayer experience with Counter Strike or just wanna play the slighly changed multiplayer.
I'll always come back to play Deleted Scenes and always have a nostalgic feel when i play the very first mission while the fact remains that Jeffrey Epstein truly didn't and never killed himself.

This recommendation is for Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes.

What can I say, other than it's basically Call of Duty made with the GoldSRC engine.

It doesn't look good, animations are clunky, it usually takes enemies two or three headshots to die (seriously) and the stealth parts can get really annoying.

Even with that, it managed to keep me entertained long enough to actually finish it, but in short bursts. I don't think anyone will find themselves playing this game for more than 40 minutes or so at a time.

I give it a 6 / 10 only because I finished it and because FPSs are one of my favourite genres of gaming, but if you're not into FPSs I'm pretty sure you'll give it a lower score.

This Game was released way back in 2004 on Steam and it still has it's active and loyal Player base to this Day.

What makes this Game so great?

It is a First Person Shooter in a line of Progenitor series that started in the late 90s.
Even though the Single Player mode is ignored by Most Player however it's Multiplayer popularity still remains today. There are various Multiplayer Servers around the World with tons of Mods to make Player experience more engaging. 

Popular Mods include Death-match, Gun-game, Zombie Mode and Clan Wars.

There are 2 Single Player Modes - 
1. Tour of Duty
2. Deleted Scenes

Unlike it's predecessor, Condition Zero has the ability to add Bots to Multiplayer Servers.

Some of the most Popular Maps people play in includes Dust2, Inferno, Downed, Aztec, Italy and many more community submitted Maps.

If you are the part of that Group of Kids that started their Gaming Career with this Game then i would recommend you Buy it just for the sake of Old Memories and also new experiences at the Servers. For new Players unknown to this Game, you will surely enjoy this Game with it's simplistic Graphics and interesting Modded Servers.

Condition Zero is merely Counter 1.6 with bots. Sure, they make an effort to add structure by giving you points after every mission to choose better cobinations of bots to accompany you, but its just the standard multiplayer maps and gametypes.

However, it comes packaged with an extra game called 'Deletd Scenes, which is an amazing single player title. If you can see past the action cliches and terrible accents, then this game'll provide hours of entertainment in a raft of unique, fully fledged missions. Settings are well varied as you take your place in the ranks of different national anti-terrorist organisations.

Despite offering a brand new setting, the game utilises plenty of familiar assets from multiplayer CounterStrike, making it an easy game for any 1.6 or CS:Source pro to get straight into.

Condition Zero in itself is a unique package, allowing for progression of teammates in an AI environment. Nowhere near as popular as it's predecssor or successor, Condition Zero still provided a unique experience with an interesting change in visual design that is quite often forgotten.

Deleted Scenes provided the first step towards trying to turn a very popular and successful competitive shooter into a single-player goal-oriented experience. While not inherently mind-blowing, the low cost of Condition Zero in combination with some neat ideas put together to provide a small, but interesting run through the ideas of what Ritual Entertainment was putting together for their contribution.

Simple, basic, still interesting.

This was a singleplayer campaign addon to CS:CZ. I personally had fun playing it, but felt that it would have been gloriously entertaining as an online co-op game. Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is a revamped version of the original Counter-Strike with new maps, new graphics, new weapons and interface improvements. It also includes a single-player mode with difficulty levels and bots you can swap out as you progress through the 'tour of duty'. It's fun on Normal difficulty and below, but on Hard and above you need to be good at CS to really make progress. There's also custom campaigns available online.

The 'Deleted Scenes' are a series of single-player missions. Unlike the regular CZ, these are scripted, generally linear/cinematic in nature and put you in a wider variety of unconnected situations including bank robberies and drug busts. Some of the missions are great, some of them are average; sometimes it can get quite campy as evidenced by my original 'review' above, and there are only a handful of custom missions I found online. Almost none of them really go into the backstory of the terrorism and assorted nefarious acts on display here: you're just the tip of the spear meant to counter terrorist aggression.

The development of this game is rather storied, with four separate companies working on it before its release. It was intended to be a revamp of the original CS with a single-player mode, then it was turned into a game with single-player missions (the Deleted Scenes(. Then it was restarted again in the vein of the first version, which shipped with the missions anyway. For more details, you can read [url=http://counterstrike.wikia.com/wiki/Development_of_Counter-Strike:_Condition_Zero]this[/url].

If you're a fan of classic CS and feel like something different, I'd say give it a shot. I'm not sure if it'll do anything for you unless you're a CS/oldschool shooter fan, but since it's an old CS game there's still plenty of people playing it online.
Worth getting if you like counter-strike, it comes with CS 1.6 and Condition Zero, and also has a single player mode in the deleted scenes.

Many (most?) people play either the original CS or CS:Source, but for me CS:CZ is still the best incarnation of CS. It fixes a lot of the bugs in CS, yet retains that special gameplay which (and let's be honest here) never surfaced in the Source version of CS.
coocl game

Nice updates to the levels, textures, models, sounds, and most importantly, the Bot/Team-mate AI. Not sure why this game gets the hate it does as it plays almost identical to 1.6.

If you love 1.6, you'll likely enjoy this as well. I especially like all the new levels though many have not yet made it into source.
Play if stoned, otherwise avoid.

Maybe old but its still new

Hi people, I just thougth I'd write a recommendation for this epic early 2000 game. So you play as different factions from the original Counter-Strike from 1998 but with updated graphics and infact new models. The game has AI that attempts to look at you making you think that the AI likes you.. Then they run at you with a machete, and don't forget how you are ALWAYS alone even though you saw 5 swat guys behind you  1 min ago. So, this game in a nutshell: Lone wolf, cool, time killer and something you  can play without stopping. It's not like you get stuck in Sierras obvious traps and puzzles. I also recommend you to YouTube it, because a video is always better than words! (fuck you) have an awesome friggin day.. (that was for me) enjoy DS.

I've put more hours in this game, than I ever should have. But I don't regret any second of it. 

This game sums up my entire summers as a teen, lots of fun servers, people, and just is a great shooter in general.
